div1.p: The solemn earnestness with which Demosthenes undertook this vindication of his whole political life is shown by the unusual and impressive prayer with which he begins, and still more by its repetition. He shows the same spirit in the appeal to the Gods in § 141, with which he introduces his account of the fatal events which led to Chaeronea, and in his peroration (§ 324).

div2.p: 1. toi=s qeoi=s pa=si kai\ pa/sais, to all the Gods and Goddesses. *qeo/s is Goddess as well as God, qea/ being poetic; thus h( qeo/s is the common title of Athena. A slight extension of the solemn formula pa=si kai\ pa/sais becomes absurdly comic in Ar. Av. 866 eu)/xesqe o)/rnisin *)olumpi/ois kai\ *)olumpi/h|si pa=si kai\ pa/sh|sin.

2. eu)/noian: eu)/noia may mean de- votion based on any superiority or merit, including loyalty of a subject to a prince or of a servant to his master (even of a dog to his mistress), devotion to a benefactor, and even enthusiasm for the success of a contestant in the games (though felt by a stranger). Here it means a good citizen's loyal devotion to the state.

See Jackson's note on eu)/noia in Trans. of Cambr. Philol. Soc. II. p. 115, where he explains the word in Arist. Pol. I. 6 (1255.a, 17) as “loyalty, i.e. the willing obedience which an inferior renders to a kind and considerate superior.” He refers especially to Arist. Eth. IX. 5, §§ 3, 4 (1167.a, 18), o(/lws d) eu)/noia di) a)reth\n kai\ e)piei/keia/n tina gi/netai, o(/tan tw| fanh=| kalo/s tis h)\ a)ndrei=os h)/ ti toiou=ton. —e)/xwn diatelw=: a)nti\ tou= a)ei\ e)/xw, *)attikw=s. Schol. (See M.T. 879.) The words e)/xwn diatelei= with eu)/noia probably occurred in Ctesiphon's decree. Aeschines (III. 49) quotes from the decree o(/ti diatelei= kai\ le/gwn kai\ pra/ttwn: see the spurious indictment (below) § 54.10, and § 57.2-3.

3. u(pa/rcai moi, be granted me (be made available to me). The fundamental idea of u(pa/rxw in this sense is best seen in ta\ u(pa/rxonta, the resources or the existing conditions, i.e. what is available, what one has to depend on: see note on u(pa/rxein § 95.5, and be/ltiston u(pa/rxei, IX. 5.

4. a)gw=na: see note on a)gwni/zomai, § 3.3.—e)/peiq), secondly: simple e)/peita (without de/) is the regular rhetorical
formula after prw=ton me/n (see §§ 8, 18, 177, 235, 248: cf. 267). Thucydides generally has this, but often e)/peita de/.

5. o(/per e)sti\: sc. eu)/xomai, refer- ring to the whole sentence o(/per... a)kroa/sasqai. The relation of o(/per to tou=to here is clearly that of o(/ ti (§ 8.6) to the following tou=to.—e)sti\ ma/lisq) u(pe\r u(mw=n, concerns you especially (more than myself).

6. eu)sebei/as: referring to the oath (§ 2). Greek eu)se/beia reached a lower level than our piety, including negative abstinence from impiety, so that one who does not break his oath is so far eu)sebh/s.—tou=to parasth=sai u(mi=n, may put this into your hearts: tou=to refers back emphatically to the omitted antecedent of o(/per, as ou(/tws (§ 2.7) to that of w(s, and is explained by mh\ to\n a)nti/dikon k.t.l.
8. tou= pw=s...dei=: explained by to\ kai\...xrh/sasqai (end of § 2): cf. peri\ tou= o(/ntina tro/pon xrh\ zh=n, Plat. Rep. 352 D.

1. to\n o(/rkon: the Heliastic oath, which each judge had sworn. The document in XXIV. 149—151 purporting to be this famous oath (hardly authentic) has this clause: kai\ a)kroa/somai tou= kathgo/rou kai\ tou= a)pologoume/nou o(moi/ws a)mfoi=n. For the connection of the laws with the oath, see note on § 6.5.
2. dikai/ois, just provisions.

3. a)kroa/sasqai: this (*s) or a)kro- a=sqai (L) is far preferable to the emendation a)kroa/sesqai, the fut. infin. being exceptional with to/. The infin. with to/ here denotes simply the provision for hearing both sides impartially and is not in oratio obliqua (M.T. 96, 111).

4. to\ mh\ prokategnwke/nai: not having decided against (kata/) either party in advance, the perf. expressing completion (M.T. 109): to\ mh\ prokatagnw=nai would be timeless, like to\ a)kroa/sasqai (above) and to\ a)podou=nai and to\ e)a=sai (below).—ou)de\ (sc. mo/non), nor only (cf. § 93.1, 2).
5. i)/shn (pred.), in equal measure. —kai\ th=| ta/cei...xrh/sasqai, i.e. to allow everyone to adopt not only (kai\) that order of argument but also (kai\) that general plan of defence which etc.

6. a)pologi/a| refers strictly to the defence, which alone remained.—w(s... e(/kastos: e(/kastos is made subject of the relative clause, as this precedes; we reverse the order, and translate it with xrh/sasqai.—tw=n a)gwnizome/nwn e(/kastos (not e(ka/teros), acc. to Weil, is “tout homme qui plaide sa
cause,” a general expression. He remarks that a)gwni/zomai applies especially to the defendant.

This is a dignified appeal against the offensive demand of Aeschines (III. 202), that the court should either refuse to hear Demosthenes or (at least) compel him to follow his adversary's order of argument. Both parties could not be heard impartially if one were compelled by the court itself to present his case in the most damaging order at his opponent's dictation.
1. polla\: sc. e)lattw/mata.
2. kai\ mega/la, even serious.
3. a)gwni/zomai, like a)gw/n, used of contests of all kinds, here of a lawsuit. See the pun on the two meanings of a)gwni/sasqai peri\ qana/tou in IV. 47.
4. diamartei=n, to forfeit: cf. a)po- sterei=sqai, § 5.4, and the following words.

5. mh\ e(lei=n th
 grafh
, not to gain his case: cf. *)olu/mpia nika=n, Thuc. I. 126; yh/fisma nika=|, Aesch. III. 68; polla\s...grafa\s diw/cas ou)demi/an ei(=len, Ant. 2, A.a, 5. A victorious defendant is said grafh
 (di/khn) a)pofugei=n, a defeated defendant grafh
 (di/khn) o)flei=n.—a)ll) e)moi\ me
: a familiar a)posiw/phsis, often quoted by the rhetoricians. What is plainly meant would sound unpleasant (dusxere/s) and suggest disaster in the opening of his speech. See Quint. IX. 2, 54, who quotes “quos ego— sed motos praestat componere fluctus,” Aen. I. 135.

7. e)k periousi/as, at an advantage, lit. from an abundance, like a rich man who stakes little compared with his wealth. In Luke xxi. 4, the rich cast into the treasury “of their abundance” or “superfluity,” e)k tou= perisseu/ontos au)toi=s.

8. e(/teron d) (sc. e)la/ttwma) corre- sponds to e(\n me\n in 3, and keeps up the construction of polla\ e)lattou=mai in 1.—o(\...u(pa/rxei, which is a natural disposition of the whole human race: pa=sin a)nqrw/pois suggests the subject of a)kou/ein and a)/xqesqai, which explain e(/teron.

2. e)sti pro\s h(donh
, makes for pleasure (e)sti
 h(du/, Schol.): cf. Aeschyl. Pr. 494, a)
 ei)/h dai/mosin pro\s h(donh/n.—w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n modifies pa=sin. Aeschines (III. 241) had warned the court against the self-glorification of Demosthenes.
5. a)polu/sasqai: see § 50.6.

6. kai\ pepoi/hka kai\ pepoli/teu- mai: a familiar form of rhetorical amplification (opposed to modern ideas of style), for which ordinary speech would use pepoli/teumai alone. Other instances are bebou/lhtai kai\ proh/|rhtai (§ 2.6), pepragme/nwn kai\ pepoliteume/nwn and kateyeu/dou kai\ die/balles (§ 11.3-7), e)tragw/|dei kai\ diech/|ei (§ 13.6), die/balle kai\ diech/|ei (§ 14.2), e)di/dacas kai\ diech=lqes (§ 22.10), polemei=n kai\ diafe/resqai (§ 31.4). In these cases one verb is generic and the other specific; but sometimes two verbs of nearly or quite the same meaning are used together for a similar rhetorical effect, as pra/ttein kai\ poiei=n (§ 62.4), zw/ntwn kai\ o)/ntwn (§ 72.3).
7. badi/zw, proceed, more formal than come or go.
8. w(s metriw/tata: cf. the full form w(s a)\n du/nwmai metriw/tata, § 256.9.
9. o(/ ti...a)nagka/zh|, whatever the case itself may require of me (lit. compel me): with a)nagka/zw without an infin. cf. Quint. XI. I, 22, qui hoc se coegisset.
10. di/kaios e)/xein: the common personal construction (M.T. 762). The apodosis is future in sense, after the future o(/ ti a)\n a)nagka/zh|.
11. toiou=ton a)gw=n), a suit like this, i.e. in which Ctesiphon is indicted and Demosthenes accused: cf. §§ 12—16.
1. a)\n o(mologh=sai (so *s and L): a)/n after a comma is allowed when words belonging to the same clause precede, as here u(ma=s pa/ntas (M.T. 222).
3. ou)de\n e)la/ttonos, quite as great.
4. pa/ntwn a)posterei=sqai, to be deprived of anything: cf. pantaxou=, anywhere, § 81.6.

7. o(/sw|per, (by so much) as: the implied tosou/tw| is felt as limiting ma/lista (sc. luphro\n kai\ xalepo/n).— kai\ before to\ tuxei=n expresses the parallelism (so to speak) between losing and gaining the privileges: see a(\ kai\ diekwlu/qh, § 60.4, and note.
Such a kai/ can seldom be expressed in English, except by emphasis.
2. a)ciw= kai\ de/omai: see note on § 4.6.

3. dikai/ws belongs to a)kou=sai, from which it is separated partly for emphasis, and partly to bring it directly before w(/sper. It cannot be taken with a)pologoume/nou, as the laws (§ 2.3) have no reference to a)pologi/a, but require the judges to hear both sides impartially.
4. o( tiqei\s e)c a)rxh=s, i.e. the ori- ginal maker: o( no/mon tiqei/s is used like nomoqe/ths, for the lawgiver, whose title is perpetual.

5. dhmotiko\s, a friend of the people or of popular government: see Ar. Nub. 1187, o( *so/lwn o( palaio\s h)=n filo/dhmos th\n fu/sin.—ou) mo/non...o)mwmoke/nai: i.e. Solon thought that these provisions for an impartial hearing should have not merely the ordinary sanction which all laws have by enactment (tw=| gra/yai), but the further security which they gained by the judges swearing to uphold them. This double sanction was secured by enacting that these provisions of law should be a part of the Heliastic oath. gra/fw, besides meaning to propose a law or decree, often refers to the enactment as a whole, as here.

2. ta\s ai)ti/as kai\ ta\s dia- bola\s, here used like loidori/a te kai\ ai)ti/a in XXII. 21, 22. There ai)ti/a is thus defined, as opposed to e)/legxos: ai)ti/a me\n ga/r e)stin o(/tan tis yilw=| xrhsa/menos lo/gw| mh\ para/sxhtai pi/stin w(=n le/gei, e)/legxos de\ o(/tan w(=n a)\n ei)/ph| tis kai\ ta)lhqe\s o(mou= dei/ch|. Commonly, ai)ti/a refers to an accusation, whether true or false: cf. § 12.7 (ei)/per h)=san a)lhqei=s). See Shilleto on Thuc. I. 23 and 69.

3. tou= pro/teros le/gein: in public suits (grafai/) in the Heliastic courts, each side spoke once (though the time might be divided among several speakers), the plaintiff first; in private suits (di/kai), and in the Areopagus, each side was allowed a second argument.
4. parelqei=n, to escape (get by): w(s e)pi\ drome/wn. Schol.

6. tou= le/gontos u(ste/rou, the second (later) speaker, i.e. the defendant (tou= feu/gontos): see Ar. Vesp. 15, su\ le/con pro/teros, Dem. 1. 16, tou\s u(sta/tous... ei)po/ntas.—di/kai), pleadings, the statement of his rights: cf. § 9.8 (see West.).
—prosde/cetai, shall receive kindly, take under his protection.
7. koino\n: impartial.
8. ou(/tw repeats with emphasis the idea of parasxw\n...a)kroath/n.—dia/gnwsin, decision (between two sides).
2. lo/gon dido/nai, to render an account, used often of the formal accounts which all officers of state rendered at the eu)/qunai: see Aesch. III. 11, 12, and cf. § 62.5 (below), lo/gon...labei=n.
6. o(/ ti...e(ka/stw|: see note on o(/per ...do/chs, § 1.5.
8. parasth=sai: sc. tou\s qeou/s (subj.), as in § 1.6.—tou=to gnw=nai, to give that judgment.

div1.p: the orator replies to charges which are foreign to the indictment (e)/cw th=s grafh=s). We have (1) an introduction in § 9; then (2) he speaks of his private life in §§ 10, 11; then (3) of his public policy in §§ 12—52.

Under (3) we have an introduc- tion (§§ 12—16), and the defence of his policy concerning the Peace of Philocrates (§§ 17—52). The last contains an introduction (§ 17), the narration (§§ 18—49, and the conclusion (§§ 50—52).

div2.p: 1. ei)...kathgo/rhsen, i.e. if he had confined his accusation (in his speech) to the charges in his indictment (grafh/): see the same distinction between kathgorei= and kri/nei in § 15.5, 6.
2. probouleu/matos: the strict name of a bill which had passed only the Senate, though the less exact yh/fisma was often applied to it: see § 56.1.
3. eu)qu\s a)\n a)pelogou/mhn, I should at once proceed (lit. be now proceeding) to my defence, etc. Cf. § 34.4.—ou)k e)la/ttw, quite as much (as in his proper accusation).

4. ta)/lla dieciw\n belongs to both a)nh/lwke and kateyeu/sato.—a)nh/lwke: often of lavish expense.—ta\ plei=sta: the antithesis to the comp. ou)k e)la/ttw seems to show that the superl. is to be taken literally. The statements repudiated by Demosthenes about his private life and the Peace of Philocrates can well be said to outnumber all the others.
7. a)llotriw/teron, less kindly (with greater alienation).

8. tw=n...dikai/wn: like di/kaia, § 7.6. Two genitives with a)kou/w are rare.— u(pe\r: in the same sense as peri/, as often in the orators, who, however, often observe the common distinction. Cf. § 1.5 and § 11.3 and 6, and XXIII. 19, tou\s peri\ tw=n no/mwn lo/gous a)kou/sh| mou.

The reply in §§ 10, 11 to the charges against his private life and character amounts merely to a scornful refusal to discuss them, and an appeal to the judges to decide against him at once if they believe them.

1. peri\ tw=n i)di/wn: with o(/sa beblasfh/mhke (not with le/gw), the omitted antec. of the cognate o(/sa being understood as limiting qea/sasqe ...le/gw, as regards all the calumnies which he has abusively uttered about my private life. The whole sentence peri\ me\n...le/gw is parallel to u(pe\r me\n ...e)ceta/sw in § 11.6. (West., Bl.)— loidorou/menos beblasfh/mhke: for the relation of loidori/a and blasfhmi/a to kathgori/a see § 123.2. blasfhmi/a is slander, a special form of loidori/a, abuse in general. Our word blasphemy (like many others) never goes beyond the special meaning which it derives from the ecclesiastical Greek: cf. angel, apostle, hypocrite, liturgy, litany, etc.
3. toiou=ton: sc. o)/nta (M.T. 911). So belti/w (7) and xei/rona (8).
4. mhde\ fwnh\n a)na/sxhsqe=mhde\ fqeggo/meno/n me a)na/sxhsqe, i.e. stop my speech at once.
5. pa/nta ta\ koina\: i.e. settle the case without reference to my public acts.

7. belti/w kai\ e)k beltio/nwn, better and better born: cf. ti/s w)\n kai\ ti/nwn, § 126.5 (below). See Terent. Ph. i. 2, 65, bonam bonis prognatam.—mhdeno\s tw=n metri/wn xei/rona, i.e. quite as good as any of our respectable citizens (cf. § 126.7): this moderate expression is made more effective by i(/na...le/gw.
12. e)pi\ pollw=n a)gw/nwn: see §§ 249, 250, where he speaks of being brought to trial “daily” after the battle of Chaeronea.

1. kakoh/qhs...eu)/hqes w)|h/qhs: an untranslatable paronomasi/a, the sarcastic effect of which, as pronounced by Demosthenes, can easily be imagined. kakoh/qhs, ill-natured, malicious, is in antithesis to eu)/hqes, good-natured (in the double sense of our simple). The idea (imperfectly expressed) is: malicious (ill-natured) fellow though you are, you conceived this perfectly simple (silly) notion.
3. pepragme/nwn kai\ pepoliteu- me/nwn: see note on § 4.6.

5. tetu/fwmai: cf. tetufw=sqai, IX. 20. If tufw= is connected with *tufw=n or *tufw/s, tetu/fwmai must mean I am distracted or crazed, like e)mbro/nthtos (§ 243.7). If it is derived from tu=fos, mist or smoke (see Lidd. & Sc.), tetu/fwmai means I am stupefied, befogged or wrapt in smoke.

7. pompei/as, ribaldry (procession- talk). See Harpocr.: pompei/as kai\ pompeu/ein a)nti\ tou= loidori/as kai\ loidorei=n. The Scholia have: pompei/as, loidori/as, u(/brews: e)n tai=s pompai=s proswpei=a/ tines forou=ntes a)pe/skwpton tou\s a)/llous, w(s e)n e(orth=| pai/zontes, e)pi\ a(macw=n fero/menoi. See e)c a(ma/chs, § 122.7, and pompeu/ein, § 124.2.

8. a)ne/dhn, loosely, without check: cf. a)ni/hmi and a)/nesis.—a)\n...toutoisi\: if these (judges) shall wish to hear it. See Thuc. VI. 46, tw=| *niki/a| prosdexome/nw| h)=n, and other examples in M.T. 900. Whiston compares Liv. XXI. 50, quibusdam volentibus novas res fore.

§§12—16. After thus dismissing the private charges as unworthy of a reply, he comes to the charges against his conduct with regard to the Peace of Philocrates in 346 B.C. In this introduction he dwells on the outrage of bringing such grave charges against a statesman in a way which neither allows the accused a fair opportunity to defend himself, nor gives the state any adequate remedy against him if he is guilty, while it may entail grave consequences on an innocent person.
1. peri\ w(=n e)ni/wn, about which in some cases: e)ni/wn qualifies w(=n (West.). Cf. XXVII. 23, kai\ o(/sa e)/nia.

3. h( proai/resis au(/th: au(/th: (so *s) is much more expressive than au)th/ (with no stop), pointing vividly to the following statement of the true purpose of Aeschines. It also gives tw=n me/ntoi kathgoriw=n k.t.l. (6) its proper relation to e)xqrou= me/n. The Schol. charges this passage with a)sa/feia pollh/. The thought is as follows:— The charges include some of the gravest known to the law, which provides the severest penalties for the offences; but this suit was never brought to punish anybody for these. I will tell you what its object is (au(/th): it is to give a personal enemy an opportunity to vent his spite and malice, while it gives the state no means of properly punishing my crimes if I am guilty. The first clause, ta\ me\n... timwri/as (1—3), states the gravity of the actual charges, and is opposed to the following tou= de\...au(/th. The latter introduces the double construction, (a) e)xqrou= me\n...toiau=ta and (b) tw=n me/ntoi...ou)d' e)ggu/s, in which the motive of Aeschines and the inadequacy of this suit to deal with the alleged crimes are declared. The last two clauses are confirmed, (a) by ou) ga\r... di/kaio/n e)stin (§ 13.1-4), (b) by a)ll' e)f) oi(=s...grafo/menon (§ 13.5-11). Finally, ou) ga\r dh/pou...e)gra/yato (§ 13.11-13) shows that Aeschines, by his present action, virtually admits that the course just pointed out (e)f' oi(=s...grafo/menon) is the only consistent one.
4. e)ph/reian, malice (cf. § 13.2): see e)phrea/zw, maliciously insult, §§ 138.4, 320.6.—e)/xei, involves, contains.

7. ei)/per h)=san a)lhqei=s, si verae erant (not essent), a simple supposition, with nothing implied as to its truth: there is no need of reading ou)k e)nh=n in the apodosis.—ou)k e)/ni, it is not possible, i.e. by this suit.
8. ou)d' e)ggu/s (sc. a)ci/an), nor any- thing like it.

Here the orator gives the most striking proof of his adversary's malicious purpose (e)ph/reian), viz. his bringing a form of suit by which he hoped to deprive Demosth. of the power to defend himself (lo/gou tuxei=n). It must be remembered that Aesch. had not merely prosecuted Ctesiphon instead of Demosth., but had also (III. 200—202) besought the judges most earnestly not to allow Demosth. to speak as Ctesiphon's advocate.

1. ou) ga a)fairei=sqai k.t.l.: in *s dei= is crowded into the line by a later hand after a)fairei=sqai. If we omit dei=, a)fairei=sqai and tou=to poiei=n with their adjuncts are subjects of ou)/te...e)/xon ou)/te politiko
 ou)/te di/kaio/n e)stin, the negation of ou) and ou)d) being thrice repeated in ou)/te. As we naturally omit ou) in translation (that
we may translate ou)/te), we can give the emphatic ou)d) (2) the force of still more (dazu, Bl.), and translate, for to try to take away my right to come before the people and be heard—still more to do this by way of malice and spite—is neither right nor patriotic (see note on 4) nor just. a)fairei=sqai is conative (cf. § 207.5). For a)fairei=sqai as subject (where we might expect to\ a)fairei=sqai, were it not for the following to\ proselqei=n), see Thuc. III. 38, a)mu/nasqai de\, tw=| paqei=n o(/ti e)gguta/tw kei/menon, a)nti/palon o)
 ma/lista th
 timwri/an a)nalamba/nei.—to\ proselqei=n...tuxei=n here is the right of every accused citizen to be heard before the popular court, which is here called dh=mos, as it is often addressed a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi.
2. e)n e)phrei/as ta/cei, by way of (venting) malice: cf. § 63.3, e)n th=|... ta/cei, and XX. 81, e)n e)xqrou= me/rei. So III. 31.
3. ou)/te...ou)/te...ou)/te after ou): see Eur. frag. 322 (N.), ou)k e)/stin ou)/te tei=xos ou)/te xrh/mata ou)/t' a)/llo dusfu/lakton ou)de\n w(s gunh/.

4. o)rqw=s e)/xon: stronger than o)rqo/n.—politiko\n, properly belonging to the state (see § 246.7), here due to the state from a citizen: cf. X. 74, ou)k i)/sws ou)de\ politikw=s. Such conduct, it is meant, is not fair to the state. In IX. 48, politikw=s refers to the simple old-fashioned Spartan style of warfare.
5. e)f) oi(=s...e(w/ra: a condensed form for e)pi\ toi=s a)dikh/masin a(\ a)dikou=nta/ me e(w/ra.

6. ou)=si thlikou/tois (=ei) h)=n thli- kau=ta), supposing them to have been so great. e)tragw/|dei kai\ diech/|ei (see note on § 4.6), set forth in his tragic style (i.e. pompously), referring to the theatrical days of Aeschines, like u(pokri/netai, § 15.5. Cf. XIX. 189, tau=ta tragw|dei=.
8. xrh=sqai (sc. di/kaion h)=n, sup- plied from di/kaio/n e)stin in l. 4), he ought to have employed.

9. ei)sagge/llonta and grafo/- menon (11) express the manner of xrh=sqai, and with it make the apodoses to the conditions ei)...e(w/ra and ei)...para/noma (sc. e(w/ra). ei)sagge/llw is to indict by ei)saggeli/a (a state prosecution), as gra/fomai is (properly) to indict by ordinary grafh/. Notice the distinction between gra/fonta para/noma, proposing illegal measures, and parano/mwn grafo/menon, indicting for illegal proposals. For the double meaning of the passive of gra/fw see note on § 56.4.

11. ou) ga\r...e)gra/yato: ou) ga\r dh/pou belongs to both clauses, *kths. me\n and e)me\ d' k.t.l.: for it surely
cannot be that he is prosecuting Ctesiphon on my account, and yet would not have indicted me myself if etc. See note on § 179.3.
12. di) e)me\, e)me\ d): emphatic re- petition.

1—3. ei)/ ti...e(w/ra: if he ever saw me etc., a simple supposition, to which ei)si\ no/moi and e)ch=n are a natural apodosis; e)ch=n, he might, implies no unreal condition. Cf. e)f) oi(=s e(w/ra, § 13.5.—w(=n...die/balle kai\ diech/|ei, i.e. which he slanderously related: cf. § 13.6.

3—5. no/moi...ta)piti/mia: there is no tautology here. He first mentions laws and their prescribed penalties (timwri/ai), which would be used in a)gw=nes a)ti/mhtoi, in which the law fixed the penalties; then processes and (special) suits, in which heavy penalties could be inflicted by vote of the court (a)gw=nes timhtoi/). e)piti/mia, like timh/mata, are especially penalties which the judges assess (timw=si).

6. o(phni/k' e)fai/neto is so nearly equivalent to ei)/ pote e)fai/neto (M.T. 528), that if he had ever been seen best translates it. It is often impossible to express an unreal condition in English by a relative sentence: here whenever he had been seen would not be clear.
7. kexrhme/nos toi=s pro/s me, to have dealt with me (managed his relations to me).

8. w(mologei=t' a)\n, would have been consistent, the impf. referring to the various occasions of kexrhme/nos. If he had brought the proper suits (a)gw=nes kai\ kri/seis) against me personally at the time of each offence, his style of accusation (kathgori/a) before the court would have been consistent with his conduct; whereas now kathgorei= me\n e)mou=, kri/nei de\ toutoni/ (§ 15.5), this being his present e)/rgon.
3. tosou/tois u(/steron xro/- nois: the Peace of Philocrates was sixteen years old at the time of the trial.
5. u(pokri/netai, he plays his part: cf. e)tragw/|dei in § 13.6. The word implies not only pomposity but dissimulation.—kathgorei=...kri/nei: see note on § 14.8.

6. tou= a)gw=nos o(/lou proi+/statai,
he puts foremost in (at the head of) his whole suit.

7. ou)damou=, nowhere, i.e. never: cf. ou(= in § 125.1 with following e)ntau=qa.—e)pi\ tau/thn, upon this ground (that of our enmity), keeping the figure of a)phnthkw\s e)moi/, having met me—or with a view to this, i.e. to fight it out (West., Weil, Bl.): cf. e)ntau=q' a)ph/nthkas; § 125.5.
8. e)pitimi/an a)fele/sqai, i.e. to inflict a)timi/a, which Ctesiphon would incur as a public debtor if he were unable to pay his fine if convicted.
3. dokei=, personal, sc. tis (from 2): we translate it seems that one might say, because we must use a finite verb to express a)\n le/gein (M.T. 754).
5. di/kaion h)=n, we ought (M.T. 416): here of present time.—to\n e)cetasmo\n poiei=sqai, to settle up.
7. e(te/rw| o(/tw|...zhtei=n, to seek what other man we can harm, e(te/rw| standing emphatically before the indirect interrogative o(/tw|: the direct question would be e(te/rw| ti/ni... dw/somen;
For the argument of §§ 17—52 on the Peace of Philocrates, with its three divisions, see note before § 9.
1. o(moi/ws with pa/nta, all alike.
2. e)p' a)lhqei/as ou)demia=s, with no regard to truth.
3. ei)rhme/na: or. obl. with i)/doi a)/n.—kaq) e(\n, singly.—e(/kaston: obj. of e)ceta/sai (West.): cf. kaq' e(/na e(/kaston h(nw=n a)posterei=n, XXI. 142.
4. u(pe\r (like peri\): see note on § 9.8.

6. a)natiqei\s e)moi/, putting upon me. Originally Aeschines prided himself on his close connection with Philocrates in making the peace: see I. 174, th\n ei)rh/nhn th\n di) e)mou= kai\ *filokra/tous gegenhme/nhn. (See § 21.6, and note; and Hist. § 23.)
7. kai\ prosh=kon i)/sws, and be- coming as well (as necessary).
9. a)namnh=sai: sc. u(ma=s, which is added in most MSS. Cf. XX. 76, tau=q) u(pomnh=sai peira/somai.—pro\s... kairo\n, with reference to its special occasion (that which belonged to it).
1. *fwkikou= pole/mou: the Sacred or Phocian War began in 356 —355 and ended in 346 B.C. Demosthenes made his first speech in the Assembly (on the Symmories) in 354 B.C. (Hist. §§ 4, 8.)
2. e)politeuo/mhn: cf. § 60.1.

3. ou(/tw die/keisqe: when we com- pare this judicious account of the feelings of the Athenians towards the Phocians and Thebans in 346 B.C. and earlier with the impassioned language of the speech on the Embassy and of the Second and Third Philippics, we see the sobering effect of time and of recent events. When the Thebans were exulting in the devastation of Phocis by Philip, and the political interests of Athens demanded that the Phocians should be protected as allies, Demosthenes seemed to overlook their sacrilegious plundering of Delphi, which he now acknowledges. Again, the intimate alliance of Thebes and Athens in 339 B.C., and still more the destruction of Thebes by Alexander in 335, had changed the Athenians' bitter hatred to the deepest sympathy. Still the orator cannot deny the old hostility against Thebes, nor the chief ground for it.

5. (w(/ste) o(tiou=n a)
 e)fhsqh=nai paqou=sin: see M.T. 592 and 211. It is often hard to express in English the distinction between the infin. and the finite moods with w(/ste, especially when the infin. has a)/n and must therefore be translated by a finite verb. The thought is, you were (so) disposed (as) to wish...and to feel that you would be pleased etc. (M.T. 584). e)fhsqh=nai a)
 has its protasis implied in paqou=sin. The position of *fwke/as me
 (3) and *qhbai/ois d) shows their strong antithesis.
6. oi(=s eu)tuxh/kesan, their successes: sc. toi=s eu)tuxh/masin (obj. of e)ke/xrhnto). Cf. peri\ w(=n h)gnwmonh/kesan, § 94.2.

7. e)n *leu/ktrois: for the battle of Leuctra in 371 B.C. see Grote X. ch. 78. See XX. 109, showing the feeling of Demosth. himself in 355: mei=zon *qhbai=oi fronou=sin e)p' w)mo/thti kai\ ponhri/a| h)\ u(mei=s e)pi\ filanqrwpi/a| kai\ tw=| ta\ di/kaia bou/lesqai. See note on § 98.4.—e)/peiq), after prw=ton me\n: see note on § 1.4.

8. dieisth/kei, was in dissension (distracted).—oi( misou=ntes: these were especially the Messenians and Arcadians, with their new cities Messene and Megalopolis, established by Epaminondas, and the Argives.
10. oi( pro/teron a)/rxontes are oli- garchies which were maintained by Sparta in Peloponnesus before Leuctra, and were overthrown by the later revolutions.
11. a)/kritos e)/ris kai\ taraxh/, hopeless strife and confusion. a)/kritos is not admitting of settlement (kri/sis).
2. prodo/tais: for the names of some of these see § 48; a longer black list is given in § 295.

3. sune/kroue, brought into colli- sion (knocked together): cf. sune/krouon, 163.5, and cugkrou/ein, Thuc. I. 44.—e)n oi(=s h(ma/rtanon a)/lloi, in others' blunders, cf. oi(=s eu)tuxh/kesan, § 18.6, e)n oi(=s e)pisteu/qhte in § 100.6, e)n oi(=s ei)shggello/mhn in § 250.1, e)n oi(=s semnu/nomai in § 258.4, e)n oi(=s e)/ptaisen in § 286.6, e)n oi(=s eu)tu/xhsen in § 323.9, e)n au)toi=s oi(=s xari/zontai in IX. 63.
5. kata\ pa/ntwn e)fu/eto, he was growing above all their heads, i.e. so as to threaten them all.
6. tw=| mh/kei: cf. deke/ths gegonw/s, Aesch. III. 148.—barei=s, overbearing, offensive.
7. nu=n d a)tuxei=s: after 335 B.C. See Schol., and notes on §§ 18.3 and 35.10.—a)nagkasqhso/menoi: in or. obl. with the personal faneroi\ h)=san.
8. katafeu/gein e)f' u(ma=s: no such possibility is suggested by the language of Demosthenes at the time of the peace; but times had changed.
2. o)li/gou dei=n, full form of o)li/gou (M.T. 779), qualifies e(ko/ntas e)capat., almost willing dupes: cf. mikrou=, § 151.3.

3. h( *(ellh/nwn: the actual subject
appears in the alternative ei)/te...ei)/te. See § 270.7, and XXIII. 156: h( u(mete/ra, w)= a)/ndr. *)aq., ei)/te xrh\ filanqrwpi/an le/gein ei)/q' o(/ ti dh/pote.
4. kaki/an, baseness, here in the sense of worthlessness.
5. po/lemon makro\n: the so-called Amphipolitan War with Philip (357 —346 B.C.), which ended with the Sacred War. See Hist. § 3.
7. sw/masin, lives: cf. § 66.9.
10. sugxwrhqei=sa, conceded, ac- quiesced in: Athens showed no alacrity in making the peace, though she was deceived as to the main point.
11. die/ballen, slanderously de- clared: see Aesch. III. 57 (end), 60.

13. tw=n nuni\...eu(rh/sei (sc. tis): the firm foothold in Greece which Philip secured by the peace, especially his influence in the Amphictyonic Council, it is implied, made him at last the victor of Chaeronea.
1. u(pe\r th=s a)lhqei/as, from regard for (in the interest of) truth.
2. a)kribologou=mai kai\ diece/rxo- mai: see note on § 4.6.
3. ta\ ma/list), even most clearly, with dokoi/h: cf. § 95.6.

4. ou)de/n...pro\s e)me/, it is no con- cern of mine: cf. §§ 44.8, 60.3. This may be an emphatic present apodosis, referring to the present condition implied in ei)...dokoi/h, if it should appear that there is (ei)=nai) any fault; or it may be an emphatic future expression, as in Pind. Isth. IV. (V.) 14, pa/nt' e)/xeis, ei)/ se tou/twn moi=r) e)fi/koito kalw=n, you have the whole, should a share of these glories fall to you.
5. *)aristo/dhmos: a tragic actor of good repute, one of the company in which Aeschines once served (XIX. 246). For his informal mission to Philip in 348—347 B.C. see Hist. § 13.
6. o( e)kdeca/menos, his successor (he who took the business from him).— gra/yas: i.e. moved the peace, which was named from this motion of Philocrates.
9. ou)d' a)\n su\ diarragh=|s, not even if you split: cf. the common imprecation diarragei/hs (Ar. Av. 2). See note on § 17.6.

10. o(/tou dh/pote e(/neka, for what- ever reason (it may have been): dh/pote, like ou)=n, makes o(/stis indefinite. This is as strong language as Demosthenes wishes to use of Eubulus, after his death. See Hist. § 14.
11. ou)damou=: cf. § 15.7, and e)/stin o(/pou, § 22.7. Demosth. is fully justified in this strong denial.
1, 2. o)/ntwn, deiknume/nwn: adversative (M.T. 842).

4. gegenh=sqai, kekwlukw\s ei)/hn: for the perfects see M.T. 103, 109. The whole sentence (3—6) w(s a)/r' ... poih/sasqai refers to the elaborate charge of Aeschines (58—64), that Demosthenes pressed the negotiations for peace with indecent haste and thereby excluded other Greek states from the benefits of the treaty. The answer in § 23 is perfectly satisfactory. (See Hist. §§ 15, 24.)

5. sunedri/ou: a special meeting of delegates to be summoned by Athens from various Greek states, which never met; not the regular synod of the allies of Athens, which was in session when the peace was made (Aesch. III. 69, 70).
6. w)=, ti/ a)\n...prosei/poi; a)posiw/- phsis followed by a question: for the regular position of a)\n before ei)pw/n, see M.T. 224. Cf. w)= ti/ s' ei)/pw; Ar. Nub. 1378.

7. e)/stin o(/pou: temporal, like ou)damou= in § 21.11.—parw\n belongs to o(rw=n...h)gana/kthsas, h)\...diech=lqes; (as a whole): the meaning is, were you ever present when you saw me, etc.?— pra=cin kai\ summaxi/an: the general before the particular. In § 191.9 the order is reversed.

2, 3. e)pepra/kein: even the best MSS. of Demosth. give this form
of the plupf., while those of Plato generally have the older Attic form in -h (for -ea), as e(wra/kh in Rep. 336 D. (G. 683.)—soi\ loipo\n h)=n, it remained for you, after ei) e)pepra/kein, supposing that I had sold (a simple supposition).—boa=n might refer to the loud voice of Aesch., like pefwnaskhkw/s, § 308.10; but Demosth. uses it also of himself (§ 143.6), and it is probably no more than our cry out.

5. ou)/te h)=n...a)pestalme/nh to/te: Holmes calls this an “audacious assertion.” It must be remembered that h)=n a)pestalme/nh is not an ordinary plupf. like a)pe/stalto (M.T. 45), which would have meant that no embassy had ever been sent: the compound form means that there was no embassy then out on its mission. The embassies were probably informal in most cases, and no definite report was expected from them in case of failure. (See Hist. § 24.) The next sentence tells the whole truth, pa/lai ...e)celhlegme/noi, i.e. all had long before this been thoroughly canvassed (and found wanting). Cf. 20.7,8 ou)/te ...u(mi=n. Even Aeschines (II. 79) took the same view fourteen years earlier: ou)deno\s d' a)nqrw/pwn e)pikourou=ntos th=| po/lei, a)lla\ tw=n me\n periorw/ntwn o(/ ti sumbh/setai, tw=n de\ sunepistrateuo/ntwn.
2. e)n oi(=s yeu/detai: cf. § 19.3. The argument of 2—6 is that the negotiations for peace show that Athens could not have been expecting such envoys at this time.

5. *eu)ruba/tou pra=gma: Eurybatus was a proverbial scoundrel, said to have been an Ephesian who was hired by Croesus to raise an army and gave the money to Cyrus.—po/lews e)/rgon, an act fit for a state.
7. ou)k e)/sti...e)/sti: see the same repetition before the oath in § 208.1. —ti/ kai\ metepe/mpesq' a)/n; with what possible object (kai\) would you have been sending?
9. u(ph=rxen a(/pasin, i.e. peace was open to them all: see note on § 1.3.
11. th=s e)c a)rxh=s ei)rh/nhs, i.e. the earlier stages of the peace.
1. e)peidh\: see note on § 42.5.
2. e)ntau=qa, here (temporal): cf. ou)damou=, § 15.7.—ti/ proei/leto pra/ttein; what was his proai/resis (purpose or policy?)
6. bouleu/wn: Demosth. was one of the Senate of 500 in 347—346 B.C. —a)poplei=n, with e)/graya, proposed. The bill was passed on the third of Munychion (April 29): see Aesch. II. 92, Hist. § 29.
7. e)n oi(=s a)\n punqa/nwntai (M.T. 694.1): cf. §§ 26.8, 27.3.
8. tou\s o(/rkous a)polamba/nein, to administer the oaths (i.e. to receive them): o(/rkous a)podido/nai is to take the oaths (i.e. to give them). See § 26.9.
9. ou)de\ gra/yantos, not even after I had proposed the bill (its passage is implied).
1. ti/...h)du/nato; what did this (§ 25.5-8) signify? Cf. VIII. 57, XXI. 31.

2. to\n metacu\ xro/non tw=n o(/rkwn, the intervening time (after making the peace) before he (Philip) should take the oath. o(/rkwn refers to Philip's oath, not to the oaths of the two parties. See Shilleto's note on XIX. 164: he quotes Ar. Av. 187 e)n me/sw| a)h/r e)sti gh=s, between earth (and heaven); Ach. 433, kei=tai d' a)/nwqen tw=n *questei/wn r(akw=n, metacu\ tw=n *)inou=s, i.e. between these rags and those of Ino.
6. e)celu/sate, you broke off (stopped): the active, though somewhat less expressive than the middle, conveys the whole idea, and has the best MSS. authority.
7. tou=t), his own plan, to prolong the time when Athens must be quiet while he could act, referring to 4, 5.— e)k panto\s tou= xro/nou, i.e. from Philip's first suggestions of peace.
8. o(/sa prola/boi, all that he might secure from the city: we might have o(/s' a)\n prola/bh| in the same sense (cf. § 25.7).
10. ou)de/na...lu/sein continues the or. obl. from e(/cein. Even an optative may be thus continued, as in I. 22.
2. yh/fisma gra/fw plei=n: cf. e)/graya a)poplei=n (§ 25.6).—tou=to, i.e. the decree just mentioned.

6. die/sure, ridiculed (tore in pieces), refers to Aesch. III. 82, where he charges Demosth. with making trouble, after the peace was concluded, by mentioning all the insignificant places captured by Philip: ou(=to/s e)stin o( prw=tos e)ceurw\n *se/rrion tei=xos kai\ *dori/skon kai\ *)ergi/skhn kai\ *murti/skhn kai\ *ga/nos kai\ *gania/da, xwri/a w)=n ou)de\ ta\ o)no/mata h)/|demen pro/teron.
7. ou(/tw, under these circumstances (hardly translatable), sums up the preceding e)xo/ntwn...*)ergi/skhn.—gi/gnoinq) with i(/na depends on gra/fw, historic present.
8. e)pikai/rous, seasonable, here ad- vantageous for attacking the Athenian possessions, especially the Chersonese.

9. katastai/h and e)pixeiroi/h (11) continue the final clause with i(/na (4). —pollw=n xrhma/twn: from the rich Thracian gold mines. Diod. XVI. 8 says that Philip had a revenue of a thousand talents (£200,000) from his mines at Philippi.
11. toi=s loipoi=s (cf. § 95.11), what remained to be done.
1. le/gei—a)nagignw/skei, re- cites—has it read (by the clerk). le/ge, properly recite, repeat, is the term most commonly used for read in addressing the clerk.

2. prosa/gein tou\s pre/sbeis (sc. ei)s th\n e)kklhsi/an): these were the ambassadors sent by Philip to negotiate the peace. Foreign embassies first presented themselves to the Senate, which by a decree provided for their introduction to the Assembly: see Aesch. II. 58, tai=s de\ cenikai=s presbei/ais h( boulh\ ta\s ei)s to\n dh=mon proso/dous probouleu/ei. Such a bill was proposed by Demosth. in the Senate before the arrival of the ambassadors, appointing a special meeting of the Assembly to receive them on the eighth of Elaphebolion: afterwards the discussion of the peace was postponed to the eighteenth and nineteenth.

5. qe/an...keleu=sai (sc. e)xrh=n): ought I not to have ordered the architect (of the theatre) to assign them seats (as I did)? qe/an, place to see; cf. e)qew/roun (7): this would be the proedri/a (Aesch. III. 76). The stone Dionysiac theatre was at this time building under the direction of Lycurgus; and the lessee was called a)rxite/ktwn, as an important part of his duties was the superintendence of the work of building. See Dörpfeld and Reisch, Griech. Theater, 36—40, where the building of the theatre is assigned to about 350—325 B.C. Aeschines (61, 76) makes this official politeness of Demosthenes one ground of his grotesque charge of flattering Philip! To this Demosth. alludes in § 294.2, o(\s ga\r e)moi\ *filippismo\n, k.t.l. Aesch., however, mentions only the introduction of the envoys to the theatre.

6. e)n toi=n duoi=n oboloi=n, in the two-obol seats, the threepenny seats of the ordinary citizens. The diwbeli/a, which was then given from the theoric fund as festival money to every citizen who asked for it, paid the entrance fee to the theatre. It is implied that the distinguished strangers could have been admitted, like other people, to the common seats by merely paying their two obols. With e)n toi=n duoi=n o)boloi=n cf. e)n toi=s i)xqu/sin, Ar. Vesp. 789 (see Ran. 1068), in the fishmarket, e)n tw=| mu/rw|, Eq. 1375.
7. ei) mh\ tou=t' e)gra/fh, i.e. had I not proposed my bill.

8. ta\ mikra\ sumfe/ronta: it is jo- cosely assumed that Aesch. objected to the higher price which the state probably paid for the front seats, or perhaps to the state paying for the seats at all.—fula/ttein, peprake/nai: the change of tense may perhaps be seen in a paraphrase; was it my duty to watch the petty interests of the state, after I had sold her highest interests like these men? With o(/la, whole, entire, cf. tw=n o(/lwn ti, § 278.9.

This decree is a good speci- men of ignorant forgery. The Archon's name and the date are both wrong; it is called a decree of the Senate and the People, when it was passed by the Senate alone; it provides for the appointment of five envoys when there were ten, and these had been appointed long before; it provides for the oaths to be taken by Athens and her allies, when these had already been taken; and most of the five names of the envoys are wrong.
1. to\ th=| po/lei sumfe/ron: cf. 28.8, where ta\ sumfe/ronta (with the gen.) is a pure substantive.

4. trei=s o(/lous mh=nas: “sat still in Macedonia three whole months,” is of course a rhetorical exaggeration, which is corrected by Demosth. himself. In XIX. 57 he says a)pedhmh/samen trei=s mh=nas o(/lous (cf. 158), somewhat less incorrectly; but in 58—60 he gives the exact dates, by which we see that the embassy was absent from Athens only about ten weeks. (See Hist. § 33.)

5. pa/nta katastreya/menos: see § 27.—e)co\n...a)fi=xqai...sw=sai: e)co/n represents e)ch=n, and a)fi=xqai is a proper perfect (M.T. 109); lit. it was in our power to have (already) arrived and to save the towns, i.e. we might have done both of these.
6. o(moi/ws, quite as well (as in ten days): the common reading ma=llon would mean rather.

9. paro/ntwn=ei) parh=men, if we had been there. For the various past tenses with a)/n, all of which are in 8—10, see M.T. 413: thus th=s ei)r. a)\n dihmarth/kei is he would have failed to secure the peace (which he had already secured by our absence), and ou)k a)\n a)mfo/ter' ei)=xe is he would not have had both (as he did have).
1. kle/mma me\n: cf. mh\ kle/pte no/w|, Il. I. 132. The position of me\n shows that the seven words before kle/mma belong to both kle/mma and dwrodo/khma.
4. polemei=n kai\ diafe/resqai: these represent (in or. obl.) the past, the present, and the emphatic future indicated by to/te, nu=n, and a)ei/ (M.T. 32, 119).

2. dia\ tou/tous ou)xi\ pei- sqe/ntas (without tou\s) is, because of their disobedience, like meta\ *surakou/sas oi)kisqei/sas, Thuc. VI. 3, and post urbem conditam. This is rare in Greek, where we should expect dia\ to\ mh\ peisqh=nai (M.T. 829.b). See § 42.6, with tw=n...misqwsa/ntwn.

4. w)nei=tai...o(/pws mh\ a)/pimen, he bribes them (to effect) that we shall not depart (M.T. 339): a)/pimen (as fut., M.T. 29) is more regular after w)nei=tai than a)pi/wmen, and has commended itself to nearly all recent editors, though it rests only on a grammarian's authority. (Bekker's Anecd. p. 129.4.)

5. e(/ws...poih/saito, after the his- toric present w)nei=tai. The clause with e(/ws has a final force (M.T. 614), the idea being that he bribed them to wait long enough for him to get his army ready.
6. i(/na mh\...poih=sai (11): the pur pose of w)nei=tai.

7, 8. e)ce/lqoiq) refers to the land force.—peripleu/santes w(/sper pro/teron refers to the famous expedition in 352 B.C., when Athens stopped Philip at Thermopylae. See IV. 17; XIX. 84, 319; Grote XI. 403—405; and Hist. § 6.
9. klei/saite to\n to/pon, i.e. make Thermopylae impassable.
10. a)paggello/ntwn: present to a)kou/oite, as a)paggeila/ntwn in 6 is past to e)ce/lqoite.
1. ou(/tw: antecedent of w(/ste (5).
2. a)gwni/a|, conflict (of mind): Vömel refers Hesych. e)n a)gwni/a|, e)n meri/mnh|, to this passage.

3. ei) pro\ tou=: the older editions with nearly all MSS. omit ei) and read kai\ e)kfu/goi in 4, making yhfi/saisqe depend on mh/.—pro\ tou=... a)pole/sqai, i.e. before he could have time to lay Phocis waste: cf. XIX. 123.
5. w(/ste misqou=tai: a clear case of w(/ste requiring the indicative (M.T. 582, 583).
6. ou)ke/ti koinh=|: Aeschines alone was indicted for parapresbei/a. See § 41.3.
8. di) w(=n here and di) ou(\s in § 35.2 approach each other very closely, both referring to the same thing.
1, 2. a)ciw=, I ask of you (as something a)/cion); de/omai, I entreat. See § 6.2.
4. e)/cw th=s grafh=s: he has already (§ 9) justified his discussion of the peace; and he repeats his apology now, chiefly to call special attention to what follows.
4, 5. e)poiou/mhn a)\n refers to his present argument (cf. § 9.3).—e(/teron, foreign to the subject, like a)llo/trion: cf. e(/teros lo/gos ou(=tos, § 44.8.
1. oi(...r(hqe/ntes: see the fuller account of this speech in XIX. 20—22. Aeschines said that the Thebans had set a price on his head for his anti-Theban advice to Philip. See Hist. § 34.
3. tw=| parelhluqe/nai: he begged the people not to be disturbed by news that Philip had already passed Thermopylae.
5, 6. oi(=s me\n, the Phocians; oi(=s de\, the Thebans.
7. r(h/mata: e.g. the Thebans' title of allies of Philip (cf. § 213.2).
8. ma/la semnw=s o)noma/zwn, using very solemn expressions. He often jokes about the semno/ths of Aesch. See §§ 130, 133, 258, and XIX. 23.
9. sumfe/rein: sumfe/rein: a strik- ing a)nastrofh/.

10. a)nalghsi/as, want of feeling, explained by the Schol. as a)naisqhsi/as. There can be little doubt that this word, like a)nai/sqhtoi in § 43.2, refers to the dulness and lack of keen perception for which the Thebans were proverbial. See Nep. Epam. 5, 2, namque illi genti plus virium quam ingenii, and Alcib. 11, 3, omnes enim Boeotii magis firmitati corporis quam ingenii acumini inserviunt; Cic. de Fato IV. 7, Athenis tenue caelum, ex quo acutiores putantur Attici; crassum Thebis, itaque pingues Thebani et valentes; Hor. Epist. II. 1, 244, Boeotum in crasso aere natum. This dulness, and the consequent illiteracy of Thebes compared with Athens, gave rise to the proverb *boiwti/an u(=n, Pind. Ol. VI. 90: see the Schol., to\ a)rxai=on o)/neidos, toute/sti th
 palaia
 diabolh
 th
 e)pi\ th=| a)mousi/a|. Aristotle, Eth. III. 7, 7, says of a man lacking in fo/bos, ei)/h d' a)/n tis maino/menos h)\ a)na/lghtos, ei) mhde
 foboi=to, mh/te seismo
 mh/te ku/mata, and in III. 11, 7, of those insensible to pleasure, e)llei/pontes de\ ta\ peri\ ta\s h(dona\s kai\ h(=tton h)\ dei= xai/rontes ou) pa/nu gi/nontai: ou) ga a)nqrwpikh/ e)stin h( toiau/th a)naisqhsi/a. Aristotle here means stupidity and slowness, not moral obliquity, by both a)na/lghtos and a)naisqhsi/a.—baru/thtos: cf. § 19.6.
2. th\n to/q' u(pou=san (cf. u(/pesti, § 315.2): a mild way of speaking of the enmity against Thebes in 346 B.C. See § 18.3 with note.

4. ou)k ei)s makra/n (sc. o(do/n), not much later, not a long way off: ei)s of looking forward to an end, as in § 151.8, ei)s *pulai/an.—tou\s me\n...e)k tw=n a)grw=n (7): eleven days after the report of the second embassy to the Assembly, the alarming news of the surrender of the Phocians at Thermopylae arrived. See Hist. § 36.
7. skeuagwgei=n, i.e. were bringing your goods into the towns, as ordered by the decree of Callisthenes (§ 37).— xrusi/on labei=n: in malicious contrast to skeuagwgei=n.

8. th\n me\n a)pe/xqeian...*fili/ppw|: i.e. Athens by her vacillating course got nothing but the ill will of Philip's Greek friends, who believed that she would have protected the Phocians if she had dared to; while Philip had all the credit for ending the Sacred War and punishing the sacrilegious Phocians.
11. tau=t' e)phgge/lleq); i.e. how does the decree just read to you agree with the report of Aeschines (§ 35)?

This letter must be spurious. The genuine letter would have more definite allusions to the dissatisfaction of Athens, to justify what is said of it in § 40. Grote remarks that Demosthenes would have spoken much more severely of a letter so insolent as this one.
2. pro\s summa/xous, with dhloi= kai\ diori/zetai. The letter, though addressed to the Athenians, was really written for Philip's allies.
3. o(/ti before the direct quotation (M.T. 711).
8. w)/|xet' e)kei/nous labw\n, he carried them (his allies) away (M.T. 895); the figure is continued in ei)s to/ with the infinitives.
11. e)c w(=n, as a result of which.

12. oi( talai/pwroi: *qhbai=oi is added in all MSS. except *s. Of course the destruction of Thebes by Alexander is chiefly meant, and this suggests the digression in § 41; but the condition of Thessaly after the peace, which had been in Philip's power since 352 B.C., may well be included. See IX. 26: *qettali/a pw=s e)/xei; ou)xi\ ta\s politei/as kai\ ta\s po/leis au)t w=n parh/|rhtai kai\ tetrarxi/as kate/sthsen, i(/na mh\ mo/non kata\ po/leis a)lla\ kai\ kat) e)/qnh douleu/wsin;
1. o( de\...sunergo\s, i.e. he who helped him thus to persuade his allies: with pi/stews cf. pisteu/sete, § 40.6.
3. a)paggei/las ta\ yeudh=: see § 35. In XIX. 4, Demosth. puts w(=n a)ph/ggeile, his report, first among the things for which an ambassador should render an account.
4. o)duro/menos: see the solemn and eloquent invocation of Aesch. in III. 133, *qh=bai de\, *qh=bai, po/lis a)stugei/twn, k.t.l., with 156, 157.

9. kth=m' e)/xwn: Aesch. is charged with holding a confiscated Theban estate (kth=ma is in *s alone) by the gift of Alexander; as in XIX. 145 Philocrates and Aeschines are charged with having kth/mata kai\ gewrgi/ai pamplhqei=s in Phocis by gift of Philip. We have no independent evidence on either of these charges.

10. e)ch|tou/mhn: Demosth. was among the eight or ten Attic orators who were demanded by Alexander
after his destruction of Thebes in 335 B.C.; Aeschines was not. See Grote XII. 59—62.

§§ 42—49. After the digression in § 41, the orator here speaks of the disastrous consequences which have come from the peace and from the corruption by which it was made, and of the miserable fate of most of the traitors in Greece who aided Philip in his schemes.

5. e)peidh\ here has three pluperfects, while commonly it has the less precise aorist, as in §§ 25.1, 32.1 (M.T. 59). So in Latin postquam venit is more common than postquam venerat. Both e)peidh/ and postquam contain the idea of after that, which the plpf. only emphasizes.
6. dia\ tou/twn tw=n......misqwsa/n- twn (i.e. oi(\ e)mi/sqwsan): contrast dia\ tou/tous ou)xi\ peisqe/ntas, § 32.2, and see note.
2. a)nai/sqhtoi: see note on § 35.10.
3. pa/nt' e)kei=nos h)=n: cf. pa/nt' h)=n *)ale/candros, XXXIII. 120; *eu)/boia au)toi=s pa/nta h)=n, Thuc. VIII. 95; Demetrius iis unus omnia est, Liv. XL. 11.
4. ou)de\...bou/loito (M.T. 462): h)/kouon is strongly frequentative, like h(gou=nto (3), and a)/llo ti is anything opposed to fi/lon, eu)erge/thn, swth=ra.
5. u(forw/menoi, viewing with sus- picion (u(po/ like sub in suspicio).
7. ou)...e)poiei=te: most MSS. (but not *s) add mo/noi. This passage represents the state of mind in which Demosthenes delivered his speech on the Peace (v.) in 346 B.C. See Hist. § 40.

9. [a)/smenoi, kai\]: *s and the newly found Oxyrhynchus papyrus (2nd cent. A.D.) omit these words.—au)toi\... polemou/menoi, though they themselves in a certain way had been warred
against for a long time: polemou/menoi (impf.) is past to h)=gon, which covers the whole time of the peace to 340 B.C. See e)polemou=nto, § 44.7.

2. *)illuriou\s kai\ *tri- ballou\s: Diodorus (XVI. 69) mentions a victorious inroad of Philip into Illyria in 344 B.C., and Porphyrius Tyr. (Müller, Hist. Gr. III. p. 691) says of Philip, ou(=tos tou\s peri\ th\n xw/ran a(/pantas e)doulw/sato polemi/ous, mega/lhn kthsa/menos du/namin, kai\ *triballou\s u(pota/cas.
3. *(ellh/nwn: see Grote XI. 612— 614, and Hist. §§ 41, 46—49.—duna/meis, like our forces, but including allies (even without troops): see § 234.1.

4. tw=n e)k tw=n po/lewn: he counts Aesch. as one of those who took advantage of the peace to visit Macedonia, implying that the process of corruption was still going on. In XIX. 13 he says he first discovered the corruption of Aesch. on the return of the first embassy in the spring of 346 B.C.
8. e(/teros lo/gos ou(=tos, this is another matter: cf. a)/llos a)\n ei)/h lo/gos ou(=tos, IX. 16: a)/llos a)\n h)=n lo/gos, [XIII.] 7.
1. diemarturo/mhn, protested (called Gods and men to witness): cf. obtestor. See § 199.6.—par' u(mi=n probably refers to orations VI., VIII. and IX.

2. o(/poi pemfqei/hn, whithersoever I was sent, referring to the embassies mentioned in § 244 (below) and probably to others. In § 244.4 we have o(/poi e)pe/mfqhn, referring to some of the same embassies as o(/poi pemfqei/hn here. But there the leading clause, ou)damou=...a)ph=lqon, is particular, and its verb is aorist, not imperfect (as here); the relative clause is therefore particular and has the indicative regularly (M.T. 536). If he had said I always came off superior in § 244.4, we should have o(/poi pemfqei/hn there: see e)n oi(=s krathqei=en...katestre/feto, § 244.9.—e)no/soun: Demosth. is especially fond of this figure of a diseased state: see II. 21; IX. 12, 39, 50; XIX. 259 (West.).
3. tw=n...pra/ttein (one substan- tive): cf. § 11.2, 3 and note on § 4.6.
4. e)pi\ xrh/masi, for (with a view to) money; not by money, like u(po\ xrhma/twn.

5. i)diwtw=n: here opposed to tw=n...
pra/ttein (3), private citizens; generally, any men who are not of a given class, as not senators, XIX. 18; cf. i)atro\s kai\ i)diw/ths, Thuc. II. 48.
6. deleazome/nwn, caught, as by a bait (de/lear).
7. toioutoni\...peponqo/twn is ex- plained by e(ka/stwn oi)ome/nwn k.t.l.— plh\n ou)k e)f) e(autou\s, upon all but themselves.
9. tw=n e(te/rwn kindu/nwn, others' (not other) dangers.
2. toi=s me\n plh/qesin, the common people (cf. tw=n pollw=n, § 45.5) in various states: cf. tw=n me\n...tw=n de\ in § 45.3, 4.

3, 5. a)polwleke/nai (M.T. 109): i.e. the result has been that they have lost their liberty; the idea of the perfect in the next clause appears more naturally in peprako/sin (5) than in ai)sqe/sqai, to find out that they have sold themselves first (M.T. 904). For the case of peprako/sin see G. 928.1.
8. a)kou/ousin, audiunt, they hear themselves called: cf. Hor. Ep. I. 16, 17, si curas esse quod audis.
3. e)peida\n...ge/nhtai, after he has become master of what he has bought (M.T. 90). For the assimilation of w(=n a)\n pri/htai, which really conditions ku/rios ge/nhtai, see M.T. 563.
5. ou)de\n...prodo/tou, for (other- wise) nothing would be happier than a traitor.
8. kai\, also, with tw=n a)podome/nwn,

4. me/xri tou/tou with e(/ws, twice repeated. See polla\ in § 81.2, 3; cf. ou)x in § 250.10, 11 and 322.1-3. Expressions like this show the relative character of e(/ws and other particles meaning until. (M.T. 611, 612.)— *lasqe/nhs: Lasthenes and Euthycrates are often mentioned as traitors who betrayed Olynthus to Philip: see Plut. Mor. p. 178 B: tw=n de\ peri\ *lasqe/nhn to
 *)olu/nqion e)gkalou/ntwn kai\ a)ganaktou/ntwn o(/ti prodo/tas au)tou\s e)/nioi tw=n peri\ to
 *fi/lippon a)pokalou=si, skaiou\s e)/fh (sc. *fi/lippos) fu/sei kai\ a)groi/kous ei)=nai *makedo/nas kai\ th
 skafh
 skafh
 le/gontas, i.e. they called a spade a spade.

6. *timo/las: Timolaus was a Theban, who was probably active in causing the surrender of Thebes to Philip after Chaeronea. Theopompus calls him the greatest voluptuary who was ever engaged in state affairs. See § 295.15.
7. *si=mos: Simus belonged to the Thessalian house of the Aleuadae at Larissa, who called in Philip against the tyrants of Pherae in 352 B.C. See Hist. § 5. Eudicus is not otherwise known.

9. ti/ kako
 ou)xi\ pasxo/ntwn;= ou)de
 kako
 ou)xi\ (i.e. pa/nta kaka\) pasxo/ntwn.—pa=s) h( oi)koume/nh is properly the whole habitable world, i.e. the Greek world; as in Ev. Luc. ii. I it is the whole Roman world. But here it is merely a loose expression with no special limit. We should say, “all the world is full of these wretches.”
10. *)ari/stratos, a tyrant of Sicyon.
11. *pe/rillos, of Megara: see XIX. 295. Perillus and Aristratus are in the “black-list” of Cor. § 295. For Philip's intrigues in Megara see Grote XI. 613, 621.
4. to\ e)/xein...peripoiei=, secures for you your opportunities for being bribed (the wherewithal to be bribed).
6. e)ste sw=|oi kai\ e)/mmisqoi, i.e. you survive to be venal.

7. dia/...au)tou\s, if you were left to yourselves (M.T. 472). The orator surprises his audience by this original reason why the Athenian traitors have been saved from the fate of traitors in other states, i.e. the honest citizens thwart their schemes and thus save them from the ruin of success. This brilliant attack is followed up sharply in what follows.
§§ 50—52. the peroration to the argument on the Peace of Philocrates.
1. tw=n to/te praxqe/ntwn, i.e. the transactions concerning the peace. This suggestion that he will drop the subject makes this sudden recurrence to the charge of venality all the more effective.

3. ai)/tios, i.e. of my speaking plei/w tw=n i(kanw=n.—w(/sper, as it were (M.T. 867), with e(wlokrasi/an, not with kataskeda/sas.—e(wlokrasi/an, a mixture of stale dregs, lit. a mixture of the refuse (esp. heel-taps) of last night's feast (e(/wla, hesterna). This burst of indignation refers especially to the audacity of Aeschines (III. 60) in charging Demosthenes with the same coöperation with Philocrates in making the peace which he had once claimed for himself as a merit (I. 174). See § 17.6 (above). Demosthenes calls this treatment “deluging me with the stale refuse of his own villainy.”
4. [kai\ tw=n a)dikhma/twn] is in all MSS., but is omitted in many ancient quotations of the passage.
5. newte/rous: the youngest judges present might have been only fourteen years old in 346 B.C.
6. a)polu/sasqai, to clear myself of: see Thuc. VIII. 87, a)polu/esqai pro\s au)tou\s ta\s diabola/s.—parhnw/xlhsqe: addressed to the older judges (cf. e)noxlei=, § 4.3).

1. fili/an, ceni/an, properly friendship and guest-friendship, here seem to be used with little thought of the distinction. Cf. ceni/an *)aleca/ndrou (3) and ou)/te *fil. ce/non ou)/te *)alec. fi/lon (below).
2. ei)=pe le/gwn: cf. ei)=pe fwnw=n, Aeschyl. Ag. 205, “spake, saying.”

3. o)neidi/zwn: Aesch. had said (66),
o( th\n ceni/an e)moi\ profe/rwn th\n *)aleca/ndrou.
4. po/qen...a)ciwqe/nti; with dra- matic energy for po/qen e)/labes h)\ pw=s h)ciw/qhs; cf. § 128.3.
6. qerista\s, reapers, properly ex- tra farm-hands, called in at the harvest.
4. ou(=toi pa/ntes probably included both court and audience.

6. misqwto\s: most MSS. (*s only by correction) read mi/sqwtos, following the absurd story of Ulpian (see Schol.), that Demosth. pronounced this word mi/sqwtos to make the judges correct his accent by shouting out the very word misqwto/s which he wanted to hear. It is much more likely— indeed, it is certain—that he saw by the faces of his hearers that it was safe for him to put this question boldly; and he was probably greeted by an overwhelming shout of misqwto/s, misqwto/s, from both court and audience. The judges, more than fourfifths of whom voted in a few hours to acquit Ctesiphon and to condemn Aeschines to a fine and a)timi/a, were by this time ready to respond to such a sudden appeal, after listening to this most conclusive argument with its brilliant close.

div1.p: Having finished his reply to the charges foreign to the indictment, he now proceeds to the indictment itself. We have (1) an introduction (§§ 53—59), (2) a discussion of his public life (§§ 60—109), (3) a reply to the charge that the orator was u(peu/qunos when it was proposed to crown him (§§ 110—119), (4) a defence of the proposal to crown him in the theatre (§§ 120, 121), and (5) a conclusion (§§ 122—125).

div2.p: §§ 53—59. Introduction, includ- ing the reading of the indictment.

4. tw=n probebouleume/nwn (pass.), strictly accurate for the provisions of the probou/leuma of Ctesiphon, which had passed only the Senate. The corresponding phrase for the items of a yh/fisma would be tw=n e)yhfisme/nwn. Cf. tw=n gegramme/nwn, § 56.4.
5. di/kaios ei)=nai, that I deserve: personal use of di/kaios (M.T. 762).

§§ 54—55. This spurious docu- ment once passed for the “single undoubtedly genuine Athenian indictment.” Chaerondas was archon in 338—337 B.C.; but the indictment was brought in the spring of 336. The grafh\ parano/mwn came before the qesmoqe/tai, not before the Chief Archon.

The expression tragw|doi=s kainoi=s, § 54.8, on the day of the new tragedians, i.e. when new tragedies were performed, is confirmed by toi=s tragw|doi=s, Aesch. III. 45. In § 55.6 tragw|dw=n th=| kainh=| is probably corrupt.
See note on the spurious probou/- leuma of Ctesiphon in § 118.
1. *(\a me\n diw/kei: the passages of the decree quoted in the indictment are all that are accused of illegality.

3. pa/nta dikai/ws a)pologh/somai: this is a sarcastic allusion to the demand of Aesch. (202) that the court compel Demosth., if he is allowed to speak at all, to follow his opponent's order of argument: a)ciw/sate to
 *dhmosqe/nhn to
 au)to
 tro/pon a)pologei=sqai o(/nper ka)gw\ kathgo/rhka. See note on § 2.6. It happens that Aesch. states the charges in the indictment in the order in which Demosth. wishes to reply to them, just the order which Aesch. is anxious to prevent him from following: in his speech he has followed an entirely different order. See Essay I. § 4.

4. tw=n gegramme/nwn (pass.), of the items of the indictment: see note on § 53.4. ge/grammai and e)gra/fhn may be used as passives of both gra/fw, propose (a bill), and gra/fomai, indict: see dikai/ws gegramme/na, XXIII. 101, w(=| ge/graptai, ibid. 18; ta\ grafe/nta, the proposed measures, Cor. § 86.4; ou)de\ grafe/nta, not even indicted, § 222.8. But ge/grammai is generally middle (seldom passive, as here) of gra/fomai, indict: see § 59.5, gegramme/nos tau=ta: cf. ge/grayai, § 119.2.
5. kaq' e(/kaston e)fech=s: by taking up each point in the order of the indictment, he will ensure completeness in his defence. The same sarcasm is kept up.

1. tou= gra/yai...kai\ e)painei=n (sc. *kthsifw=nta) depends on th\n kri/sin (5). pra/ttonta...a)gaqo\n (2—4) is in substance quoted from the decree: cf. § 59.4. Aesch. (III. 49) professes to quote the exact words, o(/ti diatelei= kai\ le/gwn kai\ pra/ttwn ta\ a)/rista tw=| dh/mw|: cf. other references in Aesch. 101, 237.
4. e)painei=n: see § 113.3 and note.

6—8. a)lhqh=, prosh/konta, and yeudh= are predicates to tau=ta (sc. o)/nta).—ei)/te kai\ yeudh=: kai\, on the other hand (perhaps untranslatable), expresses parallelism with a)lhqh=: cf. ei)/te kai\ mh/, § 58.5. See note on kai/ before diekwlu/qh, § 60.4.

1. to\...keleu=sai (3), the bidding me (in his decree) to be crowned...and the crown to be proclaimed in the theatre (stefanou=n and a)neipei=n in the usual active form): this clause is repeated in tou=to (4) as subject of koinwnei=n.—mh\ prosgra/yanta...dw=|: Aesch. makes it a special act of shamelessness in Ctesiphon (see 11, 12) to omit this saving clause. It was frequently added in such decrees: v. C. I. Att. II. no. 114 (343 B.C.), stefanw=sai xrusw=| stefa/nw| e)peida\n ta\s eu)qu/nas dw=|. This proviso, according to Aesch. (12), did not make the decree legal, though it showed a sense of shame in the mover.

3. koinwnei=n ... pepoliteume/nois, ei)/t)...kai\ mh/ (6), lit. I think this too is concerned with my public acts, (namely with the question) whether I deserve the crown etc. or not. The loose relation of ei)/t' a)/cio/s ei)mi k.t.l. to toi=s pepoliteume/nois, which it explains, is permissible after the full form in § 57.1-5; without this it would be obscure.
5. e)n tou/tois: i.e. before the people (in the theatre).
6. tou\s no/mous: the arguments are given in §§ 110—121.—deikte/on ei)=nai =deiknu/nai dei=n.
9. badiou=mai, I will proceed (cf. 4.7).

2. *(ellhnika\s...lo/gous, i.e. a discussion of our foreign policy, i.e. our relations to other Greek states. See note on oi)kei/wn, *(ellhnikw=n, and cenikw=n, § 311.5. Demosthenes selected foreign affairs as his special department: see § 62.6.
3. tou= yhfi/smatos, depending on to\ le/gein...me, i.e. the clause declaring etc.
5. gegramme/nos (middle): see note on § 56.4.

8. proaire/sewn th=s politei/as,
departments of the government (open to choice).

§§ 60—109. In this general de- fence of his public policy, (1) he defends his fixed principle of opposition to Philip's aggressions (§§ 60—72); (2) he speaks of the events which immediately preceded the outbreak of war with Philip in 340 B.C. (§§ 73— 101), avoiding all mention of the later Amphissian war and the other events which led to the battle of Chaeronea; (3) he defends his trierarchic law (§§ 102—109).

1. pro\ tou= politeu/esqai: the public life of Demosth. properly began with his speech on the Symmories in 354 B.C. (Hist. § 8); but his responsibility for the foreign policy of Athens began after the peace of 346 (§ 18.2). Still, his fixed policy of opposing Philip, though unsuccessful at first, goes back at least to the First Philippic in 351; and he is here (§§ 60—72) defending his public life as a whole, seldom mentioning his special acts. He reserves these for a later part of his argument (§§ 79—94, and after § 159).
2. prou)/labe and kate/sxe com- bined have the idea of securing by being beforehand.

4. kai\ diekwlu/qh: see note on kai\ in § 57.7. kai\ expresses parallelism with prou)/labe kai\ kate/sxe, and strengthens the antithesis between what Philip did before Dem. appeared and what he was prevented from doing afterwards. a(\ diekwlu/qh represents an active form a(\ au)to\n diekw/lusa: no infinitive is understood.
5. tosou=ton u(peipw/n, after pre- mising the following. Demosth. has no preference for the forms in -de (e.g. toso/nde) in referring to what is to follow.
6. u(ph=rce: cf. u(pa/rcai moi, § 1.3.
2. fora\n, a crop: see the list of this crop of traitors in § 295. For fora/, rush, see note on § 271.6.
6. kai\ pro/teron...e)/xontas=oi(\ kai\ pro/teron kakw=s ei)=xon, impf. partic. Cf. nosou=ntas e)n au(toi=s, IX. 50, and kakw=s diekei/meqa, IX. 28. See §§ 45—49.
9. die/sthsen...polla\: cf. [X.] 52, gego/nasi kaq' au(tou\s e(/kastoi, *)argei=oi, *qhbai=oi, *lakedaimo/nioi, *kori/nqioi, *)arka/des, h(mei=s. (Bl.)
10. kwlu/ein: in apposition with e(no\s tou= sumfe/rontos. An appositive infinitive generally has the article in the fully developed language.
1. e)/t' a)gnoi/a| (sc. e)n) ... o)/ntwn=e)/t' a)gnoou/ntwn, e)/t) belonging in sense to a)gnoi/a|. Vömel: quum adhuc ignorarent etc.
2. sunistame/nou: cf. VI. 35, e(/ws... suni/statai ta\ pra/gmata.

4. pra/ttein kai\ poiei=n: see § 4.6. When these words do not have their proper distinction of do and make, they sometimes have no apparent distinction: see § 246.5, 11, and IV. 5, ou)de\n a)\n w(=n nuni\ pepoi/hken e)/pracen.
6. e)ntau=q)...th=s politei/as: parti- tive. Cf. § 59.8.

1. po/teron au)th\n e)xrh=n... a)nairei=n; should she...have helped Philip to gain his dominion over the Greeks, and (so) have set at naught the glorious and just deeds of our ancestors? Here, and in mh\ poiei=n and periidei=n (also depending on e)xrh=n), in prosh=ke poiei=n and e)/dei le/gein h)\ gra/fein in § 66.2, 4, in e)xrh=n poiei=n in § 69.6, and fanh=nai e)xrh=n in § 71.10—12, we have simply the ordinary use of the infinitive depending on a past verb expressing duty or propriety, with none of the idiomatic force by which (for example) e)/dei se e)lqei=n often means you ought to have gone (but did not go). These expressions are all repetitions or enlargements of ti/ prosh=kon h)=n in § 62.4, which obviously asks only what was it right for Athens to do? with no implied idea that she did or did not do the right thing. So in § 63.1 the question is simply was it her duty to help Philip etc.?
2. to\ fro/nhma kai\ th\n a)ci/an, her spirit and her dignity.

3. e)n...ta/cei implies a descent to their level and serving in their ranks. The Thessalians helped Philip in the Amphissian war; the Dolopians are probably mentioned only to disparage the Thessalians further.
7. sumbhso/mena ei) mhdei\s kwlu/sei: cf. Aesch. III. 90, d(\ pro/dhlon h)=n e)so/menon ei) mh\ kwlu/sete. In both we might have the future optative.
8. tau=ta periidei=n gigno/mena, to allow these acts to go on; periidei=n geno/mena would be to allow them to happen (M.T. 148 and 903.6).
1. nu=n, now, when the fight for liberty is ended: toi=s pepragme/nois refers to the fight itself.—to\n ma/list' e)pitimw=nta, i.e. the severest critic.
3. gene/sqai, to join (not to belong to): cf. Ar. Nub. 107, tou/twn genou= moi.

3. w(s e)kra/thse: i.e. at Chaeronea. Philip treated Athens with great consideration after the battle, restoring her 2000 prisoners without ransom; but wreaked his vengeance on Thebes (as a former ally) and invaded Peloponnesus. Hist. § 68. (Grote XI. 699—705.)— w)/|xet' a)piw\n, had taken himself off.

6. h)=n a)/n tis...kathgori/a, there might perhaps be some ground for blame and accusation etc.: the older editions have o(/mws h)=n a)/n tis and kata\ tw=n ou)k e)nantiwqe/ntwn, with an entirely different meaning.

1. e)kei=s' e)pane/rxomai, Ire- turn to my question, i.e. after the digression in § 65.
2. prosh=ke poiei=n: see note on § 63.1.
5. o(\s sunh/|dein: the antecedent, to\n su/mboulon, refers to the speaker, and most MSS. (not *s and L.1) insert e)me/ after *)aqh/nhsin.
6. e)k...xro/nou: see § 203.3.—a)f' h(=s, when (on which), strictly beginning with which, counting from which (as a date).
8. a)gwnizome/nhn: or. obl. after sunh/|dein, like a)nhlwkui=an (9); cf. four participles after e(w/rwn, § 67.1.
9. xrh/mata kai\ sw/mata, money and lives. With the lordly boast of this passage compare the allusion to Salamis in § 238.—filotimi/as, her honour; properly love of honour, but often used like timh/.
1. e(w/rwn continues the construction of o(\s sunh/|dein (§ 66.5).

2. u(pe\r...dunastei/as, contrasted with u(pe\r...sumfero/ntwn in § 66.9. dunastei/a is properly a government of force, not based on the popular will; see § 270.5. Cf. Arist. Pol. VI. (IV.) 5, 2. But Demosth. uses dunastei/as in § 322.7 of the power of Athens. It is generally, however, an odious term.

3. to

6. proi+e/menon, i.e. always ready to sacrifice, followed by o(/ ti boulhqei/h.

2. tolmh/sai (so *s and L): the form in -eie is far more common in Demosthenes and in other Attic prose.—e)n *pe/llh| trafe/nti: cf. Hegesippus [Dem. VII.] 7, pro\s to
 e)k *pe/llhs o(rmw/menon, with the same sarcasm. Pella was a small place until Philip enlarged and adorned it. See Strab. VII. fr. 23: th

4. megaloyuxi/an, lofty aspirations. Aristotle (Eth. IV. 3, 3) says of the megalo/yuxos, the great-souled, or highminded man, dokei= ei)=nai o( mega/lwn e(auto\n a)ciw=n a)/cios w)/n. Cf. mikroyuxi/as, § 279.6.
5. ei)s to\n nou=n e)mbale/sqai: cf. our phrase take it into his head.
7. e)n pa=si...qewrh/masi, i.e. in all that you hear and see: qew/rhma is very rare for qe/ama.
8. u(pomnh/maq' o(rw=si, beholding memorials; o(rw=si by a slight zeugma including lo/gois: cf. Aeschyl. Prom. 21 ou)/te fwnh\n ou)/te tou morfh\n brotw=n o)/yei.
9. kaki/an: see note on § 20.4.— u(pa/rcai, like e)ggene/sqai (4), depends on prosh=ken.—au)tepagge/ltous e)qelonta\s, as self-offered volunteers: cf. § 99.10.
10. ou)d' a)\n ei(=s: see M.T. 219: ou)d' ei(=s (separated)=ne unus quidem, not a man.
1. a)nagkai=on a(/ma: cf. a)nag- kai=on kai\ di/kaion a(/ma, § 9.5.
2. e)/pratten a)dikw=n: in strong an- tithesis to e)nantiou=sqai dikai/ws.

3. e)c a)rxh=s: this refers strictly only to the time of his own leadership (kaq' ou(\s e)politeuo/mhn xro/nous). But he modestly and speciously appears to represent his own vigorous policy as a continuation of earlier energy. Yet
when Philip was capturing Amphipolis, Pydna, and Potidaea, Athens was supinely inactive; but Demosthenes was not yet a responsible adviser. In §§ 18 and 60 he expressly disclaims all responsibility for these earlier times.
6. ti/ e)xrh=n me poiei=n; see § 63.1. —h)/dh s' e)rwtw=: the third time of asking.
7. a)fei\s, leaving out of account: for Amphipolis, Pydna, and Potidaea, see Hist. § 3; for Halonnesus, Hist. §§ 44, 45, 53.

1. For Serrhium and Doris- cus see note on § 27.6. For the sacking of Peparethus (in 341—340 B.C.) see Hist. § 53. tau/thn e)po/rqhsen *)/alkimos nau/arxos tou= *fili/ppou, Schol. The people of Peparethus, an ally of Athens, had taken Halonnesus from Philip and captured his garrison.
3. ou)d' ei) ge/gonen oi)=da: cf. XXI. 78, tou=ton ou)d' ei) ge/gonen ei)dw/s, not being aware even of his existence.
4. su/ g' e)/fhsqa: see Aesch. III. 82, a)rxa\s au)toi=s e)nedi/dou pole/mou kai\ taraxh=s.—tau=ta le/gonta, i.e. by everlastingly talking about these.

5. *eu)bou/lou kai\ *)aristofw=ntos: in replying to Aeschines (as just quoted) he is glad to be able to refer to decrees of his political opponents while there were none of his own. Eubulus, though he was the leader of the peace party and always friendly to Philip, might have proposed decrees directing negotiations with Philip about the towns captured by Philip or the later affair of Peparethus; and he might have proposed one remonstrating against the seizure of Athenian ships (§ 73), like the spurious one in §§ 73, 74.
7. ou)de\...e)rw=: the third para/leiyis (cf. §§ 69.7, 70.3), in which a fact is impressively stated by declaring that it shall not be mentioned.

71. 1. e)kei=nos: this position is allowed the demonstrative when another qualifying word follows the article: cf. h( stenh\ au(/th o(do/s, Xen. An. IV. 2, 6. But even then, the regular order may be kept.—sfeterizo/menos (from sfe/teros), appropriating, making his own, of unlawful or unjust appropriation: cf. XXXII. 2, sfeteri/sasqai, and Aeschyl. Suppl. 39, le/ktrwn sfeterica/menon e)pibh=nai. The verb spheterize has been used in English by Sir William Jones: see larger edition.

2. e)pitei/xism' e)pi\ th\n *)attikh\n, as a fortress commanding Attica. An e)pitei/xisma is properly a fortress in an enemy's country, used as a military basis, like the Spartan fort at Decelea in the Peloponnesian War. Here Euboea in Philip's hands is figuratively described as such a fortress commanding Attica; and the sight of its high mountains across the narrow strait made the figure especially vivid to dwellers in the east of Attica: see § 87.4. This passage relates to Philip's operations in Euboea in 343—342 B.C. See § 79.8 with note, and Hist. § 46.

3. *mega/rois e)pixeirw=n: in 344— 343 B.C. Philip attempted to get possession of Megara, with the help of his friends in the city. See § 48.11 and note. Megara in Philip's hands would have been another e)pitei/xisma e)pi\ th\n *)attikh/n.
6. to\n *(ellh/sponton: for Philip's operations in the Hellespont and at Byzantium, see §§ 87—89 and 244.

...ei)s a(\s de\: very rare for ta\s me
...ei)s ta\s de\: in XLI. 11 we have a(\ me

)...tw=n de\...ta\ de\. See Philem. frag. 99 (Kock), w(=n me
 dia\ tu/xhn, w(=n de\ di) e(autou/s.—tou\s fuga/das kata/gwn: i.e. restoring his own exiled partizans.
10. h)\ ou)/: sc. h)di/kei k.t.l.; but (in 12) h)\ mh/: sc. fanh=nai.
11. to\n tau=ta kwlu/sonta=o(\s t. kwlu/sei (final); in § 72.6 is the simple kwluth\n; both predicates with fanh=nai.
12. e)xrh=n h)\ mh/: the question is here put for the fourth time; see note on § 63.1.

1. ei) me
 ga mh\ e)xrh=n: the alternative is ei) d' e)/dei (6).—th
 *musw=n lei/an, Mysian booty, i.e. like the Mysians, a prey to everybody. paroimi/a, h(/n fhsi *dh/mwn th
 a)rxh
