 *musi/an kata\ th
 *thle/fou tou= basile/ws a)podhmi/an, Harpocr. This refers to the wanderings of Telephus, disguised as a beggar, in quest of Achilles, who had wounded him and alone could cure his wound. This was the plot of the much-ridiculed Telephus of Euripides.
2. o)fqh=nai: sc. e)xrh=n (without mh/).

3. zw/ntwn kai\ o)/ntwn: see note on § 4.6. See Plat. Rep. 369 D, tou= ei)=nai/
te kai\ zh=n.—periei/rgasmai, I have done a useless (superfluous) work: perittw=s kai\ ou)k a)nagkai/ws parh/|nesa/ te e)gw\ kai\ h( po/lis h( peisqei=sa ma/thn e)pei/sqh (Schol.).
5. e)/stw...e)ma/: a)di/khmata kai\ a(mar- th/mata e)ma/ is predicate to e)/stw. See a)di/khma, crime, and a(ma/rthma, blunder, distinguished in § 274.

10. mh\ proi+/esqai, not to make sur- renders (not to give up your own), here absolute, as in Arist. Eth. III. 5, 14: to/te me\n ou)=n e)ch=n au)tw=| mh\ nosei=n, proeme/nw| d' ou)ke/ti, i.e. after he has sacrificed his health.

1. kai\ mh\n...labw\n: this seizure of merchant ships, of which we have no other knowledge, was the overt act which Athens made the occasion of her declaration of war. It perhaps hastened this declaration by a few weeks; but after the letter of Philip (§ 76), which was practically a declaration of war on his part, only one course was open to Athens.

3. th\n e)pistolh\n: this was a detailed statement of Philip's grievances, with a defence of his own conduct toward Athens, ending with a formal declaration of war. The document numbered XII. among the orations of Demosthenes purports to be this letter. See Hist. § 55.

5. ti/s ti/nos: such double inter- rogatives are common in Greek, but colloquial or comic in English, as who's who? An increase of the number becomes comic in Greek; as in IV. 36, ti/s xorhgo\s...po/te kai\ para\ tou= kai\ ti/ labo/nta ti/ dei= poiei=n.

4. e)gw\ d' ou)de\n peri\ tou/- twn: this with § 76.2 is a positive denial of the statement of Aeschines (III. 55) that the decree declaring war was proposed by Demosthenes: Hist. § 55, notes 4, 5. Though Demosthenes was constantly proposing decrees at this time, he cannot have proposed the one which formally declared war or any on the matters mentioned in § 70 or about the seizure of ships (i.e. peri\ tou/twn).
7. e)pistolh\n: see note on § 73.3. The following letter is spurious.
3. o(/ti...tw=n au(tou=: this implies that Philip could not speak of any recent case in which Demosthenes had opposed him, without alluding to some disgraceful act of his own.

4. ei)/......g) e)/grafen: this abso- lutely certain but long neglected correction of Droysen (1839), hardly an emendation, is now generally adopted for the impossible ge/grafen (*s) or ge/grafe of the MSS.
5. ei)xo/mhn, clung to, followed up closely.
6. ei)s *pelopo/nnhson: probably the embassy of 344, on which Demosthenes made the speech quoted in the Second Philippic, 20—25.
8. paredu/eto, was working his way, stealing in.—th\n ei)s *eu)/boian (sc. presbei/an): in 343—342 B.C. (§ 71).
9. th\n e)p) *)wreo\n...*ere/trian: the two military expeditions to Euboea in 341 B.C., by which the tyrannies in Oreus and Eretria were suppressed. See Hist. § 52.

1. a)posto/lous: the orators use a)po/stolos, properly a messenger (N. Test. apostle), and sto/los for a naval armament: cf. ou)/te nausi\ krath/sas h)=lqen a)/n pote sto/lw|, ou)/te pezh=| k.t.l., VI. 36.
2. a)pe/steila: properly used with a)posto/lous, I sent out (by my decrees): cf. presbei/an e)/graya, § 79.7.—*xerro/nhsos...su/mmaxoi: see §§ 87—89, 240, 241.
4. e)/painoi...xa/rites: the decrees conferring these grateful rewards on Athens were read after § 89.

7. toi=s d' o)ligwrh/sasi: this refers to the Peloponnesians who neglected the advice of Demosthenes in 344 B.C. (§ 79.6) and later (IX. 27, 34), and to the early refusal of Oreus and Eretria to listen to Athens (IX. 57, 66, 68).
4. w(/ste tau=q' u(pa/rxein, i.e. that he might have these (the two towns under the two tyrants) to depend on, i.e. as e)piteixi/smata e)pi\ th\n *)attikh/n (§ 71).
5. mhde\n e)cele/gxesqai (sc. subj. au(to/n): cf. the active constr. in Plat. Ap. 23 A, a(\ a)\n a)/llon e)cele/gcw.
6. pantaxou=, anywhere: cf. pa/n- twn, § 5.4.—pa/ntwn h(/kista su/: a sudden outburst of personality.
2. a)fiknou/menoi...kate/- luon: the tenses imply that such envoys of the tyrants were regular guests of Aeschines.

3. kate/luon: lodged (as we say put up), lit. let down, originally unharnessed; cf. Od. IV. 28, katalu/somen w)ke/as i(/ppous.—prou)ce/neis au)tw=n, you were their pro/cenos: this might be metaphorical; but there is good reason for thinking that Aeschines was the official representative at Athens of Oreus, if not of Eretria.
5. a)ph/lasen, rejected (i.e. their proposals).

6. ou) toi/nun...ou)de
: i.e. nothing of the kind was ever successful with me, referring to polla\ me
 a)
 xrh/mat' e)/dwke k.t.l. in § 81.1.
7. w(s siwpw=...a)nalw/sas: quoted from memory from the speech of Aesch. (218), su\ d' oi)=mai labw\n me\n sesi/ghkas, a)nalw/sas de\ ke/kragas.

8. boa=|s e)/xwn, you keep on shouting: cf. Ar. Nub. 509, ti/ kupta/zeis e)/xwn; (M.T. 837). The Scholia understand xrh/mata with e)/xwn (as with labw/n); there may be a double meaning in e)/xwn.—pau/sei...pau/swsin, you will not stop unless these judges stop you.

9. a)timw/santes, i.e. by not giving you a fifth of their votes, the result of which would be the partial a)timi/a of losing the right to bring a similar suit hereafter, with a fine of 1000 drachmas. This was actually the result of this trial.

2. gra/yantos...ge/grafen: i.e. the two decrees were essentially identical in form. In § 223.1 he says of a later decree, ta\s au)ta\s sullaba\s kai\ tau)ta\ r(h/mata e)/xei. Even this does not include such details as dates, names, etc.
4. e)n tw=| qea/trw|: this anticipates the argument on the place of proclamation (§§ 120, 121), and gives a precedent for Ctesiphon's proposal.

5. deute/rou...tou/tou gignome/nou: tou/tou is here ambiguous, but it probably refers to the crown proposed by Aristonicus, the clause deute/rou... gignome/nou meaning that one crown had been given to Demosthenes in the theatre before that of Aristonicus. gignome/nou is imperfect and we might have had deu/teron kh/rugma h)/dh moi tou=to e)gi/gneto, the imperf. implying that he was then receiving the distinction for the second time.
6. parw\n, though present.—e)gra/- yato: sc. parano/mwn.
2. sumba=san=o(/ti sune/bh: cf. fai/nomai tetuxhkw\s (6).
3. e)/fh sumbh/sesqai: see Aesch. 231, o(/tan to\n toiou=ton a)/nqrwpon stefanw=te, ou)k oi)/esqe e)n tai=s tw=n *(ellh/nwn do/cais suri/ttesqai;

6. w(s e(te/rws, otherwise, in the other way (opposed to kalw=s), used to avoid kakw=s. This is the adverb of to\ e(/teron, as w(sau/tws (w(s au)/tws) of to\ au)to/, and w(s a)lhqw=s of to\ a)lhqe/s. See XXII. 12, a)gaqa\ h)\ qa/tera, i(/na mhde\n ei)/pw flau=ron, which shows the euphemistic character of w(s e(te/rws here.

2. pa/nt)...pra/ttein, that I did everything that was best. It is difficult to choose even the most probable reading here. Both pa/ntas (*s) and pa/ntas tou\s xro/nous (Vulg.) are objectionable, and we seem compelled to decide between the conjectures pa/nt) and pa/ntws. pra/ttein is imperfect (for e)/pratton). On the contrary, nika=n, katapraxqh=nai, and gene/sqai are distinguished only like ordinary present and aorist infinitives (M.T. 87, 96).
4. ta\ grafe/nta=a)\ e)/graya: see note on § 56.4.
5. kai\ e)moi\ kai\ pa=sin repeats the idea of th=| po/lei.
6. proso/dous, processions: cf. § 216.10.

2. toi=s me\n o(/plois, I mean, by arms, added, as if by afterthought, to limit u(f' u(mw=n, as politei/a| and yhfi/smasi limit u(p' e)mou=. The interruption is colloquial and designedly spontaneous. See note on § 121.7, tw=n d' a)fairw=n me/rh.
3. ka)\n diarragw=si: see § 21.9.
4. e)piteixismo\n, i.e. Byzantium, as a point from which to threaten Athens: see note on § 71.2.

5. si/tw| e)peisa/ktw|: the same words are found in XX. 31, where it is said that the grain from the Euxine was about half of the whole amount imported by Athens. See Sandys's notes on XX. 31—33. The thin soil of Attica (to\ lepto/gewn, Thuc. 1. 2) could not supply grain enough for the population, even in the best seasons, and the fruitful shores of the Euxine were the most important sources of supply. Hence it would have been fatal to Athens to have the Hellespont and the Bosporus in hostile hands (cf. §§ 241, 301). Boeckh estimates the grain annually consumed in Attica at about 3,400,000 me/dimnoi (5,100,000 bushels), of which only 2,400,000 me/dimnoi could be raised at home. See the story of Xerxes in Hdt. VII. 147.

7. parelqw\n e)pi\ *qra/|khs: this probably refers to the advance of Philip to the siege of Perinthus in 340, when he protected his fleet in its passage through the Hellespont by marching an army through the Chersonese. The appeal to Byzantium, as an ally, to help him in his coming war with Athens was perhaps sent from Perinthus, which he besieged unsuccessfully before he attacked Byzantium. See Hist. §§ 54, 55.—*buzanti/ous: with both h)ci/ou and e)polio/rkei (12).—summa/xous: after Byzantium left the Athenian alliance in the Social war, she became an ally of Philip (XV. 3, IX. 35). But now she had been brought into friendship and alliance with Athens by the skilful diplomacy of Demosthenes before Philip's appeal to her for help (Hist. §§ 51, 53).
9. ou)k h)/qelon ou)d' e)/fasan, re- fused and denied.
11. xa/raka, here a palisade, gen- erally a pale or pole: see Harpocr. xa/raka: *dhmosqe/nhs to\ xara/kwma o(\ perieba/llonto/ tines stratope/dw| e)pi\ swthri/a|.
12. mhxanh/mat' e)pisth/sas: cf. IX. 17, 50. The siege of Byzantium marks an epoch in engines of war.
2. ou)k e)perwth/sw, i.e. I will not repeat the question, already asked in §§ 63, 66, 69, 71.

8, 9. le/gwn...didou/s: these parti- ciples are imperfect, and so contrasted with the preceding bohqh/sas etc. Few venture to accept dou/s for didou/s, though it is supported by *s and L. Vömel says: “Nec puto Demosthenis aures tolerasse continuatas syllabas—dw=s dou/s. Sed in talibus nihil affirmarim.”
2. e)k tou= lo/gou, in the familiar antithesis to e)/rgw|.
3. o( e)nsta\s, which broke out (o(\s e)ne/sth): cf. e)neisth/kei, was upon us, § 139.7.

4. a)/neu, besides (without reckon- ing): cf. [XIII.] 7, a)/neu tou= sumfe/rein, and XXIII. 112, a)/neu tou/tou.—e)n pa=si...dih=gen u(ma=s, saw you supplied (carried you through) with all the necessaries of life in greater abundance and cheaper.

6. th=s nu=n ei)rh/nhs: th=s e)pi\ *)ale- ca/ndrou (Schol.), the peace of Demades, under which Athens had been living since Chaeronea.—h(\n...throu=sin: the Macedonian party had been strong enough to prevent Athens from openly helping Thebes in her revolt 335 B.C., or the Peloponnesians under Agis in 330. See Grote XII. 44, 59; 380—383.

7. xrhstoi\: cf. the sarcastic xrhste\, § 318.4.—e)pi\...e)lpi/sin, in (with a view to) their hopes of future gain: e)lpi/zousi ga\r e)panelqo/nta to\n *)ale/candron a)po\ tw=n *persw=n mega/la au)toi=s xari/zesqai w(s prodo/tais (Schol.).

8—10. kai\ meta/sxoien...mh\ meta- doi=en: this reading of *s gives an entirely different sense from that of the common text, kai\ mh\ meta/sxoien... mhde\ metadoi=en. The meaning is, May they fail in these their hopes; and may they rather be allowed to share with you patriots in the blessings for which you pray, that they may not involve you in the calamities which would result from their policy. *mh\ metadoi=en cannot be a mere continuation of the wish of meta/sxoien: the asyndeton would be too harsh. It must be a final clause, assimilated to the optative meta/sxoien (M.T. 182), as in e)/lqoi o(/pws ge/noito luth/rios, Aeschyl. Eum. 297, and ge/noito...i(/n' ai( *mukh=nai gnoi=en, Soph. Phil. 324. See M.T. 181. I know no other
such final optative in prose; but I know no other final clause (of any kind) depending on a wishing optative in prose, which is hardly strange.
10. w(=n au)toi\ proh/|rhntai, i.e. their proai/resis: th=s doulei/as dhlono/ti (Schol.).
11. tou\s tw=n *perinqi/wn, i.e. the crowns voted by these towns and sent to Athens as marks of honour.
1. ou)kou=n introduces the conclusion to which the decrees point.
2. ou)de\ (sc. mo/non): cf. ou)de\, § 2.4.
4. h( proai/resis kai\ h( politei/a: cf. §§ 292.4, 8, 317.2. In § 192.5 we have th\n proai/resin th=s politei/as in nearly the same sense. proai/resis is deliberate choice.
7. su/mmaxos w)\n: cf. § 87.7.
1. oi( memya/menoi a)\n=oi(\ e)me/myasqe a)/n.—polla\ kai\ di/kai) e)kei/nois: cf. Ar. Plut. 8, *loci/a| me/myin dikai/an me/mfomai tau/thn.

2. w(=n h)gnwmonh/kesan ei)s u(ma=s: cf. oi(=s eu)tuxh/kesan, § 18.6. This “want of feeling” (cf. 207.7, 248.7) refers to the conduct of Byzantium in the Social war: see note on § 87.7, and Hist. §§ 2, 51.
4. mnhsikakou=ntes: remembering old grudges (maliciously): cf. § 99.5. See mh\ mnhsikakh/sein in the oath of oblivion after the restoration in 403 B.C., Xen. Hell. II. 4, 43.
5. do/can, eu)/noian: the asyndeton is more emphatic than do/can kai\ eu)/noian: see §§ 96.4, 5, 234.5, and XIX. 190 and 220.
7. tw=n politeuome/nwn, your public men.
9. su/mboulon...r(h/tora: Phocion as general was probably one of the exceptions here implied.
§§ 95—101. Historical parallels are cited to show that the considerate treatment of Euboea and Byzantium was in accordance with the traditional policy of Athens.

1. ta\s blasfhmi/as refers to the long tirade of Aeschines (III. 85—93) against the proceedings in Euboea in 341—340. There is nothing in the speech of Aesch., as it now stands, relating to the help sent to Byzantium.
2. dusxere\s, unpleasant, is a euphemism adapted to the changed state of feeling towards Euboea and Byzantium since 343.

5. u(pa/rxein u(ma=s ei)do/tas, that you may be presumed to know: cf. § 228.3. This is not a mere expanded ei)de/nai (as if ei)=nai were used), but we have the fundamental idea of u(pa/rxw (§ 1.3) added. In line 11, tw=n u(parxo/ntwn applies to the glories of our ancestors as material stored up for us to emulate.
6. tw=|...sumfe/rein, like tw=| yeudei=s ei)=nai, expresses means.—ei)...h)=san, si erant (not si essent): cf. § 12.7.—ta\ ma/list' a)lhqei=s, never so true: cf. § 21.3.

8. xrh/sasqai, deal with, manage. —tw=n kaq' u(ma=s, of the events of your time, beginning with the Corinthian war of 395 B.C. This war was now 65 years old; but there were probably old men in the immense audience who distinctly remembered it and who would be pleased to have it spoken of as in their day. Still, he feels that these earlier events hardly fall within his limit of kaq' u(ma=s, for he says tw=n to/te *)aqhnai/wn in § 96.8, directly after e)ch/lqete ei)s *(ali/arton, and oi( u(me/teroi pro/gonoi, followed by u(mei=s oi( presbu/teroi, in § 98.1.
10. pro\s, with reference (or re- gard) to: cf. to\ pro/s ti, Aristotle's category of relation.
11. ta\ loipa\ (cf. § 27.11), opposed to tw=n u(parxo/ntwn.

2. *lakedaimoni/wn...a)rxo/n- twn: after the Peloponnesian war, Lysander established in most of the conquered towns, and even in some which were previously friendly to Sparta, a Spartan governor (a(rmosth/s) with a military force (froura/), and a board of ten citizens of the subject state (dekadarxi/a), who were partizans of Sparta. See Plutarch, Lysand. 13, and Grote IX. 255.—ta\ ku/klw| th=s *)attikh=s: more rhetorical than ta\ peri\ th\n *)attikh/n, ku/klw| having the adverbial sense of around. See IV. 4.5, ei)/xomen pa/nta to\n to/pon oi)kei=on ku/klw|, and XIX. 155, e)poreu/onto ku/klw|, they travelled round.

4, 5. *eu)/boian...*ai)/ginan: Euboea and Megara had been in the hands of the Spartans before the end of the Peloponnesian war. Aegina, which Athens had settled with her own people in 431, after expelling the native population, was restored to its former owners (so far as this was possible) by Lysander in 405, as he was on his way to attack Athens (Thuc. II. 27; Xen. Hell. II. 2, 9). Boeotia as a whole was nominally allied with Sparta; but Thebes and other towns became disgusted with Sparta's tyrannical conduct soon after the end of the war, and though Thebes had been the greatest enemy of Athens when the peace was made, she harboured Thrasybulus and his fellow exiles before they attacked the Thirty in 403. This disaffection ended in the Boeotian war in 395, in which Athens aided Thebes; in the battle of Haliartus the allies gained a doubtful victory over Sparta, which was made decisive by the death of Lysander on the field. (See Grote IX. 409.) The invasion of Boeotia by Lysander and his Spartan army justifies th\n *boiwti/an a(/pasan from the Athenian point of view.

5. *ke/wn, ta\s a)/llas nh/sous, i.e. Ceos and the adjacent islands, Tenos, Andros, Cythnus, Melos, etc. Melos is mentioned as restored to its old inhabitants by Lysander (Plut. Lys. 14). The emendation *ke/wn, ta\s a)/llas nh/sous for *klewna\s, a)/llas nh/sous (*s) removes the difficulty caused by the mention (for no apparent reason) of Cleonae, a town between Corinth and Argos, under ta\ ku/klw| th=s *)attikh=s.—ou) nau=s ou) tei/xh to/te kthsame/nhs: Athens was required by Sparta to demolish her Long Walls and the walls of the Piraeus, not those of the a)/stu; and she was allowed to keep twelve war-ships: see Xen. Hell. II. 2, 20. Here to/te kthsame/nhs (not kekthme/nhs) means that she had not yet acquired any ships or walls beyond what were left her at the end of the war.
6. ei)s *(ali/arton: see note on ll. 4, 5.

7. ou) pollai=s h(me/rais: according to the accepted chronology, the battle of Haliartus was in the autumn of 395 B.C., and that of Corinth in the summer of 394, in the year of Eubulides. The Corinthian war was the result of a combination of Athenians, Corinthians, Boeotians, Euboeans, Argives, and others against Sparta. In the battle of Corinth, the Spartans were victorious. See Grote IX. 426—429. The beautiful monument, representing a young warrior on horseback, now standing near the Dipylon gate of Athens, was erected in honour of Dexileos, one of the Athenian horsemen slain in this battle. The inscription is:
*deci/lews *lusani/ou *qori/kios.
e)ge/neto e)pi\ *teisa/ndrou a)/rxontos, a)pe/qane e)p' *eu)bouli/dou e)g *kori/nqw| tw=n pe/nte i(ppe/wn.
8. po/ll' a)\n e)xo/ntwn (po/ll' a)\n ei)=xon), i.e. they might have done so, potuissent.
10. *dekeleiko\n po/lemon, a name often given to the last years of the Peloponnesian war (413—404 B.C.) when the Spartans held a fort at Decelea in Attica.
11. ou)d' e)ggu/s: cf. § 12.8.

6. pe/ras me\n...thrh=|: this was celebrated as a gnomic saying in various forms. The meaning is not the flat truism, “death is the end of all men's lives,” but all men's lives have a fixed limit in death, and this is made a ground for devoting our lives to noble ends, for which it is worthy to die.
7. e)n oi)ki/skw|, in a chamber: a)nti\ tou= mikrw=| tini oi)kh/mati, Harpocration.
10. proballome/nous e)lpi/da, pro- tecting themselves by hope (holding it before them, as a shield). See Menand. fr. 572 (Kock):
o(/tan ti pra/tth|s o(/sion, a)gaqh\n e)lpi/da pro/balle sautw=|, tou=to gignw/skwn o(/ti to/lmh| dikai/a| kai\ qeo\s sullamba/nei.
1. pro/gonoi: see note on § 95.8.

2. u(mei=s: cf. par' u(mw=n tw=n pres- bute/rwn, XX. 52.—*lakedaimoni/ous, obj. of a)nelei=n (5), diekwlu/sate having tou\s *qhbai/ous, or perhaps simply to\ pra=gma, understood as its object. From the position of *lak. we should expect it to belong to the leading verb.

4. krath/santes e)n *leu/ktrois: the “Leuctric insolence” of Thebes (Diod. XVI. 58), which made her rather than Sparta the natural enemy of Athens from 371 to 339 B.C., was notorious. See §§ 18.6 and 36.2. In 370 Epaminondas with a Theban army invaded Laconia and marched up to the city of Sparta itself; but he did not venture to enter the unwalled town and withdrew into Arcadia. At this time he established Messene and Megalopolis, to hold Sparta in check. In this trying emergency, Sparta humiliated herself so far as to ask help from her old enemy, Athens. Her request was granted, and Iphicrates was sent into Peloponnesus to the aid of Sparta with 12,000 Athenians in the spring of 369 B.C. This saved Sparta from another invasion at this time. The alliance then formed remained unbroken, though sometimes strained, until after the battle of Mantinea in 362 B.C., in which Athens fought on the side of Sparta.
7. u(pe\r oi(=a pep.a)nqrw/pwn, i.e. what the men had done for whom.
3. tou/twn, for this, refer- ring to o(tiou=n, as o(/stis can always have a plural antecedent.
4. u(pe\r, concerning, involving.

5. mnhsikakh/sete...u(pologiei=sqe: mnhsikakei=n, though usually intransitive (cf. § 101.6), may have an accusative, as mnhsikakh=sai th\n h(liki/an, Ar. Nub. 999. Thus both verbs may here have the same object, suggested by o(tiou=n.

6. e)pi\ tou/twn mo/non: cf. XV. 15, tw=| *(rodi/wn dh/mw| mo/non, and IX. 57, para\ tou/tois mo/non. In these cases mo/non modifies the whole sentence loosely as an adverb, where we should expect the adjective mo/nwn or mo/nw| with the noun. We are often careless about the position of only; as “he only went to London once.”

7. sfeterizome/nwn th\n *eu)/boian: cf. 71.1. Euboea had been under the
control of Thebes since Leuctra, but in 357 B.C. a Theban army was sent to quiet some disturbances in the island. The Athenians with great energy sent an army to Euboea, and drove the whole Theban force from the island in thirty days. This is the famous expedition to which the orators always referred with pride. See Dem. VIII. 74, 75, IV. 17; Grote XI. ch. 86, pp. 306—309; and Hist. § 2.

8. ou) periei/dete: cf. diekwlu/sate, § 98.5.—*qemi/swnos: a tyrant of Eretria, who in 366 B.C. took from Athens the frontier town of Oropus and gave it to Thebes. (Grote X. ch. 79, p. 392.) Oropus had long been a bone of contention between Athens and Thebes. It was stipulated that Thebes should now hold the town only until the right to it could be settled by arbitration (me/xri di/khs, Xen. Hell. VII. 4, 1). The “case of Oropus” was a protracted one; and it is said that Demosthenes as a boy was first inspired with a passion for oratory by hearing an eloquent plea of Callistratus in defence of the rights of Athens (Plut. Dem. 5).

10. tou/tois: the Euboeans.—tw=n e)qelontw=n...th=| po/lei, i.e. the state then for the first time obtained the services (genome/nwn) of volunteer trierarchs (e)qelontai/): tw=n, because these became an institution.

12. a)ll' ou)/pw peri\ tou/twn: this may look forward to the orator's account of his public services in § 267, or possibly to the discussion of his trierarchic reform in §§ 102— 109. ou)/pw: sc. le/cw, but in XIX. 200, mh/pw tau=ta: sc. ei)/pwmen.
2. kai\ to\ sw=sai th\n nh=son, even saving the island, i.e. this by itself, opposed to pollw=| d' ... ka/llion, sc. e)poih/sate.

5. mhde\n......u(pologisa/menoi: mh- de\n shows that the participial clause is closely connected with to\ a)podou=nai, not with e)poih/sate (understood). G. 1611. The meaning is without taking into account, rather than not taking into account.
6. e)n oi(=os e)pisteu/qhte (for e)n e)kei/- nois a(/), representing the active pisteu/ein tau=ta u(mi=n, as w(=n h)di/khsqe represents a)dikei=n tau=ta u(ma=s.
7. e)co/dous peza\s, land expeditions (after naumaxi/as); stratei/as, campaigns.

9, 10. th=s...swthri/as, rare geni- tive of purpose or motive, generally found with e(/neka, which is added here in most MSS. So XIX. 76, pa=s' a)pa/th kai\ te/xnh suneskeua/sqh tou= peri\ *fwke/as o)le/qrou, with similar variety of reading. (See G. 1127.) The infinitive with tou= is common in this construction, especially in Thucydides (M.T. 798): an example occurs in § 107.2, tou= mh\ poiei=n.
4. u(pe\r au)th=s...ou)/shs, when the question in a manner concerned herself.
6. nh\ *di/a, in bitter irony: cf. XX. 161.
8. di) a(\s prohso/meqa (excuses) for sacrificing (final).
9. u(parxo/ntwn (cf. § 95.5): the glories (kala/) are viewed as a public possession.

10. e)pexei/rhs' a)/n (M.T. 506): there is no objection here to ei) e)pexei/rhs' a)/n, as to either grammar or sense. It is amply justified by XIX. 172: ei) mh\ dia\ to\ tou/tous bou/lesqai sw=sai, e)cw/lhs a)poloi/mhn kai\ prow/lhs ei) proslabw/n g' a)\n a)rgu/rion pa/nu polu\ meta\ tou/twn e)p re/sbeusa. There ei) e)pre/sbeusa a)/n is if I would have gone on the embassy, as ei) e)pexei/rhsa a)/n here is if I would have undertaken (for any consideration). There may be a justification of e)pexei/rhs' a)/n in the following to/ g' e)/rgon ou)k a)\n e)poih/saq) u(mei=s, you would not have done the thing in reality (e)/rgw|), opposed to the preceding supposition, if I had been capable of undertaking it even in word (lo/gw|).
13. ou)x u(ph=rxon...ou(=toi; were not these men here ready to tell you this? tau=ta refers to mnhsikakei=n... prohso/meqa (6—8).

§§ 102—109. The orator de- fends his Trierarchic Law against the attacks of Aeschines. This important measure was enacted in 340 B.C., at about the time of the outbreak of the war with Philip (see § 107.6). For an account of the trierarchy at Athens, see Boeckh's Staatsh. d. Athener, I. Book 4, ch. 11—16.
4. kataluo/menon, break- ing up: notice the following descriptive present participles.

5. a)telei=s...gignome/nous, becoming exempt (from all ‘liturgies’) by small payments. As all the members of a sunte/leia (under the former system) were assessed equally for the support of their ship, the richer suntelei=s might satisfy the law (as in the case supposed in § 104) by paying 1/16 of the expense of one ship; and as no one could be required to take more than one ‘liturgy’ in the same year, they would thus be exempt from all other services. But the richest of all, the leaders of the symmories (§ 103.4), sometimes ingeniously used their legal duty of advancing the money for the trierarchy in case of special necessity as a means of avoiding even their own legal share of the expense. They could bargain with a contractor to do all the work for a fixed sum (e.g. a talent), which they advanced, afterwards assessing this whole sum, or an unfair part of it, on their poorer colleagues. See Dem. XXI. 155.
7. ta\ o)/nt' a)pollu/ontas, losing what they had: a strong expression of the injustice to which the poorer suntelei=s were liable.—u(steri/zousan ...tw=n kairw=n, as we say, behind time.
9. [tou\s plousi/ous]: these words probably crept into the text as an explanation of tou\s me\n, which needs no such note. The text is very doubtful, though the sense is clear.

1. grafei\s: sc. parano/mwn. —to\n a) gw=na tou=ton...ei)sh=lqon, i.e. I stood (entered on) my trial on this issue before you, ei)s u(ma=s implying coming into court. tou=ton refers to grafei\s, meaning the trial which followed his being indicted. Cf. ei)sh=lqon th\n grafh/n, § 105.2.
2. to\ me/ros (sc. pe/mpton): cf. § 266.6. See note on § 82.9.

4. h(gemo/nas tw=n summoriw=n, lead- ers of the symmories, here probably the symmories of the trierarchy, though the term commonly refers to the 300
richest citizens (oi( triako/sioi, § 171.5), who were leaders of the symmories of the property-tax (ei)sfora/). Under the system which prevailed from 357 to 340 B.C., the 1200 richest citizens, who alone were liable to the duty of the trierarchy, were divided into 20 symmories, regularly of 60 men each. But exemption or changes in property might reduce the whole number of 1200 and the number in each symmory in any year. To each of these symmories was assigned a number of triremes to be fitted out in each year, regulated by the needs of the state. The symmory divided itself into smaller bodies (sunte/leiai), each of which equipped a single ship. The expense was borne equally by all the members, without regard to their wealth. Each symmory probably had a single leader, and the 20 leaders, with the two classes called deu/teroi and tri/toi (who are not mentioned elsewhere), evidently belonged to the triako/sioi, perhaps including all of that class in the symmories (15 in each). The new law of Demosthenes imposed the burden of the trierarchy on the members of each symmory according to their taxable property, thus greatly increasing the assessment of the richer and diminishing that of the poorer members. Of this a striking case is given in § 104.6, 7.
5. dido/nai, offered, representing e)di/dosan, which appears in § 104.10.
6. ma/lista me\n, above all things, opposed to ei) de\ mh\, otherwise, if not (M.T. 478).—mh\ qei=nai, not to enact; see next note.

7. kataba/llont' e)a=n e)n u(pwmosi/a|, to drop it and let it lie under notice of indictment (lit. under the prosecutor's oath to bring an indictment). Whenever anyone brought a grafh\ parano/mwn against a law or decree, he was required to bind himself by an oath, called u(pwmosi/a, to prosecute the case. This had the effect of suspending the law or decree if it was already finally passed, or of stopping a decree which had passed only the Senate (i.e. a probou/leuma) from being voted on by the Assembly, until the grafh\ parano/mwn could be tried. (See Essay II.) The meaning here is that Demosthenes was offered large sums if he would either decline to bring his new law before the nomoqe/tai (mh\ qei=nai) or else quietly let it drop (e)a=n) when a grafh\ parano/mwn was brought against it after it was passed.

1. h)=n...lh|tourgei=n, i.e. they might perform the service (of the trierarchy) in bodies of sixteen: this is probably stated as an extreme case under the old law, in contrast with an equally extreme case of a man with two whole triremes to support under the new law. A sunte/leia of sixteen implies a change from 60 in the size of the symmory: see note on § 103.4.
3. au)toi=s me\n, themselves (ipsis), opposed to tou\s d) a)po/rous.—mikra\ kai\ ou)de\n: see note on § 102.5.
4. e)pitri/bousin, distressing (grind- ing).

5. to\ gigno/menon tiqe/nai, to pay their quota (what fell to each): cf. tiqe/nai ta\s ei)sfora/s, XXII. 42.—kata\ th\n ou)si/an, according to his property: kata\ to\ ti/mhma, according to his valuation, would be more strictly accurate, as the ti/mhma, or taxable property, in different classes bore a differing proportion to the ou)si/a.

6. duoi=n...suntelh/s: it was a possible case that a man who had been assessed (as supposed above) for only one-sixteenth part of the expense of one ship might be compelled to pay for two whole ships under the new law. trih/rarxos suggests trih/roin and trih/rous with duoi=n and mia=s.
8. suntelei=s, partners in a sunte/- leia: sixteen trierarchs of a single ship, of whom perhaps no one even saw the ship, were absurd!
10. e)di/dosan, offered: cf. dido/nai as imperfect in § 103.5.

2. yh/fisma: this cannot be the trierarchic law itself, which was no yh/fis ma; but a decree passed after the u(pwmosi/a, which may have ordered the suspension of the law or have provided for the trial of the case.—kaq' o(\=secundum quod, ex quo, not propter quod (see West.).

3. tou\s katalo/gous: the stupidity of the interpolator of the false documents never shows to greater advantage than in the two fragments of a pretended decree given as kata/logoi in § 106. The real documents were two lists of citizens of various degrees of wealth, with statements of their assessments for the trierarchy under the old law and under the law of Demosthenes. The contrast between the two called forth the question with which § 107 begins. The document in § 105 is not a decree, but a memorandum.

2. mi/kr) a)nalw=sai a)\n... e)qe/lein, does it seem likely that the rich would have been willing to spend (only) a little to escape doing justice? With oi( plou/sioi supply dokou=sin from dokw= in l. 1 (see M.T. 754). a)nalw=sai depends on e)qe/lein a)/n, which represents h)/qelon a)/n. tou= mh\ poiei=n is genitive of purpose (cf. § 100.9).
3. kaqufei=nai, dropping: cf. kata- ba/llonta, § 103.7.

5. sumfe/ronta qei=nai to\n no/mon: cf. pthna\s diw/keis ta\s e)lpi/das, Eur. frag. 273.—tw=| pei=ran dedwke/nai, on the law having given a test of itself (sc. to\n no/mon au(tou=). See § 195.12, a(/ ge mhde\ pei=ran e)/dwke, with note; XXIV. 24, pei=ran au(tw=n polla/kis dedw/kasin (sc. oi( no/moi) (with au(t w=n expressed); Thuc. I. 138.9 (of Themistocles), a)po\ tou= pei=ran didou\s cuneto\s fai/nesqai, i.e. on trial. Compare the perfect dedwke/nai with the timeless aorists which precede (M.T. 109, 96).
6. a)posto/lwn: see § 80.1; and cf. IV. 35, tou\s d' a)posto/lous pa/ntas u(mi=n u(steri/zein tw=n kairw=n.
8. i(kethri/an (sc. r(a/bdon), sup- pliant's bough, generally of olive, bound with wool, which a suppliant laid on the altar of a divinity whose succour he invoked.

9. e)n *mounixi/a|: e)/nqa e)sti
 i(ero
 *mounuxi/as *)arte/midos: ka)kei= e)/feugon oi(/tines tw=n trihra/rxwn h)dikou=nto, h)\ nau=tai h)/ tines tw=n e)cetazome/nwn e)n tw=| *peiraiei= (Schol.). See Lys. XIII. 24, kaqi/zousin e)pi\ to
 bwmo
 *mounixi/asin. Munychia is the high hill of the peninsula of Piraeus.

10. a)postole/wn: see Bekk. Anecd. 435, 29: a)postolei=s: de/ka to\n a)riqmo\n a)/rxontes h)=san, oi( e)pi\ th=s e)kpomph=s tw=n pleousw=n trih/rwn kai\ tw=n a)pagome/nwn sto/lwn a)podedeigme/noi. They were chosen for each occasion, and had charge of supplying the trierarchs with rigging and other material for the triremes from the public stores, and of seeing that these were properly restored at the end of the voyage.

10, 11. e)/cw kataleifqei=s), aban- doned at sea; au)tou= a)pelei/fqh, was left behind in port.—au)tou=, on the spot, i.e. in port, where she was lying: e)n tw=| lime/ni a)nepiskeu/astos (Schol.). See Plat. Rep. 371 C, au)tou= me/nontas peri\ th\n a)gora/n.
2. to\ d' ai)/tion, without o(/ti, like shmei=on de/ and tekmh/rion de/: cf. VIII. 32.
3. lh|tourgei=n: the h| here is settled by inscriptions.—a)du/nata, cases of impossibility.
7. proh|rou/mhn: cf. proai/resis, § 93.4.
8. duna/meis, power (of various kinds): cf. §§ 44.3, 233.2, 237.6.
9. ba/skanon, malicious: see Har- pocr., a)nti\ tou= filai/tion kai\ sukofantiko/n.
10. kako/hqes, low-principled: see h)=qos, § 109.1.
1. h)=qos, principles (of action), political character: see note on § 114.2.
2. e)n toi=s *(ellhnikoi=s, opposed to e)n toi=s kata\ th\n po/lin: see 59.2.
6. a)nti/, rather than, like ma=llon h)/ (4).

§§ 110—121. contain the reply to the first two arguments of Aeschines, that on the responsibility of Demosthenes as an a)/rxwn at the time when Ctesiphon proposed his decree (§§ 111—119), and that on the place of proclamation (§§ 120, 121). § 110 is introductory. §§ 122—125 are a peroration to the division of the argument beginning with § 53.
1. peri\ tou= khru/gmatos, i.e. about the place of proclamation, this being the only point in dispute under this head.

2. tw=n eu)qunw=n: this concerns only the question whether Demosthenes was a “responsible magistrate” when Ctesiphon proposed to crown him.— to\ ga\r...u(ma=s, i.e. the statement in Ctesiphon's decree that I did etc., subj. of dedhlw=sqai (4): with this reference to the words of the decree cf. 57.1.
5. ta\ me/gista refers especially to his important public services in the year before Chaeronea (339—338), the account of which comes in later with far greater effect.

6. paralei/pw, I leave aside (not necessarily I omit). This whole passage is full of rhetorical art. He has no intention whatever of omitting these acts; but he skilfully implies that his earlier acts, already related, are ample for the legal justification of Ctesiphon, so that he could afford to leave his greatest achievements unmentioned. He also diverts attention from the weakness of his argument on the eu)/qunai by placing it between two most effective political harangues. See Essay I. § 5.

7. e)fech=s, in due order: cf. § 56.6, ou)de\n e(kw\n paralei/yw, where he simply states his general purpose of giving a full account of his public life.—au)tou= tou= parano/mou, the strict question of illegality, with which alone the grafh\ parano/mwn is properly concerned.
9. o(moi/ws, all the same.—par) u(mw=n...u(pa/rxein moi, that I may rely on a consciousness of them in each of your minds: cf. § 95.5 and note.

1. tw=n lo/gwn, depend- ing on tou\s pollou/s.—a)/nw kai\ ka/tw diakukw=n, mixing them in utter confusion. See IX. 36, a)/nw kai\ ka/tw pepoi/hke, and without kai/ IV. 41, sumparaqei=te a)/nw ka/tw, up and down.

2. paragegramme/nwn: the laws which the indicted decree (to\ feu=gon yh/fisma) was charged with violating were written on a tablet (sani/dion) by its side, and this was posted in the court-room. See Aesch. III. 200: e)n tai=s grafai=s tw=n parano/mwn para/keitai kanw\n tou= dikai/ou touti\ to\ sani/dion kai\ to\ yh/fisma kai\ oi( paragegramme/noi no/moi.

4. th
 o)rqh
 (sc. o(do/n), as we say, straightforward: see Ar. Av. 1, o)rqh
 keleu/eis;

5. tw=n dikai/wn, the rights of the case, opposed to tw=n lo/gwn (1).— tosou/tw| de/w le/gein, I am so far from saying: tosou/tw| (*s) with de/w as with comparatives: so in IX. 17. Most MSS. have tosou/tou in both passages.
6. die/balle kai\ diwri/zeto: see § 4.6.
8. w(=n...pepoli/teumai, i.e. either for money that I have handled or for public acts that I have done.

The sophistical character of the argument of §§ 112—119 explains the anxiety of the orator to cover its weakness by its position in the oration. The reply of Aeschines (III. 17 ff.) to this a)/fukton lo/gon, o(/n fhsi *dhmosqe/nhs, probably written or greatly modified after hearing this passage, is conclusive. The law quoted by Aesch. (11), tou\s u(peuqu/nous mh\ stefanou=n, certainly made no exception for those who gave money to the state while in office. Indeed, this very claim is one which needed to be established by the eu)/qunai, in which it might be disputed: see Aesch. 23, e)/ason a)mfisbhth=sai/ soi to\n boulo/menon tw=n politw=n w(s ou)k e)pe/dwkas. The claim of Demosthenes at least amounts to this, that any officer who asserts that he has expended more in the service of the state than he received should be exempt from the law tou\s u(peuqu/nous mh\ stefanou=n. The specious argument that a man cannot fairly be called to account for the expenditure of his own money on public
works could not release Demosthenes from eu)/qunai when he had obviously had public money in his hands.
1. w(=n me/ntoi g): ge emphasizes the whole relative clause.
2. e)paggeila/menos de/dwka, have offered and given, i.e. have given by my free act, openly declared.
4. tw=n e)nne/) a)rxo/ntwn: The Ar- chons, as the chief magistrates and as candidates for the Areopagus, would be subject to special scrutiny at their eu)/qunai.
5. misanqrwpi/as, misanthropy, op- posed to fila/nqrwpon (7).
8. ei)s tou\s sukofa/ntas: ironical allusion to ei)s tou\s logista/s, as if the sycophants were a board of officers (hence tou\s).
9. tou/tous...e)fista/nai, to set them to audit the accounts etc.
1. a)ll' ou)k e)/stin (sc. no/mos toiou=tos).

2. e)pi\ tw=| qewrikw=| w)/n, being treas- urer of the Theoric Fund: for the importance of this office see Aesch. III. 25, 26, ending with *kthsifw=n de\ *dhmosqe/nhn to\n sullh/bdhn a(pa/sas ta\s *)aqh/nhsin a)rxa\s a)/rxonta ou)k w)/knhse gra/yai stefanou=n.—e)pe/dwka, properly gave in addition (to the public fund in his charge). Gifts to the state were often called e)pido/seis: cf. note on § 171.7.

3. e)ph/|nesen au)to\n (sc. *kthsifw=n) =e)/grayen e)paine/sai. All MSS. except *s insert h( boulh/ as subject of e)ph/|nesen. The true subject appears in l. 10, tau=t' e)/grayen o(di\ peri\ e)mou=. e)painei=n, compliment by a vote of thanks, and stefanou=n are both used of the vote conferring the crown, which included a vote of thanks: see §§ 57.4, 58.2, 117.5.

4. ou) peri\ tou/twn...e)pe/dwka: this argument assumes that an ordinary u(peu/qunos could be crowned, before passing his eu)/qunai, for a gift to the state which was not connected with his office. But this was not the case with the gifts of Demosthenes. These were both closely connected with the funds which he held as an officer of state, and the argument of Aeschines (23) applies to them in its full force. Demosthenes says nothing which shows that Ctesiphon did not violate the letter and even the spirit
of the law tou\s u(peuqu/nous mh\ stefanou=n. And yet it is more than likely that the friends of Demosthenes, in their eagerness to crown him for his noble services, overlooked the technical obstacle to their action; and the court appears to have decided to overlook their oversight.

6. teixopoio\s, one of a board of commissioners appointed to superintend the repairs of the city walls. The argument seems to have been the same about both of the offices which Demosthenes held in 337— 336 B.C. See Essay III. § 1.
8. tw=n e)cetaso/ntwn (=oi(\ e)ceta/- sousi), men to investigate: the present would be simply investigators, with no temporal or final force.
2. h)/qesin, your moral feelings, which impel you to act thus. Cf. § 204.2. Cf. h)qika/, mores, morals. See note on § 275.3.

3. pollaxo/qen dei/cw: Aeschines anticipates or rather answers this argument in 193: le/gei de\ o( feu/gwn... ou)x w(s e)/nnoma ge/grafen, a)ll' w(s h)/dh pote\ kai\ pro/teron e(/teros toiau=ta gra/yas a)pe/fugen.
4. *nausiklh=s: the general who commanded the well-known expedition which stopped Philip at Thermopylae in 352 B.C.

6. *dio/timos: mentioned in XXI. 208 as a rich trierarch, included by Arrian (1. 10, 4) among the generals whom Alexander demanded after the destruction of Thebes.—*xari/dhmos: of Oreus, an adopted Athenian, the object of severe invective in the oration against Aristocrates (352 B.C.). He was first a guerrilla leader in the service of Athens, later one of the patriotic party, and was demanded by Alexander in 335.

7. ou(tosi\ implies that Neoptole- mus was well known in Athens.— pollw=n e)/rgwn e)pista/ths: probably one of those called dhmosi/wn e)/rgwn e)pista/tai by Aesch. (III. 29), specially appointed to direct special works.
8. sxe/tlion a)\n ei)/h...u(fe/cei: for the peculiar form of conditional sentence see M.T. 503, 407.
11. komi/sasqai implies that the receiver has a claim on the giver: cf. a)podou=nai, § 110.8, and Plat. Rep. 507 A, e)me/ te du/nasqai au)th\n a)podou=nai kai\ u(ma=s komi/sasqai.

2. e)f' oi(=s e)stefanou=to: we do not know whether there was any distinction between these decrees and that of Ctesiphon like that mentioned in § 113.4. As Demosthenes
identifies his own case absolutely with these, the question is of little moment.
5. e)painou=mai: cf. e)ph/|nesen, § 113.3.
7. nh\ *di/), a)ll): a more emphatic form in stating an objection than the common a)lla\, nh\ *di/a: cf. XIX. 272, XX. 58.—parw\n: i.e. being present (as you were).

8. m' ei)sh=gon oi( logistai\: see Aristot. Pol. Ath. 54, kai\ (klhrou=si oi( *)aq.) logista\s de/ka kai\ sunhgo/rous tou/tois de/ka, pro\s ou(\s a(/pantas a)na/gkh tou\s ta\s a)rxa\s a)/rcantas lo/gon a)penegkei=n: ou(=toi ga/r ei)si mo/noi toi=s u(peuqu/nois logizo/menoi, kai\ ta\s eu)qu/nas ei)s to\ dikasth/rion ei)sa/gontes. Before this board of auditors every magistrate had to appear for his eu)/qunai at the end of his term of office; and they (generally as a matter of form) brought him before a Heliastic court of 501 judges, in which anyone might appear and accuse him of any offence connected with his office. His accounts of money expended were audited at the same time. See Aesch. III. 17—23. The question ti/s bou/letai kathgorei=n; (Aesch. 23) was probably asked in presence of the court at the eu)/qunai of Demosthenes; and to this Aeschines did not respond. But these eu)/qunai must have come several months after Ctesiphon's bill had passed the Senate and had been indicted by Aeschines, so that accusation at the eu)/qunai was superseded. See Essay III. § 1.
2. e)stefanw=sqai (sc. e)me/), that the proposal to crown me has passed the Senate: cf. e)ph/|nesen in § 113.3.
3. grafe/n moi, proposed in my honour: see note on § 56.4.

4. tou= probouleu/matos: partitive after oi(=s. The meaning is, that he will use the omissions from the decree in the indictment to show the malice of Aeschines in prosecuting the clauses which he includes.
a(\ diw/kei sukofantw=n: see XXIII. 61, sukofantou=men to\ pra=gma.

The orator now calls for the reading of the bill of Ctesiphon, ostensibly to prove the point just made, but perhaps chiefly to recall to the minds of the judges Ctesiphon's enumeration of his public services which the Senate has approved. In the following spurious decree the Archon's name is wrong and different from that in the indictment (which is also wrong).

Here the proof of the malice of Aeschines, promised in § 118, is given on the authority of the decree just read. It is argued that Aeschines admits the gifts and their legality by his silence concerning them, while he brands as illegal the proposal to return public thanks for these gifts. As if the thanks for a legal gift might not be given in an illegal manner.
5. parano/mwn gra/fei: cf. note on § 13.9.

2. muria/kis muri/ous: this means that 10,000 men had been crowned on 10,000 occasions (not 10,000 times 10,000 men). This was justified rhetorically by the great frequency of decrees conferring crowns to be proclaimed in the theatre: the number of these on record shows that any law which may have forbidden the proclamation of crowns in the theatre was a dead letter.

3. to\ polla/kis...pro/teron: in the note on § 83.5 (deute/rou...gignome/nou). I have given reasons for thinking that the crown voted on the motion of Aristonicus in 340 B.C., and proclaimed in the theatre, had been preceded by another, also proclaimed in the theatre, of which we have no other account than the allusion in § 83. These two, with the one voted on the motion of Demomeles and Hyperides in 338 B.C. (§§ 222, 223), if the latter was actually proclaimed, justify the use of polla/kis, especially after muria/kis muri/ous.
5. w(/st' ou) du/nasai: see M.T. 601 and 584. The meaning is are you so stupid that you are not able? while with w(/ste mh\ du/nasqai it would be are you stupid enough not to be able?
6. to\n au)to\n e)/xei zh=lon, i.e. the receiver of the crown feels the same pride: zh=los is emulation, pride in excelling, hence glorying (see §§ 217.3, 273.5).
7. ei(/neka: this Ionic and poetic form is often found in the best MSS. of Demosthenes.
9. ei)s to\ poiei=n eu)=: this motive is strongly urged in many decrees conferring crowns.
This short but impassioned outburst cannot be a reply to the long and confused argument of Aeschines (32—48). See Essay 1., Remarks on §§ 120, 121.

3. tou/tous d' a)nagoreue/tw (sc. o( kh=ruc): the quoted passage plh
 e)a
 ...a)nagoreue/tw appears to be an addition to the law quoted by Aeschines in 32, e)a
 me/n tina h( boulh\ stefanoi=, e)n tw=| bouleuthri/w| a)nakhru/ttesqai, e)a
 de\ o( dh=mos, e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a|, a)/lloqi de\ mhdamou=. This would mean that Aeschines read a mutilated law to the court, which in full would have told against him, and that Demosthenes simply supplied the omitted words and so ended the argument. This is more than we can believe either of Aeschines or of the court. Our trouble is, that we do not know what law the clerk read to the court at the end of § 120, and therefore do not know in what connection the words now quoted by Demosthenes stood.

5. e(llebori/zeis: see Ar. Vesp. 1489, pi=q' e(lle/boron, i.e. you are mad; Hor. Sat. II. 3, 166, naviget Anticyram; A. Poet. 300, tribus Anticyris caput insanabile.—ou)d) ai)sxu/nei...ei)sa/gwn: for the difference between ai)sxu/nomai ei)sa/gein and ai)sxu/nomai ei)sa/gwn, which in the negative form is not very important, see M.T. 881, 903.1. This appears clearly in Xen. Cyr. V. 1, 21: tou=to me\n ou)k ai)sxu/nomai le/gwn: to\ de\... ai)sxunoi/mhn a)\n le/gein.—fqo/nou di/khn, a suit based merely on fqo/nos, opposed to a)dikh/matos di/khn, a suit (to get redress) for an offence (cf. § 279.1).

7. tw=n d' a)fairw=n me/rh, and cut- ting out parts of others, as if tou\s me\n metapoiw=n had preceded, which is the reading of all MSS. except *s. The use of tw=n de/ alone gives the clause the appearance of a sudden afterthought; and, so far from showing carelessness, it may be a rhetorical device to give emphasis. The same occurs in XIX. 180: o(/soi dia\ tau=t' a)polw/lasi par) u(mi=n, oi( de\ xrh/mata pa/mpoll) w)flh/kasin, and XXVII. 9: kate/lipe...maxairopoiou\s me\n tria/konta kai\ du/o h)\ trei=s, a)na\ pe/nte mna=s kai\ e(\c, tou\s d) ou)k e)la/ssonos h)\ triw=n mnw=n a)ci/ous.—o(/lous di/kaion h)=n a)nagignw/skesqai, ought to be read entire.
8. toi=s ge o)mwmoko/si...yhfiei=sqai: see Aesch. III. 6, o( nomoqe/ths tou=to prw=ton e)/tacen e)n tw=| tw=n dika/stw=n o(/rkw|, yhfiou=mai kata\ tou\s no/mous.
§§ 122—125. are a peroration to the division §§ 53—125.

2. po/sa: Blass for prosa(\ (*s).—tw=| dhmotikw=|: referring to Aesch. 168—170.—w(/sper...suggrafh\n: we find it convenient to translate, as if you had put out a statue to be made by contract; but the participle with w(/sper (without a)/n or a)\n ei)) is not conditional, as appears by its having ou) (not mh/) for its negative, as in § 323.7 (M.T. 867). w(/sper is simply as, or
as it were, but we can seldom translate it with a participle without an if.
6. gignwskome/nous (with w(/sper): accus. abs. (M.T. 853): cf. w(s... e)/xonta, § 276.5, 7.—r(hta\ kai\ a)/rrhta, dicenda, tacenda (sc. o)no/mata), with o)noma/zwn.

7. w(/sper e)c a(ma/chs: see note on pompei/as, § 11.7; and Suid. under ta\ e)k tw=n a(macw=n skw/mmata: e)pi\ th=s a(ma/chs o)xou/menai ai( gunai=kes ai( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, e)pa\n ei)s ta\ *)eleusi/nia e)ba/dizon ei)s ta\ mega/la musth/ria, e)loido/roun a)llh/las e)n th=| o(dw=|: tou=to ga\r h)=n e)/qos au)tai=s.
1. kai/toi kai\ tou=to: cf. IV. 12.
2. loidori/an kathgori/as: see note on § 10.1.
5. kata\ th\n au(tw=n fu/sin, op- posed to e)n toi=s no/mois (4): the accident of personal nature is expressed also in sumbai/nei (6).
7. tauti\ ta\ dikasth/ria: most of these were in the a)gora/, as is implied by Lysias, XIX. 55.
8. a)po\ tw=n i)di/wn, i.e. out of (our stock of) private enmity. For the use of a)po\, cf. Thuc. I. 141, a)po\ tw=n au(tw=n dapanw=ntes.

9. kakw=s......a)llh/lous, abuse one another with lawless epithets: a)po/rrhta were epithets which it was unlawful to apply to a citizen: cf. Lys. X. 6, e)rei= w(s ou)k e)/sti tw=n a)porrh/twn e)a/n tis ei)/ph| to\n pate/ra a)pektone/nai: to\n ga\r no/mon ou) tau=t' a)pagoreu/ein: a)ll) a)ndrofo/non ou)k e)a=n le/gein. This speech shows that a)ndrofo/nos, r(i/yaspis, patraloi/as, and mhtraloi/as were a)po/rrhta, but the number must have been much larger.

10. e)a\n...tugxa/nh|, if it shall happen that anyone has wronged: the perfect participle is the common form for expressing past time with tugxa/nw etc.; e)a\n a)dikh/sas tu/xh| would mean if he shall perchance wrong (M.T. 144, 147.1).
2. e)mou=: with ou)de\n h(=tton. —pompeu/ein (cf. pompei/as, § 11.7): referring to e)c a(ma/chs, § 122.7, and loidori/an, § 123.2.

3. e)/latton e)/xwn a)pelqei=n, to get off with any less (than he has given): this fatal principle of paying off vituperation in the same base coin is the weak justification of the scurrility which follows (§§ 128—131) and elsewhere.
5. po/teron...fh=|; here fh=| tis; hardly differs from fw=men; the third person without tis in these questions is rare (M.T. 289).
7. ou(=, where, explained by e)n...kri/- sesin.—u(pe\r tou/twn: the Athenians present, as representing the whole.
8. e)ce/leipes expresses habitual neglect.
9. eu)qu/nais: i.e. by bringing a suit in connection with my eu)/qunai (see note on § 117.8), like the grafh\ parapresbei/as against Aeschines (XIX.).
grafai=s: here ordinary public suits, not including ei)saggeli/a, eu)/qunai, etc., which come under grafai/ in its wider sense. See § 249.3.

1. ou(= d)...a)qw=|os, but where I am scot-free, opposed to ou(= me\n h)=n, § 124.7.—toi=s no/mois...pro/teron: these four grounds of immunity (explaining a(/pasin) do not all exclude each other, no/mois in fact including all the rest, and xro/nw| being in great part identical with proqesmi/a|.

2. th=| proqesmi/a|, the limitations of time set by law to bringing certain actions. Debts were outlawed in five years, and this limitation applied to many other cases. The mover of a law was personally liable to the grafh\ parano/mwn only one year. Of course in this suit nothing could make Demosthenes personally amenable to any law, as he was only Ctesiphon's advocate; but the meaning of a)qw=|os is that no suit could now legally be brought against him personally for any of the offences with which he is charged before the court. He bitterly complains of the power given to Aeschines by the form of this suit to accuse him of crimes for which he could not indict him: see §§ 9—16.— tw=| kekri/sqai polla/kis pro/teron (sc. e)me/): probably referring to the cases mentioned in §§ 83, 222—224, which covered important parts of the present case. He may also refer to actual indictments against himself: for the time since Chaeronea we have his statement in §§ 249, 250, e.g. kata\ th\n h(me/ran e(ka/sthn e)krino/mhn. See note on § 224.5. For the law forbidding new trials of cases already decided, see XXIV. 55, ou)k e)a=| peri\
w)=n a)\n a(/pac gnw=| dikasth/rion pa/lin xrhmati/zein.
3. u(ma=s a)dikw=n: u(ma=s shows that the orator could address the audience in the midst of a question addressed to Aeschines personally.
5. e)ntau=q), there, referring back emphatically to ou(= (1).

6. a)ph/nthkas: cf. a)phnthkw/s, § 15.8.—o(/ra mh\...h)=|s, see to it that you do not prove to be their enemy: mh/ with the subjunctive always implies the future; but fobou=mai mh\ a)lhqe/s e)stin is I fear that it is true (M.T. 369).
6. e)moi\: the MSS. are divided between e)moi/ (*s) and e)mo/s.

div1.p: The next main division of the argument is devoted chiefly to the account of the means by which Aeschines gained for Philip an entrance into Greece with his army, by getting up the Amphissian war (§§ 139—159), and of the measures by which Demosthenes opposed this joint plot of Aeschines and Philip (as he represents it), especially his negotiations with Thebes in 339—338 B.C., which led to the alliance of that city with Athens (§§ 160—226). The orator introduces these accounts by a general sketch of Aeschines' life and that of his parents, full of offensive scurrility (§§ 126—131), followed by a brief account of some of the lesser political offences of Aeschines (§§ 132—138).

The orator's account of his own political acts in the eventful year before the battle of Chaeronea, connected with his vigorous defence of the policy of Athens under his guidance in her last resistance to the power of Philip, is the most eloquent passage in the oration (§§ 160—226). This is a direct continuation of the story of his political life which was interrupted by skilful design in § 110.

div2.p: 1. e)peidh\ toi/nun k.t.l. This is one of the few undoubted cases of anacoluthon in Demosthenes. The causal sentence introduced by e)peidh/ goes on regularly through § 126, when the sudden turn given by the question ti/s ou)k a)\n...fqe/gcasqai; causes the orator to burst forth into the fierce invective which follows, forgetting his leading sentence, the apodosis to e)peidh\...fqe/gcasqai. This exclamatory diversion carries him to the end of § 128, where we find in a changed form (in § 129) what would be a natural apodosis to § 126. But it is hardly possible that the orator ever thought of the beginning of § 129 as a resumption of his broken sentence.—h( eu)sebh\s...yh=fos, i.e. the vote which your oath and justice both require of you.

4. au)ta\ ta)nagkaio/tata, what is barely necessary (to satisfy the promise in § 124.3, 4). Cf. a)nagkaio/tata § 168.7. See Thuc. I. 90 w(/ste a)poma/xesqai e)k tou= a)nagkaiota/tou u(/yous, i.e. to have the wall just high enough to be defensible.
5. ti/nwn: sc. geno/menos.

6. lo/gous tina\s diasu/rei, ridi- cules certain sayings of mine. It is hard to decide between tina\s and ti/nas. With ti/nas it is what sayings of mine he ridicules, i.e. how he ridicules my sayings. The reference is to Aesch. III. 167, tau=ta ti/ e)stin, w)= ki/naidos; r(h/mata h)\ qau/mata; also to 72 and 209.
7. a(\ ti/s...fqe/gcasqai; this in- terrog rel. sentence breaks the construction. For metri/wn see n. on § 10.8.
1. *ai)ako\s...*mi/nws: the three judges of the dead in Plat. Gorg. 523 E.
2. o( kathgorw=n is subject: Vömel says, “Non dicit si Aeacus accusaret, sed si accusator esset Aeacus.”

3. spermolo/gos: originally a little bird which picked up seed from newly sown fields (Ar. Av. 232, 579); then a man who lives by picking up what he can in the market and other places of trade, a vagabond, and generally a worthless fellow; sometimes one who picks up and retails small scraps of gossip, a babbler or prater, as applied to St Paul in Acts xvii. 18. Either of the last two meanings, or perhaps a combination of both, suits the present passage.—peri/trimm' a)gora=s, a hack of the market place: see Arist. Nub. 447, peri/trimma dikw=n, with the explanation in Bekk. Anecd. p. 59, oi(=on tetrimme/non i(kanw=s pra/gmasin.— o)/leqros grammateu\s, a curse of a scribe: see IX. 31, o)le/qrou *makedo/nos (of Philip), and XXIII. 202, a)nqrw/pous ou)d' e)leuqe/rous, o)le/qrous.

2. tou= (=ti/nos) prw/tou mnhsqw=: indirect question (M.T. 677).—o( path\r...e)dou/leue: it is a hard problem for historical criticism to evolve the real father of Aeschines from this slave of a schoolmaster, seen with his feet in the stocks or wearing a wooden collar for punishment, and the patriotic citizen described by his son (Aesch. II. 147, III. 191), who had died about twelve years before at the age of ninety-five, who lived through the Peloponnesian war, in which he lost his property, was banished by the Thirty Tyrants, served his country bravely in Asia, was one of the restorers of the democracy under Thrasybulus, and in his old age discoursed learnedly and wisely to his son on the early history of the grafh\ parano/mwn! Fortunately Demosth. speaks of him thirteen years before this, when he was still living, in XIX. 281, where he calls Aeschines the son of Atrometus the schoolmaster. From this respectable station he has now descended to be the son of Tromes, a schoolmaster's slave (see § 130.5).

It meant also stocks for the feet, and the pentesu/riggon cu/lon was an instrument with five holes, for neck, arms, and legs. See Lexicon, cu/lon. —toi=s meqhmerinoi=s ga/mois, a euphemism for daylight prostitution: the stories of the mother of Aeschines are as trustworthy as those of his father (see §§ 258, 259).

XXIV. 208.—pro\s tw=| kalami/th| h(/rw|, near the shrine (or statue) of the hero kalami/ths. Many identify this hero with the h(/rws i)atro/s of XIX. 249, notwithstanding strong objections. 4. ou)x o(/pws...a)lla\: ou)x o(/pws and ou)x o(/ti came originally from ou) le/cw o(/pws (or o(/ti), I will not speak of, I will not say that, etc., while the nearly equivalent mh\ o(/pws (rare) or mh\ o(/ti came from mh\ le/ge o(/pws (or o(/ti), do not mention that, etc. Usually not to speak of is a good English equivalent; but what is not to be spoken of may be either affirmed or denied. Thus here ou)x o(/pws xa/rin e)/xeis, not to mention your being grateful, means not only are you not grateful; but in Dem. XXIV. 7, ou)x o(/ti tw=n o)/ntwn a)\n a)pesterh/mhn means not only should I have lost my property (not to speak of losing my property). §§ 132—138. Here the orator alludes briefly to some lesser offences of Aeschines, which preceded the outbreak of the war with Philip. In § 139 these are called slight matters compared with his conduct after the war began.

1. oi)=den, know of.—a)poyh- fisqe/nt), rejected from the list of citizens. In 346—5 B.C. a general revision of the lists of citizens was ordered at Athens; and the members of each deme went through its own list (the grammatei=on lhciarxiko/n), voting on each name which was questioned. This process was called diayh/fisis (diayhfi/zomai), and the rejection of any person was called a)poyh/fisis (a)poyhfi/zomai). Demosthenes wrote his oration against Eubulides (LVII.) for a client who had been thus rejected and had appealed (as every such person might) to a Heliastic court. Antiphon was probably rejected at the same diayh/fisis (see Dem. LVII. 2, pollw=n e)celhlame/nwn dikai/ws e)k pa/ntwn tw=n dh/mwn), and afterwards offered his services to Philip.

4. katasth/santos ei)s th\n e)k- klhsi/an: it is hardly probable that Demosthenes brought Antiphon before the Assembly without some official authority. At the time of the passage of his trierarchic law (340 B.C.) he held the office of e)pista/ths tou= nautikou= (Aesch. III. 222). Antiphon was probably arrested by mh/nusis, denunciation to the people, the process by which those charged with mutilating the Hermae in 415 B.C. were dealt with. Except in the rare cases in which the Assembly itself undertook the trial (as in the mh/nusis against Phidias, Plut. Pericl. 31), the people either sent the accused to a Heliastic court for trial or discharged him. The appeals of men like Aeschines moved the Assembly to discharge Antiphon: but the Areopagus interposed, and ordered (through the Assembly) that Antiphon be tried before a court, which condemned him to the rack and to death. See Hist. § 43.
6. h)tuxhko/tas: referring to Anti- phon's “bad luck” (as Aesch. called it) in losing his citizenship.

7. a)/neu yhfi/smatos, i.e. without a vote of the Assembly or Senate. An Athenian citizen, like an Englishman, looked upon his house as his castle. But in extraordinary cases officers of the state with proper authority could search private houses and arrest persons concealed therein.
8. a)feqh=nai: Antiphon was at first discharged by the Assembly without a trial.

3. e)n ou) de/onti (neut.), unseasonably, just when it should not: cf. a)nhlw/kamen ei)s ou)de\n de/on, III. 28. —sumbebhkui=an i)dou=sa, seeing that it had occurred (or. obl. M.T. 904).— e)pezh/thse, i.e. ordered a new (e)p-) investigation of the man's case. The Areopagus in these later times seems occasionally to have revived a part of its ancient power of directing the general welfare of the state.
4. sullabou=sa shows that the Areopagus itself ordered Antiphon's arrest: Plutarch (Dem. 14) says that Demosth. arrested him and brought him before the Areopagus.

5. w(s u(ma=s, i.e. before the court, which passed the sentence of death (7). But e)panh/gagen implies that the Areopagus brought him back to some place, and this must be the Assembly, which had sent him to the court. See the Scholia: kuri/ws ei)=pe to\ e)panh/ga gen, ei)s to

6. e)cepe/pempt): this slight change from e)cepe/mpet) gives a form symmetrical with e)ch/rpast): a)/n would generally be omitted here (M.T. 226).—semnolo/gou: see note on § 35.8.

7. nu=n, as it was.—streblw/santes: torture (ba/sanos) could not legally be inflicted on an Athenian citizen; but Antiphon was now disfranchised. In Ar. Ran. 628, Dionysus, disguised as a slave, claims exemption from examination under torture as an immortal God: a)goreu/w tini\ e)me\ mh\ basani/zein a)qa/naton o)/nt).—w(s e)/dei ge kai\ tou=ton (sc. a)poktei=nai) as you ought to have dealt with this man (Aesch.).

3. su/ndikon...*dh/lw|: about 343 B.C. the Delians contested the ancient right of Athens to administer the temple of Apollo on their island. The case came before the Amphictyonic Council, probably in the spring of 343, when Demosth. was one of the Athenian delegates to Delphi (XIX. 65). The Assembly chose Aeschines as their counsel; but the Areopagus, to which the people had given authority to revise the election, rejected him and sent Hyperides in his place. This showed that the tide had turned against Macedon. Hyperides then delivered his eloquent lo/gos *dhliako/s at Delphi, and gained the case for Athens. See Hist. § 43.

2. neani/ou: this some- times (as here) expresses wantonness or insolence, like neaniko/s. See Eur. Alc. 679, a)/gan u(bri/zeis, kai\ neani/as lo/gous r(i/ptwn e)s h(ma=s, k.t.l.—ou) ga/r this sarcastic question (after ge) im

9. th=s...h(donh=s kai\ xa/ritos: abusive language (loidori/a) not only pleased the populace, but also gratified their whims and low tastes. A good example of both h(donh/ and xa/ris is the scene in the Assembly when the second embassy reported in July 346 B.C., described in XIX. 44—46. Demosthenes was insulted and jeered at by Aeschines and Philocrates, to the delight of the people: notice the single sarcastic remark of Demosthenes (46), kai\ u(mei=s e)gela=te. Hist. §§ 34, 35.

§§ 139—159. Next follows the account of the conduct of Aeschines in stirring up the Amphissian war in 339 B.C. (See note on §§ 126—226.) §§ 139—144 are introductory, and §§ 158, 159 are a peroration.
The first sentence depre- ciates the acts already mentioned, done in time of nominal peace, to heighten the enormity of helping Philip in time of war: cf. do/te...au)tw=| tou=to (3).

1. pro\ tou= polemei=n fanerw=s:
Demosth. often implies that the preceding peace was really a state of war. See IX. 19, a)f' h(=s h(me/ras a)nei=le *fwke/as, a)po\ tau/ths e)/gwg) au)to\n polemei=n o(ri/zomai. fanerw=s is repeated in l. 4.

3. kata\ th=s patri/dos: not con- nected in construction with deino
, but an independent exclamation, justifying the assertion in deino
 me
.

4. e)peidh\...e)porqei=to, after your ships had been openly seized (§ 73) and the ravaging of the Chersonese was going on. The ravaging of the Chersonese was marching an army through the Athenian territory there to enable his fleet to pass the Hellespont for the siege of Perinthus without molestation from the shore. Hist. 53.

5. e)pi\ th
 *)attikh
 e)poreu/eq): Philip's action at the Hellespont, if it had not been checked, would have opened the way for him into Attica and the whole of Greece. Demosth. had repeatedly warned the people of this peril: even in the First Philippic (351 B.C.) he had said (50), ka)

 *)attikh
 o(dou= kai\ th=s ei)s *pelopo/nnhson ku/rios ge/gone, and further tou= pro\s th
 *)attikh
 pole/mou, d\s luph/sei me
