 parh=|, ge/gone d' e)n e)kei/nh| th=| h(me/ra|. See § 143.7.
7. e)neisth/kei po/lemos: cf. o( e)nsta\s po/lemos, § 89.4. These words end the clause with e)peidh/.

8. i)ambeiogra/fos, writer of lam- poons (i)ambei=a), probably refers to verses written by Aeschines in his youth, to which he perhaps alludes in I. 136, peri\ de\ tw=n poihma/twn w(=n fasin ou(=toi/ me pepoihke/nai. This reading has the best MS. authority; but i)ambeiofa/gos, eater (or mouther) of iambics, was and is the common reading. If we read i)ambeiofa/gos, we must refer it to the career of Aeschines as an actor, not to his loidori/a, to which the ancient interpreters generally referred it. See Etym. Magn. *)iambofa/gos.
10. *ai)sxi/nh|, dat. of possession: has none to show.

11. e)n tw=| e)mw=| u(/dati, in my time: this general formula and e)pi\ tou= e)mou= u(/datos are often used when a speaker offers part of his own time to his opponent to prove something which he believes cannot be proved. It is a mere challenge, made with no idea of its being accepted. For the genitive with e)pi\ see LVII. 61 (end). The time allotted to each speaker in most
cases was measured by the clepsydra or water-clock (Dict. Antiq. under Horologium), a fixed number of a)mforei=s of water being poured in according to the importance of the case. Thus Aeschines (II. 126) says, pro\s e(/ndeka ga\r a)mfore/as e)n diamemetrhme/nh| th=| h(me/ra| kri/nomai, eleven a)mforei=s (about 100 gallons), allowed each speaker in cases of parapresbei/a, being the largest amount mentioned. The term diamemetrhme/nh h(me/ra is explained in Aesch. III. 197. In important public suits the day was divided into three parts, and the clepsydra was filled three times, the first measure of water being given to the accuser, the second (of equal amount) to the accused, and the third (in a)gw=nes timhtoi/, if the accused was convicted), a smaller measure, to the ti/mhsis, the decision o(/ ti xrh\ paqei=n h)\ a)poti/sai.

12. duoi=n...qa/teron: there is no infinitive or other verb to be supplied, and au)to\n is subject of gra/fein and fe/rein. duoi=n qa/teron (or qa/tera), a)mfo/teron or a)mfo/tera, ou)de/teron, and similar expressions, may stand emphatically, as adverbial phrases, before h)\...h)\, kai\...kai/, te...te, and in other cases where we simply say either...or, both...and, etc. See Plat. Theaet. 187 B, e)a\n ou(/tw drw=men, duoi=n qa/tera, h)\ eu(rh/somen e)f' d\ e)rxo/meqa, h)\ h(=tton oi)hso/meqa ei)de/nai d\ mhdamh=| i)/smen. So Il. III. 179, a)mfo/teron, basileu/s t' a)gaqo\s kratero/s t) ai)xmhth/s.
13—15. mhde\n...e)/xont) and zh- tou=nta are causal.—para\ tau=q), in opposition to these.

1. a)=r) ou)=n...e)/grafen; ou)d) ...ou)d) correspond to kai\...kai\ in positive expressions of this kind. We cannot express such negatives: the meaning is, as he proposed no measures, so did he also abstain from talking (so neither did he talk)? The sins of omission just described set these of commission in a stronger light.
2. ou) me\n...e(te/rw|, why, nobody else could get a chance to talk!
5. e)peceirga/sato: the idea of addition, which e)pi/ (like pro/s) expresses, is further extended by e)pe/qhke te/los, capped the climax.

6. tou\s pollou\s lo/gous, his many words, referring to the long and brilliant passage (III. 107—129) in which Aeschines describes his doings at Delphi when he stirred up the fatal Amphissian war. Cf. Aeschyl. Ag. 1456, mi/a ta\s polla\s, ta\s pa/nu polla\s yuxa\s o)le/sas).

7. ta\ tw=n *)amfisse/wn do/gmata, the decrees (of the Amphictyons) about the Amphissians, like to\ *megare/wn yh/fisma, the Megarian decree, Thuc. I. 140, called in I. 139 to\ peri\ *megare/wn yh/fisma. So tou/twn yh/fisma, XX. 115. Two MSS. omit tw=n *lokrw=n.

9. to\ d), but in fact: this to\ de/, with no correlative to\ me/n, is common in Plato, introducing an adversative statement. See Apol. 23 A, oi)/ontai/ me...ei)=nai sofo/n: to\ de\ kinduneu/ei. So Rep. 340 D (end), 357 A.—ou) toiou=to/n e)sti, i.e. this cannot be done (the case is not of such a nature), referring to w(s diastre/ywn ta)lhqe/s.— po/qen; cf. § 47.6.—e)kni/yei: cf. Act. Apost. xxii. 16, a)po/lousai ta\s a(marti/as sou, wash away thy sins.

The solemn invocation in this chapter, resembling those which begin and end the exordium (§§ 1, 8), calls attention again to the gravity of the charge about to be made, and to the supreme importance of the events which led to the fatal issue on the field of Chaeronea. He defends his invocation and his general earnestness in §§ 142—144.

4. patrw=|os: Apollo was the pa- ternal God of Athens, not only as the great Ionic divinity, but as the father of Ion (according to Athenian belief). See Schol. on Ar. Av. 1527, patrw=|on de\ timw=sin *)apo/llwna *)aqhnai=oi, e)pei\ *)/iwn, o(pole/marxos *)aqhnai/wn, e)c' *apo/llwnos kai\ *kreou/shs th=s *cou/qou e)ge/neto. So in the Ion of Euripides.

5. ei) a)lhqh= ei)/poimi kai\ ei)=pon, lit. if I should speak the truth to you now and if I did speak it then on the spot: a double condition combining a future and a past supposition (M.T. 509). We should rather invert the order and say, if I then spoke the truth and (shall) speak it again now. Cf. § 190.8.
9. pro\s e)/xqran, with a view to enmity: cf. dia\...e)/xqran in § 143.10.— filoneiki/as, contentiousness (against an enemy).
11. a)no/nhton: so XIX. 315.

1. e)ph/ramai: referring to the whole invocation of § 141, but especially to the imprecation in the last clause. ti/ tau=t' e)ph/ramai; is why have I made this imprecation? while ti/ dieteina/mhn ou(twsi\ sfodrw=s; (aor.) is why did I express myself with all this vehement earnestness?
2. e)/xwn and ei)dw\s (3) are con- cessive.—e)n tw=| dhmosi/w|, in the public record-office: this was in the *mhtrw=|on (see Aesch. III. 187, Paus. I. 3, 5).
4. mh\...e)la/ttwn, i.e. lest Aeschines may be thought too small a man to work so great mischief.

6. o(/per pro/teron sune/bh: this allusion to a former time when Aesch. caused the ruin of the Phocians by bringing home false reports, can refer only to the return of the second embassy in 346 B.C. (see §§ 32—36). This distinct statement that Aesch. was then thought “too insignificant to do so much harm,” with the apprehension that the court may make the same mistake again in the present case, is one of the strongest proofs that the case against Aeschines really came to trial, that the speeches de Falsa Legatione were actually spoken, and that Aeschines was acquitted by a small majority.
1. to\n e)n *)amfi/ssh| po/le- mon: for this and the seizure of Elatea, see § 152.8 and note.
2. h(|re/qh h(gemw\n o(\s (sc. tis), a man was chosen leader, who etc. (i.e. Philip).
6. e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a|, i.e. in the meeting in which Aesch. made his report of his doings in the Amphictyonic Council (Hist. § 61).
7. ei)s th\n *)attikh\n: Demosth. saw at once the full meaning of the Amphictyonic war, and knew that it must end in bringing Philip into Greece as the Amphictyonic general (see note on § 139.5).
8. oi(...sugkaqh/menoi, those who sat together by his summons, i.e. his para/klhtoi, with whom he had packed the meeting.

9. ou)k ei)/wn me le/gein, i.e. would not let me go on speaking (after my warning).—oi( d' e)qau/mazon: the ordinary citizens were amazed at anyone who dared to object to the pious and (apparently) patriotic speech of Aeschines. The decree of Demosthenes forbidding Athens to take any part in the future action of the Amphictyonic Council against Amphissa (Aesch. 125—127) was passed at a later meeting, after the people had opened their eyes.

4. u(pakou/sate: see Plat. Theaet. 162 A, pa/ntws kai\ nu=n dh\ ma/l' e)mmelw=s soi e)fai/neto u(pakou/ein, and 162 D, tai=s ou)=n dhmhgori/ais o)ce/ws u(pakou/eis. The general meaning is, now take your opportunity to listen to the story, since you were kept from hearing it at the right time.
5. eu)= pra=gma sunteqe\n, that the plan was well concocted.

6. pro\s i(stori/an, for gaining a knowledge. The real history of these events must be disentangled from the long story of Aeschines (106—131), supplemented and often corrected by the briefer account of Demosthenes (145—159). See Hist. §§ 57—62.

1. ou)k h)=n...ei) mh\ poih/seie: see M.T. 696 and the examples. The protasis depends on an apodosis implied in ou)k h)=n...*fili/ppw|, the real meaning being Philip felt that he could not end or escape the war unless he should make the Th. hostile to our city. This involves indirect discourse; and we might therefore have had e)a
 mh\ poih/sh| here for ei) mh\ poih/seie. See Thuc. VII. 59, ta)/lla, h)
 e)/ti naumaxei=n oi( *)aqhnai=oi tolmh/swsi, pareskeua/zonto, where the condition really depends on the idea to be ready implied in pareskeua/zonto, and ei)... tolmh/saien might have been used. Cf. Thuc. VI. 100, pro\s th
 po/lin, ei) e)pibohqoi=en, e)xw/roun, they marched towards the city, in case they (the citizens) should rush out, i.e. to meet them in that case; the thought being h)
 e)pibohqw=sin.

4. a)qli/ws...polemou/ntwn: Chares and Phocion were the Athenian commanders at the beginning of the war, while Philip was besieging Byzantium. Chares was much censured for inefficiency, but for Phocion's general
ship there is only praise. These operations are probably those of the later part of 340—339, when Philip was in Scythia (Hist. § 56).
5. u(p' au)tou= tou= pole/mou, i.e. by the mere state of war.
6. lh|stw=n: a state of war natur- ally encouraged pirates and plunderers.
7. tw=n e)k th=s xw/ras gignome/nwn: see §§ 44.4, 213.12.
8. w(=n e)dei=t): sc. ou)de/n.—au)tw=|, with ei)sh/geto.

3. mh/te...diie/ntwn, i.e. ei) mh/te *qettaloi\ a)kolouqoi=en mh/te *qhbai=oi diiei=en: Philip depended on Thessalian troops to fill his army, but he would have been satisfied with Thebes (under the circumstances) if she had merely made no objection to his marching through Boeotia to attack Athens. There was probably a coolness already between Thebes and Philip, which appears later when Thebes refused to attend the Amphictyonic meeting in the autumn of 339 B.C. (See Aesch. III. 128.) See Hist. § 57, for these relations.
5. o(poiousdh/poq): here relative, while generally relative forms with ou)=n and dh/pote are indefinite. See tou\s o(poioustinasou=n in VIII. 20, and o(/tou dh/pote e(/neka in § 21.10 (above).

7. tw=n u(parxo/ntwn e(kate/rois, of the relative resources of each, i.e. of his own inferiority in resources, especially in naval power. See Thuc. I. 141.8, where Pericles speaks of the comparative resources of Athens and her enemies: ta\ de\ tou= pole/mou kai\ tw=n e(kate/rois u(parxo/ntwn w(s ou)k a)sqene/stera e(/comen.

This is closely connected in thought with the beginning of § 145. How, thought Philip, can I induce the Thessalians and Thebans to join me? He remembered their zeal in the Phocian war: see XIX. 50, toi=s *)amfiktu/osi:...poi/ois; ou) ga\r h)=san au)to/qi plh\n *qhbai=oi kai\ *qettaloi/. A new Sacred war, or any war for the rights of the Amphictyonic Council, would be sure to rouse their interest again.

1. ei) me\n...sumpei/qoi, i.e. if he were to join in an attempt to persuade them etc.: sum- implies that he would depend greatly on the influence of his friends in Thebes and Thessaly.— e(/nek), on the ground of.

2. ou)de/n' h(gei=to prose/cein: I omit a)\n before h(gei=to, with L, A 1, and
most recent editors, because its insertion is accounted for by the v. l. prose/xein, with which it would be required. (See M.T. 208.) The simple prose/cein is also supported by the following parakrou/sesqai and pei/sein and by the infinitives in § 148. For the conditional forms in this section and the following, see note on § 148.5.

3. e)a\n...ai(reqh=|, i.e. if he should adopt (as his own) some grounds common to both Thebans and Thessalians, and so be chosen general. See ta\s i)di/as profa/seis, opposed to ta\s *)amfiktuonika\s (the real koina/s), in § 158.1. The actual result of the scheme is seen in §§ 151, 152.
5. ta\ me\n...pei/sein, i.e. to succeed sometimes by deception, sometimes by persuasion. For the tense of the infinitive with e)lpi/zw, see M.T. 136.
6. qea/sasq' w(s eu)=, see how craftily: cf. § 144.5.—po/lemon poih=sai (not poih/sasqai), to get up a war, i.e. to get the Amphictyons into a war.

7. th
 *pulai/an: the meeting of the Amphictyonic Council was so called, because twice in each year (in the spring and the autumn) the Council met first at Thermopylae in the sanctuary of Demeter Amphictyonis, and afterwards proceeded to Delphi, where the regular sessions were held. See Hyper. Epitaph. § 18, a)fiknou/menoi ga di\s tou= e)niautou= ei)s th
 *pulai/an, qewroi\ genh/sontai tw=n e)/rgwn k.t.l., with Aesch. III. 126, poreu/esqai ei)s *pu/las kai\ ei)s *delfou\s e)n toi=s tetagme/nois xro/nois, and Strab. p. 429 (of Thermopylae) *dh/mhtros i(ero
, e)n w(=| kata\ pa=san *pulai/an qusi/an e)te/loun oi( *)amfiktu/ones. Records of Amphictyonic meetings at Delphi in the spring as well as the autumn are found in inscriptions.—ei)s tau=t)...deh/sesqai, would need him for these, especially for the war, as the only available commander.

Having made up his mind (1) that he must have the support of Thebes and Thessaly (§§ 145, 146), and (2) that he can secure this only by an Amphictyonic war (§ 147), he now (3) determines to find some Athenian to instigate the war, to disarm all suspicion in advance. For this important work he hires Aeschines (§ 148).

2. i(eromnhmo/nwn: for the constitu- tion of the Amphictyonic Council see Essay V.—e)kei/nou, his, from the orator's point of view, just after e(autou=, his own, from Philip's: cf. Xen. Mem. IV. 7, 1, th\n e(autou= gnw/mhn a)pefai/neto pro\s tou\s o(milou=ntas au)tw=|.

5. a)
 d' *)aqhnai=osh)=|: we have the same antithesis here between a)
...h)=| and the preceding ei)...ei)shgoi=to which we had in § 147 between e)a
...ai(reqh=| (3) and ei) sumpei/qoi (1). It is commonly assumed that e)a
 with the subjunctive expresses greater probability or likelihood that the supposition may prove true than ei) with the optative; and this double antithesis is often cited as a strong confirmation of this view. It seems to be overlooked that all four suppositions are in oratio obliqua after past tenses, and would all be expressed in the oratio recta (i.e. as Philip conceived them) by subjunctives, e)a
 sumpei/qw, ai(reqw=, ei)shgh=tai, *)aqhnai=os h)=|, which would all be retained if the leading verb were present or future. If these forms now show any inherent distinction between subj. and opt. as regards probability, this has been introduced by the oratio obliqua after a past tense. The two subjunctives express the plans which Philip had most at heart, and the two optatives express the opposite alternatives. Cf. note on ei) proairhso/meq) in § 176.1. See Trans. of the Am. Philol. Assoc. for 1873, pp. 71, 72, and the Eng. Journ. of Philology vol. V. no. 10, p. 198.
3. problhqei\s, nominated: the pula/goroi were chosen by hand vote (xeirotonhsa/ntwn), while the i(eromnh/mwn, the higher officer, was chosen annually by lot (laxw/n, Ar. Nub. 623).
4. triw=n h)\ tetta/rwn: this small vote shows how little the Assembly understood the importance of the election.
5. a)ci/wma, prestige, dignity (of a delegate of Athens).
6. ei)s tou\s *)amfiktu/onas: this was the meeting in the spring of 339 B.C., described by Aeschines (III. 115—124).

8. eu)prosw/pous, plausible (fair- faced; cf. barefaced).—mu/qous, tales, referring to the eloquent account of the first Sacred war in the time of Solon (Aesch. III. 107—112).—o(/qen... kaqierw/qh, from the time when the plain of Cirrha was consecrated: cf. Aesch. III. 61, le/cw o(/qen ma/lista parakolouqh/sete. We see by this that Aeschines repeated to the Amphictyons in 339 his story of the consecration of the plain of Cirrha, with all the terrible curses which were imprecated against those who should cultivate the devoted land, which he told in court in 330. The consecration was made at the end of the first Sacred war, about 586 B.C.

10. a)pei/rous lo/gwn: “to the com- paratively rude men at Delphi, the speech of a first-rate Athenian orator was a rarity.” (Grote.) The Amphictyonic Council was composed chiefly of representatives of obscure and uncultivated states. It was, in fact, a mere relic of antiquity, which had outlived its right to exist; and in the time of Philip it was merely galvanized into an unnatural vitality, which proved fatal to Greece and helpful only to the invader. See Grote's remarks at the beginning of chap. 87. Hist. §§ 59, 60.

1. perielqei=n th\n xw/ran: to make an inspection (peri/odos) of the land. An inscription of 380 B.C. records an order of the Amphictyons for official peri/odoi of the consecrated land, and for imposing a fine on any who should be found encroaching on it.
3. h)|tia=t), alleged (in his accusa- tion).

4. ou)demi/an e)pago/ntwn: Aesch. (116) says the Amphissians intended to propose a decree in the Council (ei)se/feron do/gma) fining Athens fifty talents for hanging up on the walls of the new temple some old shields, relics of Plataea, with the restored inscription, *)aqhnai=oi a)po\ *mh/dwn kai\ *qhbai/wn o(/te ta)nanti/a toi=s *(/ellhsin e)ma/xonto. Demosthenes cannot understand by di/khn e)pago/ntwn what Aeschines means by ei)se/feron do/gma. An intention to introduce a decree (ei)se/feron) would not need a previous summons, which di/khn e)pa/gein, and still more di/khn tele/sasqai (7), to make a suit ready for trial, would require. And the further remark of Demosthenes, ou)d' a(\ nu=n ou(=tos profasi/zetai (5), seems to imply that Aeschines had told a different story about the intentions of the Amphissians when he made his report of the meeting at Delphi (III. 125) from that which he told in court. It is therefore difficult to judge the argument of Demosthenes about the want of a legal summons.

8. a)po\ poi/as a)rxh=s; from what authority did the summons come? Witnesses to a summons were required at Athens when the defendant was in Attica. These were called klhth=res, which same name was given to the officers of the law who served a summons on persons outside of Attica: see Ar. Av. 147, 1422. e)klh/teusen refers to the act of such an Amphictyonic klhth/r.
9. dei=con: cf. dei=con, XXIX. 41.— a)ll' ou)k a)\n e)/xois: so § 76.3.
10. Notice position of tau/th|.
1. periio/ntwn: cf. periel- qei=n, § 150.1. See Aesch. 122, 123.
3. mikrou= (M.T. 779.b), almost, belongs to kathko/ntisan: cf. Aesch. 123, ei) mh\ e)cefu/gomen, e)kinduneu/samen a)pole/sqai. See § 269.6.
5. e)gklh/m...e)tara/xqh: we have po/- lemon tara/ssein, like proelia miscere or confundere, Plat. Rep. 567 A, and e)gklh/mata tara/cein, Plut. Them. 5 (Bl.).
6. *ko/ttufos: the president of the Council, a Thessalian of Pharsalus.
7. ou)k h)=lqon: e.g. Thebans and Athenians, and doubtless others.

8. ou)de
 e)poi/oun: see Aesch. 129. —ei)s th
 e)piou=san...h)=gon (sc. ta\ pra/gmata), took measures at once, against the coming meeting (autumn of 339), to put things (i.e. the war) into the hands of Philip as commander. See IX. 57, oi( me
 e)f' h(ma=s h)=gon ta\ pra/gmata, oi( d) e)pi\ *fi/lippon.
9. oi( kateskeuasme/noi (pass.), those with whom arrangements had been made.
10. pa/lai ponhroi\: cf. § 158.7, u(po\ pollw=n kai\ ponhrw=n.

Demosthenes distinctly implies that Cottyphus was made general at the spring meeting, but that, after a mere pretence of war, intrigues at once began for superseding him by Philip at the autumnal meeting (ei)s th\n e)piou=san *pulai/an). Aeschines, on the contrary, whose whole object is to show that a real Amphictyonic war was intended, with no help or thought of help from Philip, and to represent Philip's final appointment as commander as a remote afterthought, states that no action was taken against the Amphissians in the spring, but that a special meeting was called before the regular autumnal *pulai/a, to take such action (124). At this special meeting, which Athens and Thebes refused to attend (Aesch. 126—128), Cottyphus was chosen general, (according to Aesch.) while Philip was “away off in Scythia”; and after a successful campaign the Amphissians were fined and their offending citizens were banished. But they refused to submit; and finally, “a long time afterwards” (pollw=| xro/nw| u(/steron), a second expedition became necessary “after Philip's return from his Scythian expedition”; —he does not even then say that Philip was actually made general! See Hist. §§ 61—63.
2. au)tou\s ei)sfe/rein... dei=n, they must themselves (ipsos) pay taxes.
4. h)\ )kei=non ai(rei=sqai: this alter- native was one of the profa/seis eu)/logoi (§ 152.1) for choosing Philip.
6. parelqw\n (sc. ei)/sw *pulw=n): cf. § 35.3.
7. e)rrw=sqai fra/sas polla\, bid- ding many farewells (a long adieu): so XIX. 248. Cf. e)/rrwso, vale.

8. *)ela/teian: when Philip had passed Thermopylae, he hardly made a pretence of entering into the war with Amphissa, for which he was chosen commander; and he soon appeared at the Phocian town of Elatea, which commanded the pass into Boeotia and “the road to Athens.” This move left no further doubt as to his real intentions. Aeschines says (140) of Philip's sudden movement, to
 po/lemon o(
 pro/teron e)ch/lasen e)k th=s xw/ras th=s *boiwtw=n (i.e. the Phocian war), tou=ton pa/lin to
 au)to
 po/lemon (i.e. a similar sacred war) e)ph=ge dia\ th=s *fwki/dos e)p' au)ta\s ta\s *qh/bas. Philip must have been made general in the early autumn of 339 B.C., and probably seized Elatea in the late autumn or early winter; so that the campaign lasted about eight or nine months until the battle of Chaeronea in August or September 338. A “winter battle” is naturally mentioned in § 216.6. The startling effect at Athens of the news from Elatea is described in §§ 169 ff.

2. meq' h(mw=n e)ge/nonto, joined us.—w(/sper xeima/rrous, like a winter torrent: most of the rivers of Greece are nearly or quite dry the greater part of the year, and in the winter and spring are often filled by rushing torrents. Many of these, when dry, still serve as paths over the mountain passes. Similar simple comparisons are w(/sper ne/fos, § 188.5 (cf. nukti\ e)oikw/s, Il. I. 47); w(/sper pneu=ma, § 308.9.
3. a(/pan tou=to to\ pra=gm): we might say this whole thing, but with far less dignity.
4. nu=n, as it was, in fact, opposed to ei) mh\ mete/gnwsan: cf. § 133.7.—to/ g' e)cai/fnhs, for the moment.
6. ei)=ta...di) e)me/, lit. but besides, and so far as depended on any one man, also through me: the former kai\ connects o(/son...a)/ndra to ei)=ta.

7. do/gmata tau=ta are Amphicty- onic decrees about the Amphissian affair.—tou\s xro/nous: we see from § 155.14 that this was an official statement from the records, showing that these decrees were passed when Aeschines was pula/goros.
8. h( miara\ kefalh\: cf. XXI. 117, kai\ tau=t' e)/legen h( miara\ kai\ a)naidh\s au(/th kefalh\ e)celhluqw\s k.t.l., and XIX. 313.
9. tara/cas): we should express tara/casa by the leading verb, and di/khn ou)k e)/dwken by without being punished. With pra/gmata tara/casa cf. § 151.5 and note.

1. ou)x u(ph/kouon: this must refer to a refusal of the Thebans, before the seizure of Elatea, to join Philip in an expedition against the Amphissians, against whom he professed to be marching: see § 152.7, w(s e)pi\ th\n *kirrai/an.

2. summa/xous: i.e. the Arcadians, Eleans, and Argives. See Isocr. V. 74, *)argei=oi de\ kai\ *messh/nioi kai\ *megalopoli=tai kai\ tw=n a)/llwn polloi\ sumpolemei=n (sc. u(pa/rxousi/ soi e(/toimoi), and Dem. IX. 27. See Hist. §§ 41, 42.

6. koina\: cf. koina\s profa/seis, §§ 147.4, 158.1-3.—toi=s *)amfiktu/osi do/canta, Amphictyonic decrees, a(\ toi=s *)amf. e)/docen. Cf. III. 14, to\ poiei=n e)qe/lein ta/ ge do/canta. The older Athenian decrees began with e)/doce th=| boulh=| kai\ tw=| dh/mw|.
2. *)amfiktuonika\s: see §§ 147.3, 156.—katafeu/gei, takes refuge, opposed to feu/gei (1), shuns.
3. profa/seis e)ndou/s: cf. Thuc. II. 87 (end), ou)k e)ndw/somen pro/fasin ou)deni\ kakw=| gene/sqai.
5. mh\ le/gete periio/ntes, do not go about and tell.

6. u(f' e(no\s a)nqrw/pou, i.e. by Philip: cf. ei(=s a)nh/r (of Philip), XIX. 64. Philip (he says) could never have accomplished his purpose, had he not had such accomplices as Aeschines. Notice the effective collocation in h( *(ella\s a)nqrw/pou.
2. mhde\n eu)labhqe/nta, without reserve.

3. koino\n a)lith/rion, a common curse and destroyer. An a)lith/rios is a man who has sinned against the Gods and is thereby under a curse, which curse he transmits to others with whom he has to do; also an avenging divinity: cf. Aen. II. 573, Troiae et patriae communis Erinnys (of Helen). See Andocides I. 130, 131. *)ala/stwr is similarly used in both senses: see § 296.5, XIX. 305; see also Aeschyl. Eum. 236, de/xou de\ preumenw=s a)la/stora (one who has already been purified); Pers. 354, fanei\s a)la/stwr h)\ kako\s dai/mwn poqe/n. Aeschines twice (III. 131, 157) calls Demosthenes th=s *(ella/dos a)lith/rios (see Blass).

6. tw=n fu/ntwn kakw=n (so *s), of the harvest of woes: without kakw=n, which many omit, we should have
the common saying about the harvest. Cic. Phil. II. 22. 55 perhaps supports kakw=n: ut igitur in seminibus est causa arborum et stirpium, sic huius luctuosissimi belli semen tu fuisti.— o(\n: object of both i)do/ntes and a)pestra/fhte: the latter becomes transitive in the passive, like fobe/w, e)kplh/ssw, etc.
8. pro\ th=s a)lhqei/as: i.e. so as to conceal the truth from you.

§§ 160—226. The orator now passes to his own agency in opposing the joint plot of Aeschines and Philip. See introductory note on §§ 126—226. After speaking of the enmity between Athens and Thebes, which men like Aeschines had encouraged (§§ 160— 163), he gives a graphic account of the panic excited at Athens by Philip's seizure of Elatea, and of the manner in which he took advantage of this emergency to bring Athens and Thebes to a better understanding and even to an alliance against the common enemy (§§ 168—226). Into this account he introduces (§§ 189—210) a most eloquent and earnest defence of the whole line of policy in opposition to Philip which Athens had followed chiefly by his advice. He pleads that Athens, with her glorious traditions, could have taken no other course, even if she had seen the fatal defeat at Chaeronea in advance. This is the most eloquent and impassioned passage in the oration; and it is addressed not merely to the court, but to the whole people and to future ages.
4. a)kou/saite: this read- ing, though it has slight MS. authority, is necessary here, with e(/nek' a)/n in *s and L. *s often has e for ai or ai for e, from their identity in later pronunciation.
5, 7. ta\ e)/gra...tou\s lo/gous: the actual labours, contrasted with merely listening to the account of them. Cf. lo/gw| and ta\ e)/rga, Thuc. I. 22.

The orator introduces this continu- ation of his political history in an apologetic way, as in § 110.5 he professed to leave it doubtful whether he should speak at all of these later acts, ta\ me/gista......pepragme/nwn (see note). This is a part of the skilful device by which he divides the long account of his public life, while at the same time he reminds the court that the brilliant passage which follows is over and above what is needed to defend Ctesiphon (see § 126.1), and asks their attention to it as a personal favour to himself.

The orator recurs to the critical moment in the relations of Athens and Thebes, when both were astounded by the sudden seizure of Elatea, and the great question was
whether Thebes would join Philip against Athens, or Athens against the invader.
1. o(rw=n: with parorw=ntas (5), fu- lattome/nous, and e)/xontas (M.T. 904).
2. u(po\ tw=n...diefqarme/nwn: ex- pressing the agency by which the condition described in parorw=ntas etc. was effected, as if the participles were passive.

3. par' e(kate/rois, i.e. in each city. For Athens the great danger was that her old enmity against Thebes might prevent her from taking the only safe course, union with Thebes. For Philip's way of working in such cases, see § 61. Dissen contrasts par' e(kate/rois, apud utrosque seorsim, in each city, with a)mfote/rois (4), utrisque simul, both.
5. to\...au)ca/nesqai: appositive to the omitted antecedent of o(\ (3), which is the object of parorw=ntas etc.
7. o(/pws tou=to (to\ proskrou/ein) mh\ ge/noito (so *s and L.1): most MSS. have the more common genh/setai (M.T. 339, 340).
8. parathrw=n diete/loun, I kept continual watch.
9. tau=ta: the policy of friendship with Thebes (tau/thn th\n fili/an, § 162.2), implied in o(/pws tou=to mh\ ge/noito.

1. *)aristofw=nta (see § 70.5), a leading statesman of the earlier period and a strong friend of Thebes. Aesch. says of him (III. 139), plei=ston xro/non th\n tou= boiwtia/zein u(pomei/nas ai)ti/an.—*eu)/boulon (cf. § 70.5): see Grote XI. 387.

2. boulome/nous and o(mognwmo- nou=ntas (4) are imperfect, past to ei)dw\s and diete/loun: but a)ntile/gontas (3), though they opposed one another, is present to o(mogn., to which it is subordinate.—tau/thn th\n fili/an: the friendship for Thebes during the oppressive Spartan supremacy, which appeared in the aid privately sent by Athens to Thebes when she expelled the Spartan garrison from the Cadmea in 379 B.C. This friendship was broken after Leuctra in 371. See § 98.4 and note.

5. parhkolou/qeis is more than you were one of their followers; it means you followed them round or hung on to them in a servile way. Eubulus was one of the sunh/goroi who supported Aesch. at his trial for parapresbei/a (Aesch. II. 184). The anonymous
Life of Aeschines makes him a clerk to both Eubulus and Aristophon.

1. e)kei=s), i.e. to the main point.

2. poih/santos, sumperaname/nwn: sum- implies that, while Aesch. got up the Amphissian war by himself, he had active helpers in stirring up enmity at Athens against Thebes. When all was ready, Philip appeared at Elatea (e)lqei=n e)f' h(ma=s, 4): cf. § 168.3.

6. a)nalabei=n, to recover (intrans.): cf. Plat. Rep. 467 B, poih=sai kai\ th\n a)/llhn po/lin a)du/naton a)nalabei=n.
7. ou(/tw with me/xri po/rrw, so far. —proh/gagon, carried it, i.e. the quarrel with Thebes.

8, 9. yhfisma/twn, a)pokri/sewn: as these documents were quoted to show the enmity between Thebes and Athens at the time of Philip's invasion, the yhfi/smata were probably Athenian decrees enacting measures hostile to Thebes, and the replies were remonstrances or retaliatory measures on the part of Thebes. Nothing could be more absurd than the two decrees against Philip and the two letters of Philip which appear here in the text. See § 168.2, where Philip is said to have been elated (e)parqei/s) by the decrees and the replies, i.e. by the evidence of hostility which they showed.
1. ou(/tw: as the docu- ments showed.

4. w(s ou)d) a)
...sumpneusa/ntwn a)
, i.e. feeling (w(s) that under no possible circumstances would the Thebans and ourselves become harmonious: sumpneusa/ntwn a)
 represents sumpneu/saimen a)
. The MSS. all have sumpneuso/ntwn a)/n, which Bekker retains. The future participle with a)

Moreover, the future of pne/w is not pneu/sw, but pneu/somai or pneusou=mai, and this should be decisive (see Veitch). See M.T. 216; and for the repetition of a)/n, 223.

§§ 169—180. Here follows the famous description of the panic in Athens when the news of the seizure of Elatea arrived, and of the meeting of the Assembly which was suddenly called to consider the alarming situation. This is a celebrated example of diatu/pwsis, vivid delineation.

1. The succession of tenses, h)=n, h(=ke (had come), and katei/lhptai (the direct form for the indirect), makes the narrative lively and picturesque at the outset. Much would have been lost if he had said h)=lqe d) a)gge/llwn tis w(s kateilhmme/nh ei)/h.—w(s tou\s pruta/neis: the message came to the Prytanes, the fifty senators of one of the ten tribes, who for their term of one-tenth of the year represented the authority of the state. Their office was the qo/los or skia/s, a round building with a cupola in the a)gora/, adjoining the Senate-house and the mhtrw=|on with its record-office. There the e)pista/ths of the Prytanes was expected to spend his whole day and night of office, with a third of the Prytanes whom he had selected (Arist. Pol. Ath. 44.5), so as to be accessible in emergencies like the present; and there the state provided meals for all the Prytanes. The qo/los is distinct from the ancient Prytaneum or City Hall, where certain privileged persons (a)ei/sitoi) had their meals at a public table, to which ambassadors and other guests of the state were sometimes invited.
4. tou\s...skhnw=n: cf. § 44.4.

5. ta\ ge/rra, probably the wicker- work with which the booths (skh=nai) in the market-place were covered. The word can mean also anything made of twigs, and is used of a wicker fence which enclosed the e)kklhsi/a (see Harpocr. under ge/rra, and LIX. 90). But the close connection of the two clauses, drove out those in the booths and burnt the ge/rra, shows that the ge/rra which were burnt were taken from the booths. Otherwise there is no reason for driving the poor hucksters out at all. If it is said that this was done to prepare for the “monster meeting” the next morning, we must remember, first, that the Assembly was held in the Pnyx, not in the a)gora/; and, secondly, that there was to be a meeting of the Senate before that of the Assembly, which would give time enough to make all necessary preparations after daybreak. To suppose, further, that the booths were torn to pieces and burnt on the spot after dark, merely to clear the a)gora/, when there was no pressure of time, even if the place needed clearing at all, is to impute to the Prytanes conduct well worthy of
madmen. Such a panic as this senseless proceeding would have caused was surely the last object which these guardians of the state could have had, when they left their supper unfinished and hastened into the market-place. Their first object certainly was to secure a full meeting of the Assembly the next morning. It will be noticed that while some (oi( me\n) of the Prytanes were engaged in clearing the booths, others (oi( de\) were summoning the ten Generals. The Generals and the Prytanes had the duty of calling special meetings of the Assembly (e)kklhsi/as sugklh/tous): see Thuc. IV. 118.52, e)kklhsi/an de\ poih/santas tou\s strathgou\s kai\ tou\s pruta/neis, and II. 59.11 (of Pericles), su/llogon poih/sas (e)/tid' e)strath/gei). There can, therefore, be hardly a doubt that the two acts were connected with summoning the Assembly. To do this effectually it was necessary to alarm the whole of Attica immediately; and the natural method for this was to light bonfires on some of the hills near Athens, which would be a signal to distant demes to light fires on their own hills. A fire on Lycabettus could thus give signals directly and indirectly to the whole of Attica, and probably this was understood as a call of the citizens to a special Assembly. As material for lighting signal fires might not always be on hand, it is likely that the dry covering of the booths struck the eyes of the Prytanes as they came out of their office, and that they took them in their haste for this purpose. Their high authority was needed to prevent resistance on the part of the owners of the booths.
6. salpikth\n: to give signals with his trumpet.

7. th
 boulh
 e)ka/loun: see Arist. Pol. Ath. 44.7, e)peida

 h)\ to

10. xrhmati/sai kai\ probouleu=sai, proceed to business and pass a vote (probou/leuma).

11. a)/nw kaqh=to, i.e. the people in their impatience were already seated in the Pnyx: a)/nw shows that the Assembly sat on a hill, probably in the place now known as the Pnyx. See XXV. 9 and 20, to\n dh=mon ei)s th\n e)kklhsi/an a)nabai/nein. For the identity of this famous place, see Crow in Papers of the American School at Athens, IV. pp. 205—260.
1. w(s h)=lqen h( boulh\, i.e. when, after the adjournment of the Senate, the senators entered the Assembly.

2. a)ph/ggeilan oi( pruta/neis: the fifty Prytanes were still the chief men in both Senate and Assembly, though at this time (certainly since 377 B.C.) the duty of presiding in both bodies was given to nine pro/edroi, who were chosen by lot each day from the senators of the other nine tribes by the e)pista/ths of the Prytanes (Arist. Pol. Ath. 44.7-9). The pro/edroi had an e)pista/ths of their own, called o( e)pista/ths tw=n proe/drwn (Aesch. III. 39). This is the office held by Demosthenes in
the last meeting of the Assembly before the departure of the second embassy in 346: see Aesch. III. 74.
3. to\n h(/konta, the messenger who had brought the news about Elatea: cf. § 28.5.

4. ti/s a)goreu/ein bou/letai; the regular formula for opening a debate: cf. § 191.2. Aeschines (III. 2 and 4) laments the omission of the additional words, tw=n u(pe\r penth/konta e)/th gegono/twn kai\ pa/lin e)n me/rei tw=n a)/llwn *)aqhnai/wn, the Solonic form.
9. to\n e)rou=nq)=o(\s e)rei=, the man to speak (M.T. 565): cf. § 285.3.
5. oi( triako/sioi, the Three Hundred: see note on § 103.4.
6. a)mfo/tera tau=ta: see note on § 139.12.
7. ta\s mega/las e)pido/seis, the large contributions, made after the battle of Chaeronea (Hist. § 67): meta\ tau=ta refers to the events which ended in that battle.

3. parhkolouqhko/ta, one who had followed the track of events.
See XIX. 257 (end), and Ev. Luc. i. 3 parhkolouqhko/ti a)/nwqen pa=sin a)kribw=s.
8. ou)de\n...ei)/sesqai, i.e. was none the more likely to know. The best MSS. have h)/mellen here and in § 192.4, and e)/mellon in § 101.5.
1. ou(=tos (pred.), that man, whom o( kairo\s...e)ka/lei (§ 172.1): cf. § 282.10, ou(=tos eu(re/qhs.
2. a(\...a)kou/sate: relative as obj. of imperative, as we say which do at your peril. For this in oi)=sq' o(\ dra=son; and similar expressions, see M.T. 253.
3. prossxo/ntes to\n nou=n, atten- tively, cf. animum advertere.

5. th
...e)/lipon, I did not desert my post of devotion to the state, i.e. I was never guilty of lipotaci/a here. This military figure was a favourite of Demosthenes. See III. 36, mh\ paraxwrei=n th=s ta/cews h(
 u(mi=n oi( pro/gonoi th=s a)reth=s...kate/lipon; XV. 32, 33 (with the figure often repeated); XIX. 9, 29; XXI. 120, leloipe/nai th
 tou= dikai/ou ta/cin. The same figure is seen in e)chtazo/mhn (l. 6), in e)ch/tasai (§ 197.10), e)chta/zeto (§ 217.7), e)cetazome/nhn u(pe u(mw=n (§ 277.7), and in e)ce/tasis, a mustering (as of troops), a call for (§§ 310.1, 320.10). Here there is always an idea of being counted in on one side or the other of some contest.—eu)noi/as: see note on § 1.2.
6. le/gwn...e)chtazo/mhn (see last note), I was found ready (at my post), when the test came, speaking and proposing measures.
8. pollw=|...e)mpeiro/teroi, far more experienced for the future in the whole administration of the state (politei/as).
1. ei)=pon o(/ti: introduc- ing a direct quotation (M.T. 711).
2. w(s...*fili/ppw|, in the belief (w(s) that Philip can depend on the Thebans: cf. §§ 95.5, 228.3.
3. qoruboume/nous, disturbed: cf. qoru/bou, § 169.6.

6. i(/n)...poih/shtai, i.e. to prepare Thebes for his appearance there as a
friend: cf. eu)t re/pistai (i.e. eu)trepei=s pepoi/htai), § 175.3.
6. plhsi/on du/namin dei/cas, by making a display of force in their neighbourhood, Elatea being near enough to Thebes to make Philip's presence there alarming.
7. e)pa=rai (cf. e)parqei\s, § 168.2), with poih=sai and kataplh=cai, depends on bou/letai understood, this answering ti/ bou/letai; as the following i(/n' ... biasqw=sin answers ti/nos e(/neka;

1. ei) me\n...proairhso/meq): this most vivid form of future supposition here expresses what the orator wishes to make especially prominent by way of warning and admonition, though it happens that this is not what he wishes or what actually occurs. It is an excellent case of Gildersleeve's “minatory and monitory conditions” (see Trans. of Amer. Philol. Assoc. for 1876, p. 13, and M.T. 447, with footnote). On the other hand, a)\n me/ntoi peisqh=t' e)moi/ (8) happens to express what he most desires and what actually occurs. Compare the antithesis of subjunctive and optative in §§ 147, 148, with notes.
2. du/skolon, unpleasant, euphe- mistic: cf. § 189.6.
4. w(s e)n...meri/di, looking at them (w(s) in the light of enemies (M.T. 864): cf. § 292.5 and III. 31, e)n u(phre/tou...me/rei.
7. mia=| gnw/mh|, uno consensu.
8. a)mfo/teroi, Thebans and Philip.
9. pro\s tw=| skopei=n...ge/nhsqe, devote yourselves to considering: cf. VIII. 11, pro\s toi=s pra/gmasi gi/gnesqai.
11. do/cein...dialu/sein: sc. e)me/.— to\n...th=| po/lei: for this order of words see §§ 190.2, 197.8, 220.3; and for the common order §§ 179.7, 188.4.
2. metaqe/sqai, to turn about, explained by fobei=sqai u(pe\r *qhbai/wn.

5. *)eleusi=na/de, to the plain of Eleusis, “but no further, lest a friendly demonstration should pass for a menace at Thebes” (Simcox). See note on § 178.3. This was a convenient place for the army to encamp, and they would be within an easy march of Thebes. The mountain road to Thebes by Phyle was more direct, but rougher and with no good camping place.—tou\s e)n h(liki/a|: this term properly included all citizens between 18 and 60: see Arist. Pol. Ath. 42, 4—6 and 34—37. But those between 18 and 20 always remained at home as frouroi/; while those between 50 and 60 were not regularly called into service and served as diaithtai/, or public arbiters (Arist. Pol. Ath. 53, 20—37). Here the 1000 i(ppei=s are excluded from oi( e)n h(liki/a|. See also Lycurg. 39: ai( d' e)lpi/des th=s swthri/as tw=| dh/mw| e)n toi=s u(pe\r penth/konta e)/th gegono/si kaqeisth/kesan, i.e. when the news of the defeat at Chaeronea came, showing that those above fifty were not in the battle.
7. e)c i)/sou, on an equality with Philip's friends.
9. toi=s pwlou=si, to those who would sell (conative): M.T. 25.
12. u(pa/rxeq' e(/toimoi, you are ready at hand.
2. poih=sai...strathgw=n, i.e. to give the envoys (by decree) concurrent authority with the board of generals.

3. po/te...e)kei=se; this question is made a genitive with tou=. The sub
ject of badi/zein is u(ma=s, the Athenian army. The embassy probably departed for Thebes at once, so as to lose no time in securing the confidence of the Thebans; but the army could not march further than Eleusis until it was invited by Thebes to cross her frontier. This was done in due time (§ 215.1), after negotiations at Thebes (§§ 211—214). To facilitate this movement when the summons should come, the people were asked to empower the embassy at Thebes, in concurrence with the generals at Eleusis, to order a march to Thebes at any moment, and to decide all questions about the march itself (th=s e)co/dou).
5. xrh/sasqai tw=| pra/gmati, to manage the (diplomatic) business.

6. tou/tw|...nou=n: this special call for close attention was made to excite the audience with the expectation of hearing just what the embassy was to ask of the Thebans, and to impress them the more by the unexpected answer mh\ dei=sqai *qhbai/wn mhde/n. It was indeed an unheard of thing for an embassy to be sent to a semihostile state in such an emergency, with no demands or even requests, but with an unconditional offer of military help whenever it might be asked for. Aeschines does not fail to misrepresent this noble act of Demosthenes, and to criticise the course of the embassy: see III. 145, to\ bouleuth/rion to\ th=s po/lews kai\ th\n dhmokrati/an a)/rdhn e)/laqen u(felo/menos, kai\ meth/negken ei)s *qh/bas ei)s th\n *kadmei/an.

9. e)n toi=s e)sxa/tois, in extremis. —h(mw=n...proorwme/nwn (also with w(s), on the ground that we foresee (the course of events) better than they (to\ me/llon is omitted with *s): cf. to\ mh\ du/nasqai proora=n, Plat. Theaet. 166 A.

10. i(/n)...w)=men diw|khme/noi, that we may (then) have accomplished what we wish: the perfect subjunctive here and in l. 15 (h)=| pepragme/non) is future-perfect in time, in contrast to the simple future of pra/cwmen and e)gkalw=sin (M.T. 103).

12. prosxh/matos, ground of ac- tion: pro/sxhma is what appears on the outside, which may be either mere show or (as here) an honest exhibition of the truth. Cf. the double meaning of pro/fasis, ground of action or pretext, in § 225.5.—a)\n d' a)/ra, but if after all: cf. § 278.6.
13. katatuxei=n, to succeed (=e)pi- tuxei=n, Hesych.), acc. to Blass is not elsewhere found in classic writers. —au(toi=s e)gkalw=sin, may have themselves to blame.
1. kai\ paraplh/sia: we have here only a single passage of what must have been one of the most eloquent speeches of Demosthenes.

3—5. ou)k ei)=pon me\n...*qhbai/ous: a most famous example of climax (kli=mac, ladder), in which the antitheses of me/n and de/ give a wonderful effect. Each of the three leading negatives (ou)k, ou)d' , ou)d)) introduces a pair of clauses of which the second is negative, and which as a whole it negatives. Thus the first ou)k negatives the compound idea, I spoke, but proposed no measures; then the positive conclusion thus attained, I did propose measures, is taken as an assumption in the next step. Without the help of me/n and de/ the mixture of negatives would have made hopeless confusion. Quintilian (IX. 3, 55) thus translates the passage, skilfully using quidem for me/n and sed for de/: non enim dixi quidem sed non scripsi, nec scripsi quidem sed non obii legationem, nec obii quidem sed non persuasi Thebanis.
7. a(plw=s, without reserve, abso- lutely.—tou\s...kindu/nous: for the order see note on § 176.11.
8. to\ yh/fisma...geno/menon: cf. Aesch. III. 25, pri\n h)\ to\n *(hgh/monos no/mon gene/sqai, and II. 160, poi=on (no/mon) gene/sqai kwlu/sas.
While the clerk is pre- paring to read the decree, the orator amuses the audience by a few jokes at his opponent's expense.

1. kai/toi, and now: cf. § 123.1.— ti/na bou/lei...ei)=nai qw=; whom will you that I shall suppose you, and whom myself, to have been on that day? ei)=nai is imperfect infinitive (=h)=sqa) with qw=, which in this sense takes the infinitive of indirect discourse: cf. Aesch. III. 163, bou/lei se qw= fobhqh=nai; See M.T. 287, 288, with the discussion of Plat. Rep. 372 E.

2. bou/lei e)mauto
: sc. qw= ei)=nai;— o(
 a)
...kale/sais, i.e. as you would call me, etc.
3. *ba/ttalon: this nickname of Demosthenes, which the orator said was given him by his nurse (Aesch. I. 126), probably referred to his lean and sickly look in childhood and youth. See Plut. Dem. 4.
4. mhd' h(/rw to\n tuxo/nta, not even a hero of the common kind: see note on w(=n e)/tuxen, § 130.2.—a)lla\...skhnh=s, but one of those (great) heroes of the stage.

5. *kresfo/nthn, in the Cresphontes of Euripides, in which Merope has the chief part: cf. Arist. Eth. III. 1, 17.—*kre/onta: Aeschines played Creon in the Antigone of Sophocles as tritagwnisth/s: see XIX. 247, e)n a(/pasi toi=s dra/masi toi=s tragikoi=s e)cai/reto/n e)stin w(/sper ge/ras toi=s tritagwnistai=s to\ tou\s tura/nnous kai\ tou\s ta\ skh=ptra e)/xontas ei)sie/nai.

6. *oi)no/maon: i.e. this part in the Oenomaus of Sophocles, which represented the chariot-race of Pelops and Oenomaus, by which Pelops won the hand of Hippodameia. This was the subject of one of the pedimentgroups of the temple of Zeus at Olympia.—kakw=s e)pe/triyas, you wretchedly murdered (as we say of a bad actor). The anonymous Life of Aeschines (7) gives a story that Aeschines fell on the stage in acting this part. As Oenomaus was finally killed, there is probably a double meaning in kakw=s e)pe/triyas.—e)n *kollutw=| is an additional slur on the tragic performance of Aeschines. See Aesch. I. 157, prw/hn e)n toi=s kat' a)grou\s *dionusi/ois kwmw|dw=n o)/ntwn e)n *kollutw=|. See a)rourai=os *oi)no/maos, § 242.5.
7. to/te refers to time generally: kat' e)kei=non to\n kairo\n to a critical moment.
8. *oi)noma/ou tou= *koqwki/dou: Aes- chines was of the deme *koqwki/dai.

§§ 181—187. contain the spurious “decree of Demosthenes.” Its date, the 16th of Scirophorion (June or July), once brought hopeless confusion into the chronology of the campaign before Chaeronea. See Clinton, Fast. Hellen. II. under 338 B.C. The real decree was passed in the autumn or early winter of 339—338 B.C., the year of the Archon Lysimachides. The style of the document is a ridiculous parody of that of Demosthenes (see § 182). Lord Brougham's remarks on this document, written of course in full faith in its genuineness, are now interesting. He says (p. 181): “The style of this piece is full of dignity, and the diction perfectly simple as well as chaste, with the solemnity of a state paper, but without the wordiness or technicality.”

1. au(/th...prw/th, this was the first step taken and the first settlement effected in our relations with Thebes: e)gi/gneto refers to the progress of the business in coming to a settlement. See Weil's note: “kata/stasis est ici le contraire de taraxh/.” Cf. XX. 11, e)peidh\ d' h( po/lis ei)s e(\n h)=lqe kai\ ta\ pra/gmat) e)kei=na kate/sth (after the rule of the Thirty), and Ar. Ran. 1003, h(ni/k' a)\n to\ pneu=ma lei=on kai\ kaqesthko\s la/bh|s.

5. parelqei=n w(/sper ne/fos, to pass by like a cloud, or to vanish like a passing cloud. The simplicity of this simile was much admired by the Greek rhetoricians, who quote it nine times (see Spengel's index). See Longinus on the Sublime, 39, 4: u(yhlo/n ge tou=to dokei= no/hma, kai\ e)/sti tw=| o)/nti
qauma/sion, o(\ tw=| yhfi/smati o( *dhmosqe/nhs e)pife/rei...a)ll' au)th=s th=s dianoi/as ou)k e)/latton th=| a(rmoni/a| pefw/nhtai. He then discourses on the fatal effect which would result from a change in the order of the words, or from the omission or addition of a single syllable (as w(s ne/fos or w(/sper ei) ne/fos).
7. tou/twn, i.e. than my measures.

In the last sentence of § 188, the orator suddenly breaks off his narrative, and digresses into a most eloquent defence of the policy of Athens in resisting Philip, and of his own conduct as her responsible leader. See note before §§ 160—226.

1. su/mboulos, statesman. —sukofa/nths: no modern word, least of all the English sycophant, gives the full meaning of this expressive term, though the same combination of malicious informer, dirty pettifogger, common slanderer and backbiter, is unhappily still to be seen. Cf. § 242.2. The word must have referred originally to the petty form of prosecution for violation of the revenue laws known as fa/sis, in which half of the penalty went to the informer. See Ar. Eq. 300: kai/ se fai/nw toi=s pruta/nesin a)dekateu/tous tw=n qew=n i(ra\s e)/xonta koili/as.
4. u(peu/qunon, responsible in the full Attic sense, e.g. liable to the eu)/qunai and to the grafh\ parano/mwn.
6. du/skolon: see note on § 176.2.
7. baskai/nei, reviles: Harpocr. a)nti\ tou= ai)tia=tai kai\ me/mfetai kai\ sukofantei=: *dhmosq. e)n tw=| u(pe\r *kthsifw=ntos.
1. o(/per ei)=pon: see the last sentence of § 188.
3. tw=n dik. lo/gwn: with kairo\s (West., Bl.), or (better) with fronti/zontos.—tosau/thn u(perbolh\n poiou=mai, i.e. I go so far beyond what could be asked of me.

5. e)nh=n: used personally with ti a)/llo: cf. o(/sa e)nh=n, § 193.4. So e)no/ntwn (11): such participles are very often personal (M.T. 761).— w(=n e)gw\ proeilo/mhn: cf. § 192.5, th\n proai/resi/n mou th=s politei/as.
6. a)dikei=n, in its so-called perfect sense (M.T. 27).

7. to/te praxqe\n=ei) to/t' e)pra/xqh.
—tou=t)...dei=n e)me\ mh\ laqei=n, I say this ought not to have escaped me (at the time): dei=n...laqei=n represents e)/dei e)me\ mh\ laqei=n.

8, 9. ei) de\...th/meron: for this com- pound protasis with a present, a past, and a potential optative united in one supposition, see M.T. 509: notice the three negatives and the emphatic kai\ in mh/t' a)\n...th/meron. See § 141.5.— mhde/pw kai\ th/meron, not yet, even at this day.
10. tw=n fainome/nwn kai\ e)no/ntwn, of the plans which offered themselves to us and were feasible.
3. ti/s...parelhluqo/twn; a question to be addressed to a sukofa/nths, not to a su/mboulos.
7. ou) to/te: sc. e)/deicas.—a)lla\ nu=n (M.T. 513).
8. eu)porei=n (*s, eu(rei=n vulg.), to have been provided with.
9. th=| po/lei: often taken with sumfe/rwn; better with parelei/fqh, as in § 107.11, a)pw/leto th=| po/lei.
10. ma=llon, rather than to my own.
2. a)fei=tai (gnomic), is dismissed from consideration.
3. th\n...ta/cin, i.e. the statesman at his post: ta/cin keeps up the military figure of § 173.5,6.

4. to/te...parh=n: application of the general principle to the case in hand; ta\ me\n h)/mellen referring to Chaeronea and its results, ta\ d' h)/dh parh=n to Philip's presence at Elatea. Though these are now past, they were then future and present.

5. th\n...politei/as: see note on § 190.5. proai/resis implies the deliberate choice of a policy which a statesman should make: here and in ta\ sumba/nta sukofa/ntei we have again the su/mboulos and the sukofa/nths contrasted. For the precise meaning of proai/resis, see Arist. Eth. III. 2 (especially § 17): a)ll' a)=ra/ ge to\ probebouleume/non (sc. to\ proaireto/n); h( ga\r proai/resis meta\ lo/gou kai\ dianoi/as. u(poshmai/nein d' e)/oike kai\ tou)/noma w(s o)\n pro\ e(te/rou ai(reto/n.
9. au)th\ (emphatic): the thought is, purpose is the very thing which shows etc.
3. th=| ma/xh|: Chaeronea. —e)n tw=| qew=|...te/los: cf. pe/ras and dai/mwn in § 192.7, 8. See Il. VII. 101, au)ta\r u(/perqen ni/khs pei/rat' e)/xontai e)n a)qana/toisi qeoi=sin.
6. filopo/nws u(pe\r du/namin, i.e. with greater labour than my strength warranted: cf. §§ 160.5, 218.9.

8. e)nesthsa/mhn, undertook (in- stituted): cf. § 4.11.—kai\ a)nagkai=a, and necessary too, added after the verb for emphasis. Blass remarks that the orator has not yet attained the height from which he speaks in §§ 199 ff.

1. skhpto\s [h)\ xeimw
]: most recent editors omit h)\ xeimw
 on the ground that the orator, after comparing the sudden raid of Philip to a thunderbolt, would not weaken his figure by adding a common storm. This holds good even when we admit that xeimw/n and skhpto/s are not the same thing. Aristotle (de Mundo, 4, 19), after describing kerauno/s, prhsth/r, and tufw=n, adds e(/kaston de\ tou/twn kataskh=yan ei)s th
 gh=n skhpto\s o)noma/zetai. skhpto/s, therefore, is not only a stroke of lightning, but also a furious thunderstorm; while xeimw/n is winter, a winterstorm, or a storm in general. Perhaps h)\ xeimw
 here was originally a marginal reference to xeimw=ni xrhsa/menon (6).

3. ti/ xrh\ poiei=n (sc. h(ma=s), what ought we to do? The answer is given in the two following sentences. The sense is: “What are we to do? We
are to do just what a nau/klhros would do if any one were to blame him, etc. He would say ‘I was not kubernh/ths,’ just as I can say ‘No more was I strathgo/s.’” The apodosis to ei)/ tis... ai)tiw=|to being suppressed (except a)
 in 4), its subject nau/klhros appears in the protasis as nau/klhron, and the implied w(/sper a)
 nau/klhros poih/seien appears in fh/seien a)
 (9) with its quotation, a)ll' ou)/t) e)kube/rnwn...tw=n pa/ntwn. h(mw=n (2) and e)gw\ (10) show that the orator identifies the people with himself in the comparison with nau/klhros. Cf. § 243.

4. nau/klhron, properly a ship- owner, who sails in his own ship (as e)/mporos), but generally employs a kubernh/ths or sailing-master to navigate the ship. In Plato's famous figure of the ship of State (Rep. VI. p. 488), the nau/klhros is the honest old man *dh=mos *pukni/ths, who knows little of navigation, and is not skilful enough to keep a professional sailingmaster in authority, and soon lets the command of the ship fall into the hands of the most artful and unscrupulous landsmen on board.
6. xeimw=ni xrhsa/menon: the nau/- klhros is said to have met with a storm.—ponhsa/ntwn skeuw=n, when his tackling laboured (as we speak of a ship as labouring in a heavy sea).

3. ti/ xrh=n prosdoka=n; this apodosis (like the similar one in lines 7—9) has two protases, one simply past, the other past with the condition unfulfilled. Each apodosis conforms to the latter condition. But we have in line 3 ti/ xrh=n prosdoka=n; (without a)/n), but in 7—9 ti/ a)\n...prosdokh=sai xrh=n; the two sentences being otherwise similar. We certainly should not notice the difference if the same form (either with or without a)/n) were used in both. And yet the distinction is one of principle, and is generally obvious and important. In the form without a)/n the chief force falls on the infinitive, while in the form with a)/n it falls on e)/dei, e)ch=n, xrh=n, etc., to which the a)/n belongs. Thus e)ch=n soi e)lqei=n (in this sense) is you might have gone (but did not go), while e)ch=n a)/n soi e)lqei=n is it would have been possible for you to go in a certain case (but in fact it was not possible). Here we may translate ti/ xrh=n prosdoka=n; what ought we to have expected (which we did not find ourselves expecting)? and ti/ a)\n prosdokh=sai xrh=n; what should we then have had to expect
(which in fact we did not have to expect)? See M.T. App. v.

5. pa/sas a)fh=ke fwna/s, i.e. used all his eloquence: cf. Plat. Rep. 475 A, pa/sas fwna\s a)fi/ete. See § 218.5.— triw=n h(merw=n o(do\n, three days' journey, i.e. from Chaeronea (via Thebes) to the Attic frontier at Eleutherae, about 450 stadia. It was about 250 stadia from Eleutherae to Athens; and the whole distance from Chaeronea to Athens is given (§ 230.2) as 700 stadia, about 80 miles. (See Blass.)

9. nu=n here and to/te in l. 11 refer only to opposite alternatives (as it was, and in that case), but to the same time. See § 200.1. The a)posiw/phsis after to/te de\ is far more eloquent than any description.
10. a)napneu=sai: cf. Il. XI. 801, o)li/gh de/ t' a)na/pneusis pole/moio.

12. a(/ ge mhde\ pei=ran e)/dwke, which never gave us even a trial (of their horrors): e(autw=n is omitted, leaving pei=ran e)/dwke absolute. See note on § 107.5. The negative is mhde\ because the antecedent of a(\ is indefinite (M.T. 518).

13. tw=| proba/llesqai ... summa- xi/an, by the state having this alliance to shield her (lit. holding it before herself). Cf. § 97.10. The present emphasizes the continued protection; probale/sqai would mean putting it before herself: cf. § 300.1, tau=ta prou)balo/mhn pro\ th=s *)attikh=s.

1. e)/sti moi pro\s u(ma=s, i.e. I intend it for you.—tauti\ pa/nta ta\ polla\, all this long argument (so West.): ta\ polla\ may, however, be adverbial, for the most part, chiefly, the sense being all this I intend chiefly for you.

2. tou\s periesthko/tas, the spec- tators, of whom great crowds were present: see Aesch. III. 56, e)nanti/on... tw=n a)/llwn politw=n o(/soi dh\ e)/cwqen periesta=si, kai\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn o(/sois e)pimele\s ge/gonen e)pakou/ein th=sde th=s kri/sews: o(rw= de\ ou)k o)li/gous paro/ntas, a)ll' o(/sous ou)dei\s pw/pote me/mnhtai pro\s a)gw=na dhmo/sion paragenome/nous.

4. braxu\s kai\ safh\s lo/gos: this he now puts into a dilemma, ei) me
 h)=n soi\ pro/dhla and ei) de\ mh\ proh/|deis: e)ch/rkei, was enough for him; i.e.
this would be a sufficient reply for him. e)ch/rkei sometimes has a force somewhat like that of di/kaion h)=n, i)/son h)=n, kalo
 h)=n, etc., when they are classed with e)/dei, xrh=n, etc. (M.T. 416). See Cic. Lael. XXVI. 96, satis erat respondere Magnas: Ingentes inquit, and Lane's Latin Grammar, 1496, 1497. Cf. qaumasto
 h)=n, § 248.7.
8. tau=ta: the charge of ignorance which you bring against me.
2. tau=q' a(\ le/gw, i.e. the events which preceded Chaeronea.
4. ta\ pa=si dokou=nta=a(\ pa=sin e)do/kei, with reference to votes of the people: cf. 274.5.
5. i)/dion personal, e.g. the danger of a grafh\ parano/mwn: cf. §§ 235.11, 249.
6. ou)...e)xrw=nto: sc. ei) e(/ter' ei)=pes belti/w.
7. ei)s tau=ta, in support of my measures.
8. o(/per d' a)\n: sc. poih/seien or e)poi/hsen. See § 291.4.
9. th=| po/lei: for the order see § 176.11.—pepoihkw\s...e)ch/tasai, you are shown to have done after the events: cf. Hdt. I. 170, e)pi\ diefqarme/noisi *)/iwsi, and § 284.10.

10. *)ari/stratos, *)aristo/lews: these men and the condition of Naxos and Thasos at this time are known only from this passage. It appears that these islands were in the power of Alexander, and that his great successes in Asia were having the same effect in them as in Athens, encouraging the Macedonian party to vex their opponents by prosecutions.
11. kaqa/pac e)xqroi\, outright en- emies.
12. kai\ *)aqh/nhsin...kathgorei=: this brings out clearly the meaning of tou=to pepoihkw\s (9).
1. o(/tw|...a)pe/keito, who found matter for glorification in the calamities of the Greeks: a)pe/keito, were laid up (as material).

2. e)neudokimei=n occurs only here in classic Greek, acc. to Blass, who remarks on the ease with which such compounds with e)n are made, to be used thus in the infinitive: see Thuc. II. 44, e)neudaimonh=sai and e)nteleuth=sai; II. 20, e)nstratopedeu=sai; Hdt. II. 178, e)noikh=sai; VI. 102, e)nippeu=sai; Plat. Phaedr. 228 E, e)mmeleta=n.—*(ellh/nwn ...a)pe/keito is a dactylic hexameter.
4. oi( au)toi\...e)xqroi=s, i.e. the same occasions in which also the enemies of the state have found their advantage.
5. eu)/noun, loyal: see note on § 1.2.
6. e)c w(=n zh=|s, by the life you live: cf. a)p' au)tw=n w(=n bebi/wken § 130.1. zh=n is the regular present to bebiwke/nai, biw= not being in common use.

7—10. pra/ttetai...*ai)sxi/nhs and a)nte/krouse...*ai)sxi/nhs: two paratactic conditional expressions,—suppose something is done, etc. See § 274. Dissen quotes Cicero's imitation (Phil. II. 22, 55): Doletis tres exercitus populi Romani interfectos: interfecit Antonius. Desideratis clarissimos cives: eos quoque nobis eripuit Antonius. Auctoritas huius ordinis afflicta est: afflixit Antonius.

10. r(h/gmata kai\ spa/smata, rup- tures and strains: r(h=gma is a rupture, either of the flesh or of a vein; spa/sma is properly the state of tension which may lead to a rupture, though the two terms seem sometimes to be used in nearly or quite the same sense. See Hippocrates, de Flatibus 11 (Littré VI. p. 109), of ruptures of the flesh; and de Morb. I. 20 (Litt. VI. p. 176), of the veins. See large edition.
1. polu\s e)/gkeitai, is severe (presses hard) upon: cf. Thuc. IV. 22, Hdt. VII. 158, and note on pollw=| r(e/onti in § 136.7 (above).

2. ti kai\ para/docon: the orator now rises to a new height. Heretofore he has maintained vigorously (as in § 194) that the policy of Athens in opposing Philip under his lead was sound and hopeful, and that he cannot justly be censured now, even if events have shown the “mistake” of waging war against the Macedonian power. He now suddenly changes his ground.
He declares that there has been no “mistake,” that no other policy was possible for Athens with her glorious antecedents, even if the whole future, with Chaeronea and its baneful consequences, had been foreseen from the beginning. This is the final answer to the petty criticisms of Aeschines “after the events” (e)pi\ toi=s sumba=sin, § 197.9).
6. kai\ su\ prou)/leges: the figure of Aeschines himself joining in the general warning adds greatly to the picture.
7. o(\s ou)d' e)fqe/gcw, you who did not even open your mouth.—ou)d' ou(/tws, not even then: ou(/tws sums up in one word the whole of the preceding condition (4—7).
8. a)postate/on...h)=n=e)/dei th\n po/lin a)posth=nai.
9. tou= me/llontos ai)w=nos, future ages.
1, 4. nu=n me\n...to/te d): see note on § 195.9.
2. a)potuxei=n, to have failed (in securing).—tw=n pragma/twn, mere material objects, opposed to the high principles which would have been sacrificed in the other case (to/te).
4. a)ciou=sa (imperf.), while she had claimed, followed by the aorist a)posta=sa, and then withdrew, both past to e)/sxen a)/n. We might have had h)ci/ou and a)pe/sth: cf. XV. 27, w(=n a)pe/sth.
6. a)koniti\, without a struggle, sine pulvere; cf. XIX. 77.
7. ou)de/na o(/ntin' ou)x, emphatic equivalent of pa/nta: the natural nominative ou)dei\s o(/stis ou) (=pa=s) is illogically declined.
8. sou= (accented), with special emphasis.—mh\ ga\r (sc. ei)pe/), don't say the state, or me: po/lews and e)mou= merely continue the case of sou=.
1. ti/si d)...e(wrw=men a)\n; i.e. how should we now (dare to) look in the face, etc.?

2—8. ei) ta\ me
...h(|rhme/nhs: this elaborate protasis has three divisions;
(1) ei) ta\ me/n...a(pa/ntwn, (2) to
 de\... pepoihme/noi, (3) kai\ tau=ta...h(|rhme/nhs. The clause h(gemw
 de\...a(pa/ntwn belongs closely with the preceding ei) me
 perie/sth, and to
 d) (not h(gemw
 de\) corresponds to ta\ me
.
3. ei)s o(/per nuni\, to the present state, explained by h(gemw\n de\...a(pa/ntwn.
4. to\n...a)gw=na, the fight to prevent this.

5. e(/teroi xwri\s h(mw=n: this pathetic picture of Athens sitting still and seeing others fight the battle for Grecian liberty becomes more effective when we remember (what Demosthenes never forgot) that Greece at this crisis had no state except Athens able or willing to take the lead, or any important part, in such a struggle. See §§ 304, 305.
6. kai\ tau=ta, and this too, intro- ducing the participial clause which completes the supposition: hence mhdepw/pote.
1, 2. ti/s...barba/rwn: cf. XIX. 312.—para\ *qhbai/wn: in the time of Epaminondas.
3. para\...*lakedaimoni/wn: after the Peloponnesian war, and before Leuctra.

4. para\...basile/ws, from Xerxes: see the order given to Mardonius before the battle of Plataea, reported to Athens by Alexander, king of Macedonia (Hdt. VIII. 140): tou=to me
 th
 gh=n sfi a)po/dos, tou=to de\ a)/llhn pro\s tau/th| e(le/sqwn au)toi\, h(/ntina a)
 e)qe/lwsi, e)o/ntes au)to/nomoi. See note on 204.5 (end).
6. o(/ ti bou/letai...proesta/nai: i.e. to keep her own and receive anything she wanted, on condition of being subject to Persia.
1. w(s e)/oike, spoken with sarcasm: cf. § 212.5.
2. pa/tria, i.e. inherited from their ancestors.—ou)d' a)nekta\ implies that they revolted morally against the idea; ou)d' e)/mfuta that it was against their nature as Athenians.

3. e)k panto\s tou= xro/nou, from
the beginning of time, a rhetorical u(perbolh/, as in § 66.6; in § 26.7 it means from the beginning of the transaction in question.
4. mh\ di/kaia: mh\, not ou), as we should say oi(\ mh\ di/kaia pra/ttousin (G. 1612).
5. prosqeme/nhn, taking the side of, attaching herself to: cf. § 227.5.— a)sfalw=s douleu/ein: the same idea of security in slavery is found in the speech of Pericles, Thuc. II. 63 (end).
6. a)gwnizome/nh, as partic. of man- ner modifies kinduneu/ousa diatete/leke. —prwtei/wn, timh=s, do/chs: cf. § 66.7.
2. h)/qesin, moral feelings: see note on § 114.2.
4. a)ga/saito: an epic aorist (see Blass).

5. po/lin e)klipei=n refers to the time before the battle of Salamis when, by the advice of Themistocles, Athens was abandoned to Xerxes, and all was staked on a sea-fight: so VI. 11. See Cicero, Offic. III. 11, 48: Cyrsilum quendam, suadentem ut in urbe manerent Xerxemque reciperent, lapidibus obruerunt. Herodotus, IX. 5, tells a similar story of the stoning of a senator named Lycidas, with his wife and children, before the battle of Plataea, when Mardonius sent his second message to Athens (for the earlier message see note on § 202.4).
6. u(pe\r tou= mh\...poih=sai: u(pe\r with the gen. of the infin. for a final clause, as in § 205.9, and in Aesch. III. 1, u(pe\r tou=...mh\ gi/gnesqai.
8. to\n u(pakou/ein a)pofhna/menon, who declared himself for obedience: cf. gnw/mhn a)pofai/netai, § 189.4.
10. kataliqw/santes: acc. to Bl., the only Attic example of kataliqo/w for kataleu/w.
11. ai( gunai=kes...au)tou=: the vivid- ness of the picture in the easy flowing narrative is heightened by the irregular insertion of a new subject, ai( gunai=kes, as if without premeditation.
With this and § 205 compare the speech of the Athenian envoy at Sparta more than a century earlier, Thuc. I. 73—75.
3. di) o(/tou douleu/sousin<*> final relative (M.T. 565). With douleu/sousin eu)tuxw=s (sarcastic) cf. a)sfalw=s douleu/ein, § 203.5.
4. ei) mh\ e)ce/stai, if they could not (were not to be able): ei) mh\ e)ce/soito might be used (M.T. 694, 695).

5. ou)xi\...gegenh=sqai: cf. Plat. Crit. 50 D—51 B; and Arist. Eth. I. 7, 6, to\ d' au)/tarkes le/gomen ou)k au)tw=| mo/nw| tw=| zw=nti bi/on monw/thn, a)lla\ (sc. tw=| zw=nti) kai\ goneu=si kai\ te/knois k.t.l., where au)tw=| mo/nw| and goneu=si both depend on zw=nti (living for himself alone, and living also for parents etc.), as patri\, mhtri\, and goneu=si in Demosthenes depend on gegenh=sqai. The passage of Aristotle is sometimes called ungrammatical!

8. to\n th=s ei(marme/nhs qa/naton, the death of Fate, i.e. death at an appointed time,—opposed to voluntary death, as when one gives his life for his country (cf. a)poqnh/|skein e)qelh/sei, 10): to\n au)to/maton qa/n. is natural (opposed to violent) death. The two are really the same, from different points of view. See West., with Aulus Gellius, XIII. 1, and Cicero, Phil. I. 4, 10.
9. kai\ th=| patri/di: sc. gegenh=sqai nomi/zwn.—u(pe\r tou=...e)pidei=n: cf. § 204.6.
10. douleu/ousan, in a state of slavery: see M.T. 885, 148. With the pres. partic. cf. mh/ m' i)dei=n qano/nq), not to see me killed, Eur. Orest. 746.

§§ 206—310. conclude the digres- sion which begins in § 188. The orator here appeals to the judges not to convict Ctesiphon, as this will be a condemnation of the people of Athens for maintaining the ancient glories of the state, the glories of Marathon and Salamis.

1—3. ei)...e)pexei/roun... e)pitimh/seie/ moi: this combination of a present unreal condition, if I were undertaking, with a future conclusion, everybody would justly censure me, is rare, and perhaps strictly illogical (M.T. 504). We should expect an imperfect with a)/n in the apodosis; and this is implied in the condensed form which we have. The real meaning is, if I were (now) undertaking to tell you this, the result would be (h)=n a)/n) that all would justly censure me.
4. u(mete/ras: sc. ou)/sas.

6. diakoni/as, i.e. what he terms the menial service is all that he claims for himself. This is in striking contrast with his claim for full recognition of his public services elsewhere: cf. §§ 297—300. But in this grand glorification of Athens and her noble services to freedom, the more he depreciates himself and exalts the state, the stronger does he make his argument that the condemnation of Ctesiphon now would be a condemnation of Athens herself and of all her glorious history.

Notice the antitheses in this pas- sage:—first, the main one, ei) me\n and nu=n de\ (§ 206.1, 3); then, within the latter, e)gw\ me\n and ou(=tos de\ (§ 207.1); also u(mete/ras and kai\ e)mautw=|, proaire/seis and diakoni/as.
1. tw=n o(/lwn: opposed to th=s e)f' e(ka/stois (diakoni/as), § 206.6.
3. th=s ei)s to\ paro\n timh=s: the crown.
4. ta\...e)gkw/mi): i.e. your past glories will be lost for all future time if they are condemned by your vote to-day.
5. a)fairei=tai is conative: cf. § 13.1.
6. toudi\, Ctesiphon, like toutoni\ in § 15.6.
7. a)gnwmosu/nh|, harshness (want of feeling): cf. § 252.1. a)gnwmonw= may mean to be thoughtless or inconsiderate: cf. §§ 94.2, 248.7. ta\ sumba/nta, what befell you, including Chaeronea.

The famous oath by the heroes of Marathon, Plataea, Salamis, and Artemisium here follows. The grandeur of this solemn invocation of the shades of the mighty dead, to support the orator in his last and noblest assertion of the true spirit of Athenian liberty, will strike the most indifferent reader. We do not envy one who is strong enough to read this passage without emotion. Lord Brougham says: “The whole passage, which ends here, and begins ei) ga\r tau=ta proei=to a)koniti/ (§ 200), is deserving of close study, being one of the greatest pieces of declamation on record in any tongue.” See Longinus
on the Sublime 16: a)po/deizin o( *dhmosqe/nhs u(pe\r tw=n pepoliteume/nwn ei)sfe/rei:...“ou)x h(ma/rtete, w)= to\n u(pe\r th=s *(ellh/nwn e)leuqeri/as a)gw=na a)ra/menoi: e)/xete de\ oi)kei=a tou/tou paradei/gmata: ou)de\ ga\r oi( e)n *maraqw=ni h(/marton ou)d' oi( e)n *salami=ni k.t.l.”
1, 2. ou)k e)/stin...h(ma/rtete, it can- not be that ye erred: ou)k e)/stin o(/pws= ou)damw=s.

3. a)ra/menoi: cf. po/lemon a)/rasqai, v. 5.—ma\ tou\s: most MSS. prefix ou), which *s omits, ma/ generally implying a negation.—tou\s...progo/nwn (those of) our ancestors who bore the brunt of battle at Marathon: prokinduneu/w is here stand forward (as pro/maxos) to face the foe; from its idea of contending it may take a dative like ma/xomai, as in Thuc. I. 73, fame\n ga\r *maraqw=ni mo/noi prokinduneu=sai tw=| barba/rw|, a passage which may have suggested prokinduneu/santas to Demosthenes here.

4. *maraqw=ni: as the name of an Attic deme, this is usually a locative dative: but here all MSS. except *s, and most quotations, prefix e)n, which is regular with *plataiai=s and *salami=ni (G. 1197).
5. e)n *salami=ni: this battle was fought at Salamis; the other sea-fight was off (e)p)) Artemisium.

7. dhmosi/ois mnh/masi: the public tombs were in the outer Ceramicus, on the road leading to the Academy: see Paus. I. 29, Thuc. II. 34. Those who fell at Marathon were buried on the battlefield, as a special honour.
8. a)gaqou\s a)/ndras, in apposition with the preceding accusatives: this was by no means a weak term of praise with Demosthenes: cf. l. 11. —o(moi/ws and th=s au)th=s mutually strengthen each other.

10. au)tw=n: I adopt this partitive gen. rather than au)tou/s (found in *s, L.1), as I am not convinced that au)tou/s can have the force of especially (distinguished from others), ipsos solos (Rauchenstein). In defence of English, we may note that this renowned passage has no less than fifty sigmas in sixty-seven words.
The descent from the im- passioned patriotic eloquence of the preceding passage to the personal vituperation of this is depressing.
2. grammatoku/fwn: a)nti\ tou= grammate/ws, o(/ti oi( grammatei=s prokekufo/tes gra/fousin (Etym. Magn.).
4. tro/paia...e)/leges: see Aesch. 181.
6. tritagwnista\: effectively chos- en with reference to prwtei/wn, which refers to Athens as competitor for the first prize in the political a)gw/n, in which Demosthenes is her adviser.
7. to\ ti/nos fro/nhma labo/nt), in- spired by whose spirit?
2. dikai/ws me/nta)\n a)pe/- qanon, but (in that case) I should have deserved to die. me/nta)\n by crasis for me/ntoi a)/n.—ou)d) u(ma=s...dei=, neither should you (any more than I).
3. dianoi/as, spirit (way of think- ing).

4. i)di/as, dhmosi/as: this has no reference to the ordinary distinction of grafai/ and di/kai, public and private suits, which correspond generally to our criminal and civil processes. Here di/kh has its widest legal sense of lawsuit in general, including both grafh/ and di/kh (in its narrower sense). i)/diai di/kai are suits which concern individuals and their ordinary business relations (sumbo/laia), which of course must be judged with reference to special statutes (e)pi\ i)di/wn no/mwn, cf. e)p' a)lhqei/as, § 22.1), which may change from year to year, and to special facts (i)di/wn e)/rgwn), without regard to the general policy or the traditions of the state: even criminal suits (grafai/) which involve nothing more than the acts of individuals would be included here. But dhmo/siai di/kai are suits like the present one, which involve a judgment on the general policy of statesmen (koina\s proaire/seis), whose acts are not prescribed by special statutes, but must be governed to a great extent by general principles and traditions of state: these, the orator says, must be judged by reference to the glorious deeds of the past. Demosthenes insists here, as elsewhere, that the only real question involved in this case is that of his own statesmanship and his fidelity to the best traditions of Athens, while Aeschines constantly urges the court to treat it as a common i)di/a di/kh and settle it by reference to ordinary facts and petty details. (See Aesch. 199, 200.) Aeschines saw that here lay his only chance of success in his suit.

8. th=| bakthri/a| kai\ tw=| sumbo/lw|, his staff and his ticket: each judge received in the morning a staff painted with the same colour as the lintel (sfhni/skos) of the court house in which he was to sit; after entering the court, he gave up his staff to an officer, and received a ticket (su/mbolon), which entitled him to receive his fee of three obols (dikastiko/n) after his day's service.
He now returns to the account of the embassy to Thebes, from which he digressed in § 188.
5. a)fiko/meq): i.e. the ambassadors.

6. *fili/ppou...pre/sbeis: see Plut. Dem. 18, and Philoch. frag. 135, *fili/ppou de\ katalabo/ntos *)ela/teian kai\ *kuti/nion, kai\ pre/sbeis pe/myantos ei)s *qh/bas *qettalw=n, *ai)nianw=n, *ai)twlw=n, *dolo/pwn, *fqiwtw=n: *)aqhnai/wn de\ kata\ to\n au)to\n xro/non pre/sbeis a)posteila/ntwn tou\s peri\ *dhmosqe/nh, tou/tois summaxei=n e)yhfi/santo.
8. o(/ti...le/gw is connected with le/ge (9) by a suppressed phrase like to show. See Krüger, Gr. Gr. 65, 1, Anm. 6.
10. h(\n to/t' e)pe/myamen: opposed to nu=n le/gw (8).
These words were spoken while the clerk was preparing to read the letter: cf. § 180.
2. to\n kairo\n: see Aesch. 137— 141 and 237—239; esp. o( d' ei)sa/gwn h)=n u(ma=s ei)s ta\s *qh/bas kairo\s kai\ fo/bos kai\ xrei/a summaxi/as, a)ll) ou) *dhmosqe/nhs (141).
3. w(s e(te/rws: see note on § 85.6.
4. tu/xhn: see Aesch. 157.
7. sunai/tios, partner, opposed to mo/nos ai)/tios (9).—tw=n...a)tuxhqe/ntwn =a(\ h)tuxh/samen.
1. th\n e)kklhsi/an: i.e. at Thebes. The narrative is continued from § 211.8.
2. tw=n summa/xwn: i.e. of Thebes.
6. to\ kefa/laion, adverbial, in short.
7. w(=n me\n eu)= pepo/nqesan, for the benefits they had received, eu)= pa/sxein as passive of eu)= poiei=n: this corresponds to w(=n d' h)di/khnto (8).
8. au)tou\s: the Thebans, while au(tou\s in 9 refers to the Macedonians.

9. o(pote/rws bou/lontai, in which- ever way they pleased, in the mood and tense of the direct form, the exhortation being take vengeance in whichever way you please.—die/ntas au(tou\s, i.e. by letting them pass through Boeotia into Attica (cf. § 146.4). The aorists die/ntas and sunembalo/ntas have the better authority here: when an aor. partic. denotes that in which the action of a verb (usually aorist) consists, so that they really designate one act, the two may coincide in time, as in Plat. Phaed. 60 C, eu)= g' e)poi/hsas a)namnh/sas me, you did well to remind me. (See M.T. 150, with the examples.)
11. e)k me\n...sunebou/leuon, as a consequence of following their advice, opposed to e)k d' w(=n h(ma=s e)rei=n e)/fasan in l. 13.
1. a(\ d' h(mei=s: sc. e)le/gomen.

2. ta\ me
 kaq' e(/kasta, the details, with the subordinate e)gw\ me
 and u(ma=s de\, is in antithesis to o(/ ti d' ou)=n e)pei/samen (i.e. the sum of what we accom -plished) in l. 6.—a)nti\...tou= bi/ou, as we might say, I would give my life: cf. tima=n and tima=sqai used of estimating the penalty in a lawsuit; and I. 1, a)nti\ pollw=n a)
 xrhma/twn e(le/sqai. It is not hard to see why Demosthenes should be unwilling to repeat any part of this brilliant speech. The hope of successes of the allies against Philip, which he probably held out, had been disappointed by the crushing defeat at Chaeronea; and the destruction of Thebes three years later must have made the whole tone of this speech now sadly untimely. Plutarch (Dem. 18) gives a graphic account of the Theban assembly and of the address, which was probably one of the orator's greatest efforts.

4. w(/sper a)
 ei)...h(gou/menoi, as (you would think, e)nomi/zete a)/n) if you believed, etc. (M.T. 227, 868). Strictly we should have either w(/sper a)
 ei) h(gei=sqe (impf.) or w(/sper a)
 h(gou/menoi (=ei) h(gei=sqe), since a conditional participle is not regularly preceded by ei) (M.T. 472). But it would seem that the colloquial use of w(/sper a)
 ei), quasi, sometimes caused the true ellipsis to be overlooked and the ei) to be irregularly added.—kai\ kataklusmo
