; i.e. also a deluge, as well as the lapse of opportunity (parelhluqo/twn tw=n kairw=n).
5. tw=n pragma/twn, objective geni- tive after kataklusmo\n.
6. o(/ ti e)pei/samen and (o(/ ti)...a)pe- kri/nanto are the same thing.

1. e)ka/loun u(ma=s, i.e. called your army to Thebes. This is what Demosthenes provided for in § 178.2-4 (see notes), when he proposed to give the embassy concurrent power with the generals over the movements of the army. This march to Thebes, after the answer of the Thebans had been sent to Athens (meta\ tau=ta), is commonly thought to be directly opposed to the account of Aeschines in III. 140: Dissen exclaims indignantly, “Haeccine manifesta mendacia
potuisse coram judicibus dici!” But Aeschines says only that the march to Thebes took place pri
 peri\ summaxi/as mi/an mo/nhn sullabh
 gra/yai *dhmosqe/nhn. Now that the “decree of Demosthenes” (181—187) is known to be a forgery, we have no reason for thinking that any formal treaty of alliance preceded the invitation of the Athenian army to Thebes. Demosthenes could have proposed such a treaty only after his return to Athens. It appears from the criticisms of Aeschines on the treaty (141—144) that it was an elaborate document; and it is probable that it was not made and ratified until some time after the march to Thebes, which required no further legislation than the decree appointing the ambassadors. It must be remembered that Demosthenes (§ 178) proposed that the embassy should simply offer the Athenian army to Thebes without insisting on any formal terms, e)pagge/llesqai bohqh/sein a)
 keleu/wsin.

3. e)/cw...o)/ntwn: this is commonly referred to the Athenian army, who are supposed to have first encamped outside the city and afterwards to have been invited to enter Thebes and occupy the houses. It is surely far more natural and agrees better with the context to understand that, while the Theban infantry and cavalry (i.e. the whole army) were encamped outside the walls, the Athenian army was quartered in the town. The lack of a pronoun to designate which army is meant is felt in both interpretations; but as the subject is the Thebans, it is more natural to refer the absolute clause to them. Again, the emphasis given twice to pai=das kai\ gunai=kas (5 and 13) implies that the men were absent; and e)f' u(mi=n poih/santes (13), as a testimony to the swfrosu/nh of the Athenians, implies this still more strongly.

7. kaq' u(mw=n, upon you, as in VI. 9, kaq' u(mw=n e)gkw/mion, not in its common hostile sense. See Arist. Pol. III. 13, 14, kata\ de\ toiou/twn ou)k e)/sti no/mos, au)toi\ ga/r ei)si no/mos, in respect to such men there is no law, for they are a law unto themselves. In the parallel passage of St Paul, Gal. v. 23, kata\ tw=n toiou/twn is translated against such. See Rom. ii. 14, e(autoi=s ei)si no/mos, where we have the rest of the passage of Aristotle.
11. dikaio/ter' a)ciou=n, that you made juster claims on them.
12. kai\ para\ pa=si d), and indeed (kai\) with all mankind, parenthetically after par' au)toi=s.
14. e)/xontes: or. obl. with e)/deican.

2. o)rqw=s e)fa/nhsan e)gnw- ko/tes, it appeared (later) that they had judged rightly (e)gnw/kasin): cf. § 215.14.—ou)/te...ou)de\n ou)d): a remarkable accumulation of emphatic negatives: ou)/te corresponds to te (5).
3. ou)d' a)di/kws, (not) even unjustly.

5. di/s te...prw/tas, when you twice stood in line with them in the earliest encounters: some cognate object is implied in sumparataca/menoi. All MSS. except *s add ma/xas, as if maxesa/menoi had preceded. The natural accus. would be parata/ceis, following the meaning of sumparataca/menoi and so signifying battle array or battles. See Aesch. III. 151, e)pi\ th\n para/tacin w(/rmhsan.

6. th/n t' e)pi\ tou= potamou=, the river battle, probably fought on the upper Cephisus, which flows through Phocis before it enters Boeotia near Chaeronea.—th\n xeimerinh\n, the “winter battle,” probably fought on some wintry day in the hilly parts of Phocis. Many still find chronological difficulties in this winter campaign, forgetting that the only trouble arose from the spurious decree in §§ 181— 187, dated in midsummer. See notes on §§ 152.8 and 181—187, with Hist. § 65.
9. para\ me\n tw=n a)/llwn u(mi=n is in strong (double) antithesis to para\ d' u(mw=n toi=s qeoi=s.
3. zh/lou, pride, glory: see note on § 120.6.
7. meta\...e)chta/zeto, was counted in with the rest, the same military figure which is common in this speech: see note on § 173.5.
8. ou)d' o(/sia, even impious: cf. note on § 1.6.

8, 9. w(s a)ri/stwn...w(s ou)k a)/rista: with reference to the words of Ctesiphon's decree, o(/ti diatelei= kai\ le/gwn kai\ pra/ttwn ta\ a)/rista tw=| dh/mw| (Aesch. 49). If Aeschines joined in the thanksgivings, he declared before the Gods that the policy of Demosthenes was good: but he now asks the court to declare this not good by condemning Ctesiphon.
10. o)mwmoko/tas: of the Heliastic oath.
11. a)polwle/nai polla/kis: cf. XIX. 110, tri\s ou)x a(/pac a)polwle/nai di/kaios.
2. e)n tw=|...nomi/zein, in the belief, corresponding to e)n qusi/ais (1), both denoting what occupied their minds.
3. toi=s...dokou=sin (impf.), to those who had seemed likely to need help, i.e. ourselves.—a)f' w(=n e)/pratton, in antithesis to e)c w(=n e)pei/sqht' e)moi/: cf. § 213.11-13.

4. au)tou\s, ipsos, i.e. ourselves: for the accus. see Xen. Oec. 11, 23, sumfe/rei au)toi=s fi/lous ei)=nai, where fi/lois would be more common (G. 928.1).— bohqei=n e(te/rois: subj. of perieisth/kei, it had come about.
5. oi(/as h)fi/ei fwna\s: cf. § 195.5.
6. e)pistolw=n: for an earlier letter of Philip to Peloponnesus asking for help, see § 156.
9. pla/noi refers especially to his frequent journeys to Thebes while the negotiations were going on, and also to his other embassies (cf. § 244).— ta\ polla\, the many.

10. die/sure: see the general ridi- cule of his decrees in Aesch. III.
100.1-3. This remark may perhaps refer to the fierce criticism of the terms of the alliance with Thebes (III. 141—143).—ti/ a)peirga/sato: the position of ti/ is emphatic: cf. ske/yasqe pw=s, § 235.4. We should expect sune/xeia etc. to be in the accus. by the usual attraction; but they are far more expressive as they stand.
§§ 219—221. were spoken while the clerk was preparing to read the letters of Philip.
2. *kalli/stratos: the famous orator whose eloquence is said to have inspired Demosthenes (as a boy) to devote himself to oratory: see note on § 99.8.

3. *)aristofw=n: mentioned in § 70.5.—*ke/falos: see § 251.—*qrasu/boulos, of Collytus, who served under his distinguished namesake in the Restoration of 403 B.C. (XXIV. 134). He was afterwards a warm friend of Thebes: see Aesch. III. 138, a)nh\r e)n *qh/bais pisteuqei\s w(s ou)dei\s e(/teros.
5. dia\ panto\s, throughout; like a(plw=s, §§ 88.8, 179.7.
6. ou)k a)\n e)pre/sbeusen...e)/grayen: both iterative (M.T. 162): we often use would in such iterative expressions, with no potential force; as he would often tell me stories (see M.T. 249).

8. r(a|stw/nhn, enjoyment of ease. —ei)/ ti ge/noit' a)nafora/n, i.e. some retreat in case of accident: ei)/ ti ge/noito depends on an apodosis implied in a)nafora/n; cf. Aeschyl. Sept. 1015, w(s o)/nt' a)nastath=ra...ei) mh\ qew=n tis e)mpodw
 e)/sth dori/ (M.T. 480). The direct form, e)a/n ti ge/nhtai, might have been used: see Aesch. II. 104, au(toi=s kate/lipon th
 ei)s to\ a)fane\s a)nafora
 a)
 mh\ pei/qwmen. The meaning comes from the middle a)nafe/resqai, to carry oneself back.
1. u(perh=ras; did you excel? absolutely, or possibly sc. tou/tous.—r(w/mh|: i.e. so as to need no a)nafora/ (§ 219.8).
3. ou(/tws e)pepei/smhn, I had so thoroughly convinced myself.
4. e)do/kei is first personal (sc. o( ki/ndunos); then (without ou)k) understood as impersonal with a)gaphto\n ei)=nai.
5. xw/ran dido/nai is to allow room for considerations of personal safety; pro/noian dido/nai is to allow thought for this. We should say to allow room for thought.
6. a)gaphto\n...pra/ceien: in the direct form, a)gaphto/n e)stin e)a/n tis... a(\ dei= pra/ch|, we must be content (impers.) if we (shall) do our duty, omitting nothing.
7. a(\ dei==ta\ de/onta, our duty: a(\ is here definite; but with a slight change in the view it might have been a(\ a)\n de/h| or a(\ de/oi (Dobree's conjecture), with conditional force.

2. tuxo\n, perhaps, acc. abs. (M.T. 851).—a)naisqhtw=n, senselessly: I follow Vömel, Bekk., and West. in this reading, though a)nai/sqhton (adv.) has better MS. authority.— o(/mws, nevertheless, with reference to a)naisqhtw=n.—mh/te...gra/yai: the direct form would be ou)/t' a)\n e(mou= gra/yeie be/ltion ou)dei\s: for mh/ thus used with infin. in or. obl., see M.T. 685, and Liddell and Scott, art. mh/, B. 5, C. a)/n belongs to gra/yai, pra=cai, and presbeu=sai, and be/ltion to gra/yai and pra=cai.

3. e)pairo/menos, of rais- ing (as a threat). Harpocr.: a)nti\ tou= e)panateino/menos, *dhmosqe/nhs e)n tw=| u(pe *kthsifw=ntos. Cf. XIX. 153, ou)de
 a)
 u(mi=n ei)=xen a)natei/nasqai fobero/n (of threats of Philip); and Eur. Iph. T. 1484, pau/sw de\ lo/gxhn h(
 e)pai/romai ce/nois (of a spear uplifted to strike). (Bl.) e)pairo/menos is imperfect, as is shown by ta\ pro\ tou/twn.
5. parw\n, though present: see §§ 83.6 and 117.7.
6. *diw/ndas: mentioned with con- tempt in § 249.9.—to\ me/ros (sc. pe/mpton), see notes on §§ 103.2, 266.6.
7. yhfi/smata: for the plural see note on § 223.5.—a)popefeugo/ta, acquitted (on the grafh\ parano/mwn): to\ feu=gon yh/fisma, XXIII. 58, is the decree on trial.
8. grafe/nta, indicted: cf. gra- fe/nta, proposed, § 86.4. See note on § 56.4.
1—3. For the questions concerning the decree of Aristonicus and deute/rou khru/gmatos in § 83.5, see notes on that passage and on § 120.3.

5. sugkathgo/rhsen, aided in the accusation (as sunh/goros).—*dhmome/lh ...*(uperei/dhn: the two names probably indicate a decree moved by Demomeles (cousin of Demosthenes) and amended or enlarged by Hyperides. Such double or treble bills were common: see C. I. Att. II. no. 469; whence ta\ yhfi/smata in § 222.7.

7. ei)/per—nu=n kathgorei=: the sim- ple present condition is correct here, and more effective than G. H. Schaefer's kathgo/rei. The meaning is, if he is now accusing me honestly, he would have had more reason for prosecuting (i.e. if he had prosecuted) D. and H. then than he has for prosecuting Ctes. now.
1. tw=|de (like to/nde and tw=|de in § 223.8) is Ctesiphon, who is ou(=tos in 4; while Aeschines is tou=ton au)to\n in 3.

5. mhke/t) e)a=n...kathgorei=n: the principle that “no man can be twice put in jeopardy for the same offence” is distinctly stated in the Attic law: see XX. 147, oi( no/moi d' ou)k e)w=si di\s pro\s to
 au)to
 peri\ tw=n au)tw=n ou)/te di/kas ou)/t) eu)qu/nas ou)/te diadikasi/an ou)/t) a)/llo toiou=ton ou)de
 ei)=nai, and XXIV. 55. This could here be urged by Ctesiphon as a moral, though not as a legal, argument. Aeschines is prosecuting him now on the ground of charges against Demosthenes which were indirectly declared false by the acquittal of Hyperides eight years before,—charges for which he did not similarly prosecute H. then and for which he could not legally prosecute Dem. now. This is all an answer to dia\ ti/; (which refers to § 223 (end)). —tw=n ou(/tw praxqe/ntwn, matters so settled (as these charges against Dem.): see XXXVI. 60, dika/zesqai tw=n ou(/tw praxqe/ntwn.
7. e)f' au(tou=, on its own merits: i.e. before any judgment of the court had been passed upon the case.

2. o(\ nuni\ poiei=n: all MSS. except *s have poiei= for poiei=n.— palaiw=n xro/nwn: i.e. the time of the peace of Philocrates, about which Aeschines (III. 58—78) had cited many decrees which had no real bearing on the argument.

4. mh/t) a)\n...r(hqh=nai, or thought would be mentioned to-day (r(hqh=nai a)/n=r(hqei/h a)/n): see M.T. 220.1. The negatives mh/te etc. show that the antecedent of a(\ is indefinite.—diaba/llein, to misrepresent (cast reproach upon) the case.
5. profa/seis, grounds for action, whether true or false. See note on § 178.12.
Demosthenes still clings to his plea that the story of the Peace of Philocrates is ancient history.
1. e)pi\ th=s a)lhqei/as: cf. § 17.2.
3. e)n tai=s xersi\n: for the figure Westermann compares mani-festus.— pa/ntes oi( lo/goi, i.e. the whole discussion.
4. tou\s...fugw\n: cf. § 15.2.

5. r(hto/rwn a)gw=na: cf. Thuc. III. 67.28, poih/sate de\ toi=s *(/ellhsi para/deigma ou) lo/gwn tou\s a)gw=nas proqh/sontes a)ll' e)/rgwn. Weil quotes XIX. 217: ou)de\ ga\r r(hto/rwn ou)de\ lo/gwn kri/sin u(ma=s th/meron...prosh/kei poiei=n.
7. lo/gou...sumfe/rontos: lo/gou kri/sin is a trial of eloquence. Cf. the verbal forms lo/gon kri/nein and to\ th=| po/lei sumfe/ron kri/nein.
With § 226 the orator ends his grand comparison (begun in § 139) between the part played by Aeschines in rousing the Amphissian war and his own part in uniting Athens and Thebes against Philip.

div1.p:
At § 226 the proper defence ends, with the account of the alliance with Thebes. The remainder of the speech, before the epilogue, is devoted to a reply to three arguments of Aeschines, one comparing this trial
to an investigation of an account (§§ 227—251), a second charging Demosthenes with being ill-starred (§§ 252—275), and a third charging him with being a crafty rhetorician (§§ 276—296).

div2.p: In §§ 227—251. the orator refers to the exhortation of Aeschines to the judges (59—61) to cast aside any prejudices in favour of Demosthenes which they may have, and to proceed as they would if they were examining a long account, prepared to accept any result which the reckoning may bring out. Aeschines refers here only to the facts concerning the peace of Philocrates; but Demosthenes chooses to apply the remarks to his whole political life. While Aeschines referred only to the debit side of the account, Demosthenes speaks of both sides, and especially of what stands on the credit side of his own account with the state, including credit for preventing calamities by his judicious policy. He ends (§ 251) by turning against Aeschines the case of Cephalus, which had been brought up against himself.
1. ei)=ta sofi/zetai, then he puts on airs of wisdom, or becomes very subtle, with the same sarcasm as in sofou= paradei/gmatos, § 228.2.
2. a)melh=sai, disregard: Aeschines (III. 60) says, mh/t' a)pognw/tw mhde\n mh/te katagnw/tw pri\n a)kou/sh|.

3. periei=nai xrh/mata/ tw|, that one has a balance in his favour.—logi/zhsqe: cf. Aesch. III. 59, kaqezw/meqa e)pi\ tou\s logismou/s.—a)
 kaqairw=sin... perih=|, if the counters are decisive and there is no balance remaining. With most recent editors, I follow *s.1 and read kaqairw=sin, the common text having kaqarai\ w)=sin, which was referred to the counters being cleared off from the abacus (a)/bac or a)ba/kion): cf. § 231.3. This was a reckoningboard, on which counters (originally yh=foi, pebbles) represented units, tens, etc., according to their position. See the article Abacus in Smith's Dict. of Ant. Aeschines says (59), e)pineu/sas a)lhqe\s ei)=nai o(/ ti a)
 au)to\s o( logismo\s ai(rh=|, whatever the account proves (cf. ai(rei=n tina kle/ptonta), and there is a strong presumption that Demosthenes uses a similar expression in his reply. Köchly quotes Dion. Hal. Ant. Rom. VII. 36, o(/ ti d' a)
 ai( plei/ous yh=foi kaqairw=si, tou=to poiei=n (and again, slightly changed, in 39): here the meaning determine is beyond question.
5. prosqe/sqai, acquiesce in: cf. prosqeme/nhn, § 203.5.
7. h)=| pepragme/non: see § 178.15, and note on § 178.10.

3. h(ma=s (so *s)...e)gnw-
sme/nous, that it is assumed that we (Aesch. and myself) have been thus judged (have this reputation): in the direct form u(pa/rxomen e)gnwsme/noi. It appears that e)/gnwsmai is always passive (see Veitch). The personal construction is like that of Ar. Nub. 918, gnwsqh/sei toi/ pot' *)aqhnai/ois oi(=a dida/skeis tou\s a)noh/tous, you shall be shown (for it shall be shown).
5. mh\ toiau/ths ou)/shs=ei) mh\ toiau/th h)=n. The unique reading of the Oxyrh. papyrus, mh\ toiau/ths u(parxou/shs, is suggestive.
2. ou) tiqei\s yh/fous (con- tinuing the figure of § 227), i.e. not by mere arithmetic or book-keeping.
3. ou) ga\r...logismo\s, for that is not the way to reckon affairs of state. ou(=tos is predicate.

4. a)namimnh/|skwn e(/kast): he ren- ders his account, not by setting his services against his sins, but by setting the positive gain from his public policy against the calamities which would have resulted from the opposite policy.
5. logistai=s: in the double sense of computers and comptrollers of accounts: see note on § 117.8.—toi=s a)kou/ousin: addressed equally to the court and the spectators.
7. meta\ and sun- emphasize one another.
9. kwlu/ein: present, of the whole business of checking Philip; the aor. sunembalei=n (7) of an incursion.
2. e(ptako/sia sta/dia, about 80 miles: see note on § 195.5.
3. gene/sqai: sc. e)poi/hse. By o(ri/ois he means the further confines of Boeotia.

4. lh|sta\s: see note on § 145.6, and for pirates in general [VII.] 3, 4, 14, 15. The rescue of Oreus and Eretria from Philip (§§ 79, 87) prevented Euboea from being a nest for plunderers.—fe/rein kai\ a)/gein: the common term for general plundering.
5. e)k qala/tths, on the side of the sea, with reference to e)k th=s *eu)boi/as.
6. to\n *(ellh/sponton: for the Hellespont and Byzantium in 340 B.C. see §§ 80, 87, 88, 93, 94, and Hist. §§ 53—55.
2. yh/fois o(/moios, cf. ko/mai *xari/tessin o(moi=ai, Il. XVII. 51.
3. a)ntanelei=n tau=ta, to strike these off (the services of § 230) in balancing the account, as yh=foi would be removed from the a)ba/kion.
4. ou)ke/ti prosti/qhmi, I do not go on (e)/ti) to add, i.e. to the credit side of the account.
5. e)n oi(=s...kate/sth: as in the cases of Olynthus, Thessaly, and Phocis.
7. filanqrwpi/as: especially Phi- lip's easy terms with Athens after Chaeronea, which were the indirect result of the firm and dignified attitude of Demosthenes and his friends. See Hist. § 68.
8. periballo/menos: the common figure of investing oneself with anything (like a garment), hence acquiring.

9. kalw=s poiou=ntes, by the blessing of Heaven: cf. 1. 28, w(=n kalw=s poiou=ntes e)/xousi, and kalw=s poiou=si, XXI. 212. This phrase sometimes means fortunately (as here), approaching in sense the more common eu)= pra/ssein, to be prosperous: sometimes doing as one should, as in XXI. 2, kalw=s kai\ ta\ di/kaia poiw=n o( dh=mos ou(/tws w)rgi/sqh, and LVII. 6, kalw=s poiou=ntes tou\s h)dikhme/nous ses w/kate. To show the distinction between kalw=s poiw=n and eu)= pra/sswn, Dissen quotes XX. 110, o(/te d' u(mei=s kalw=s poiou=ntes...a)/meinon e)kei/nwn pra/ttete. The active expressions eu)= poiei=n and kakw=s poiei=n are entirely distinct from kalw=s poiei=n.
§§ 232—241. We have here an account of the power of Athens under the leadership of Demosthenes, compared with her earlier resources.
3. toiau=ta: cognate (sc. kathgorh/mata).

4. paradei/gmata, like the illustra- tion just discussed (§ 227): cf. § 228.2.
—r(h/mata...mimou/menos: besides the expressions (r(h/mata) repeated by Aeschines (probably with no little exaggeration) in III. 166, of which he asks (167), tau=ta de\ ti/ e)stin, w)= ki/nados; r(h/mata h)\ qau/mata; we have in 209, poi= fu/gw, a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi; perigra/yate/ me: ou)k e)/stin o(/poi a)napth/somai, quoted from Demosthenes. See other quotations in III. 71 and 72, especially a)porrh=cai th=s ei)rh/nhs th\n summaxi/an. Imitations of gestures (sxh/mata) are, of course, harder to detect; but there is a plain one in III. 167, ku/klw| peridinw=n seauto/n.

5. para\ tou=to ge/gone, depend on this. See Cic. Orat. 8, 27: itaque se purgans iocatur Demosthenes: negat in eo positas esse fortunas Graeciae, hoc an illo verbo usus sit, et huc an illuc manum porrexerit.— ou)x o(ra=|s; cf. § 266.7.
6. mh\ touti\: in the second mem- ber of an alternative indirect question, mh/ can be used as well as ou). (G. 1609.)
1. e)p)...e)/rgwn: cf. e)pi\ th=s a)lhqei/as, § 226.1.

2. a)forma\s, means (for war): a)formh/ is properly a starting-point, or something to set out from (a)f' w(=n tis o(rma=tai), as in Thuc. 1. 90, th/n te *pelopo/nnhson pa=sin e)/fasan i(kanh\n ei)=nai a)naxw/rhsi/n te kai\ a)formh/n.— duna/meis: here in the same general sense as du/namin in § 234.1.
3. o(/t)...ei)sh/|ein: before the re- newal of the war in 340 B.C. Cf. § 60.4.
8. ei)...lo/gw|: cf. § 252.9, and XXIII. 24, w(s a(plw=s kai\ dikai/ws xrh/somai tw=| lo/gw|.

1. du/namin here refers to sources of military power, like allies, even when no actual troops are included: see o(pli/thn d' , i(ppe/a ou)de/na (5). Both duna/meis and du/namis, however, may denote troops: cf. § 237.6, tw=n politikw=n duna/mewn, and 247.5; so Xen. An. I. 3, 12 e)/xei du/namin kai\ pezh\n kai\ i(ppikh\n kai\ nautikh/n.

2. ou)/te...h)=n: this refers to the early part of 340 B.C., when Chios
and Rhodes were independent of Athens as the result of the Social War (357—355 B.C.), but Byzantium, which then followed Chios and Rhodes, had already renewed her friendship (§ 230.7): see Hist. §§ 2, 51. Corcyra, the old friend and ally of Athens, had become hostile to her before 353 B.C. (see XXIV. 202).

4. xrhma/twn su/ntacin: the pay- ment of the original assessment made on the Delian confederacy by Aristides in 478—477 B.C. was first called fo/ros from fe/rw, as Thucydides explains it, ou(/tw ga\r w)noma/sqh tw=n xrhma/twn h( fora/. The First Athenian Empire made the name odious, so that, when the new federation was formed in 378, the term su/ntacis, agreement, was adopted for the annual payment.—pe/nte kai\ tettara/konta ta/lanta: this sorry amount of 45 talents shows the decline of the power of Athens after the Social War. The original tribute of 460 talents was raised to 600 under Pericles (Thuc. II. 13.23), and (if we may trust Aesch. II. 175 and Plut. Arist. 24) to 1200 or 1300 after the Peace of Nicias, in large part by the allies commuting personal service for payments of money (Thuc. 1. 99).

5. proeceilegme/na, collected in ad- vance, probably by generals to pay their mercenaries. Aeschines (II. 71) speaks of tou\s peri\ to\ bh=ma kai\ th
 e)kklhsi/an misqofo/rous, oi(\ tou\s me
 talaipw/rous nhsiw/tas kaq) e(/kaston e)niauto
 e(ch/konta ta/lanta ei)se/pratton su/ntacin.—o(pli/thn d), i(ppe/a: so *s and L; cf. § 94.5.
7. ou(=toi: Aeschines and his party.
8. pareskeua/kesan...e)ggute/rw: cf. tou\s qeou\s i(/lews au(tw=| paraskeua/zein, Plat. Leg. 803 E.
2. ou(/tws u(ph=rxen e)/xonta, i.e. this is what we had to depend on.

9. ou) prole/gwn...bouleuo/menos: two important advantages of a despotism in war. Athens is not the last free state which has suffered from the opposite evils. With this whole passage compare § 249 and 1. 4.
4. prw=ton, to begin with: cf. XX. 54, o( lo/gos prw=ton ai)sxro/s.— met-ei=xon: met- implies the sharing of the right which the preceding clause states.
5. prou)ti/qeq), offered (see § 273.3): cf. IV. 1, ei) prou)ti/qeto le/gein.
6. o(/s)...perige/noint) e)mou=, i.e. as often as they got the better of me. The omitted antecedent of o(/s) appears in tau=q) (8).
7. tu/xoi (M.T. 532): sc. geno/menon.

8. tau=q)—bebouleume/noi, i.e. just so often had you taken counsel in the enemy's interest when you left the Assembly: tau=q) (cognate with bebouleume/noi) are the bouleu/mata in which perige/noint' e)mou=, and these counsels you always took in the enemy's interest. Cf. Thuc. II. 44.15, i)/son ti h)\ di/kaion (sc. bou/leuma) bouleu/esqai.

2. e)k toiou/twn e)lattwma/- twn, i.e. with such disadvantages at the outset.—summa/xous...e)poi/hsa: this refers to the grand league against Philip, formed early in 340 B.C. by Demosthenes and Callias of Chalcis. See Hist. § 51 (end). For the Euboeans see § 79 (above): for the Euboeans, Peloponnesians, and Acarnanians see Aesch. III. 95—97.
5. mu/rioi kai\ pentakisxi/lioi: this includes the Theban forces, which were added a year after the league was formed.
6. politikw=n, citizen soldiers (of the various states).
7. sunte/leian: this term was ap- plied to the contributions of the new league, rather than su/ntacis (§ 234.4): Aesch. (III. 97) calls them su/ntagma.

The orator here exposes with great effect one of the most
unlucky blunders of Aeschines (143), that of charging him with imposing two-thirds of the expense of the war on Athens, and only one-third on Thebes. Aeschines had forgotten the fleet at Salamis, of which Athens furnished two-thirds!
1, 2. ta\ di/kaia, our rights.
4. kai\ pro/teron, i.e. once also in former days.

5, 6. triakosi/wn, diakosi/as: the numbers of the ships at Salamis are variously given; but nearly all agree in making the Athenian fleet about two-thirds of the whole. Aeschylus, who was in the battle, is our best authority when (Pers. 339) he gives the total as 310, and Demosthenes nearly agrees with him. Herodotus (VIII. 1, 44, 48, 61) gives the total as 378 (the items giving 366), the Athenians having 200, of which they lent 20 to the Chalcidians. The Athenian orator in Thucydides (1. 74.6) gives the total as 400 and the Athenian ships as nearly two-thirds.
7. e)lattou=sqai, that they had less than their rights.
9. ai)sxro\n: sc. a)\n h)=n.—e)/xousa goes with e(wra=to like the preceding nomi/zousa, kri/nousa, and a)ganaktou=s).
2. parw\n, i.e. in the As- sembly, as Aesch. regularly was: see § 273.1.
3. ei)/per e)nede/xeto: sc. tau=ta gra/fein.—para\...kairou\s, in the crises through which we were then living.

4. ou)x o(/s)...pra/gmat), not all that we wanted (continuously), but all that circumstances (on each occasion) allowed us (M.T. 532). ou)x o(/sa bouloi/meqa would have meant not all that we wanted in each case.
5. a)ntwnou/menos (conative), bid- ding against us (trying to buy). Cf. § 247.8.
6. prosdeco/menos...e(/toimos, was ready at hand to receive them and to pay them too (pros-) for coming.
1. nu=n: opposed to ei) to/t)...a)ph=lqon.—e)pi\ toi=s pepragme/nois, i.e. for what I actually did.

2. ti/ a)
 oi)/esqe: poiei=n would naturally follow here, a)/n having its common place before oi)/esqe (M.T. 220.1): cf. § 225.4. But the long protasis ei) to/t' ...kate/sth causes ti/ and a)
 to be repeated with poiei=n (5); cf. IX. 35, ti/ oi)/esqe, e)peida
...ge/nhtai, ti/ poih/sein;—a)kribologoume/nou, quibbling, splitting hairs, part of the unreal condition ei) a)ph=lqon: the partic. is temporal.
5. ti/ poiei=n a)\n h)\ ti/ le/gein repre- sents ti/ e)poi/oun a)\n h)\ e)/legon; cf. § 241.8.
1. ou)x: sc. e)/legon a)/n. So in the next line.

3—8. tou= me\n...lh|stw=n ge/gonen; this seems to be a continuation of the indirect quotation, with ou)k a)\n e)/legon w(s understood. But there may be a change to a direct quotation (not interrogative) after ei)=ta, without w(s, as Vömel and Westermann take it.
2. pantaxo/qen, in every way (from every side).

3. filai/tion, fond of (malicious) accusation: see LVII. 34, tou=to ga/r e)stin o( sukofa/nths, ai)tia=sqai me\n pa/nta e)cele/gcai de\ mhde/n. See § 189.1.—kai\ fu/sei ki/nados, a beast by his very nature: ki/nados nascitur, sukofa/nths fit.—ta)nqrw/pion, homunculus, refers to mental not to bodily stature.
4. e)leu/qeron, i.e. worthy of a free- born Athenian: cf. mhde\n e)leu/qeron fronw=n, Soph. Phil. 1006.

5. au)totragiko\s pi/qhkos, a natural tragic ape: Schol. oi)/koqen kai\ a)f' e(autou= e)/xei to\ piqhki/zesqai. au)to- seems to have the same force as fu/sei in 3 (West.). Harpocr. under tragiko\s pi/qhkos has: e)/oike le/gein tou=to o( r(h/twr w(s kai\ peri\ th\n u(po/krisin a)tuxou=ntos tou= *ai)sxi/nou, kai\ mimoume/nou ma=llon tragw|dou\s h)\ tragw|dei=n duname/nou. Paroem. Gr. I. p. 375: e)pi\ tw=n par' a)ci/an semnunome/nwn. These describe both the imitative and the boastful ape. See Arist. Poet. 26. Cf. § 313.8, tragiko\s *qeokri/nhs.
a)rourai=os *oi)no/maos: see § 180.5, 6 and note. Aeschines is called rustic, probably because he “murdered Oenomaus” at the country Dionysia (toi=s kat' a)grou/s).
6. para/shmos, counterfeit: Har- pocr. has e)k metafora=s ei)/rhtai a)po\ tw=n nomis ma/twn.
1. nu=n h(mi=n le/geis: nu=n has great emphasis, and is repeated in 8: is this the time you take to talk to us of the past?

2. w(/sper a)\n (sc. poioi/h) ei): i.e. in talking to us of the past now you act as a physician (would act) if he etc. If poioi/h had been expressed with a)\n, i)atro\s would be its subject. Cf. § 194.4.

3. toi=s ka/mnousin: the general term for patients, not merely while they are ill (a)sqenou=si) but even after they are dead (e)peidh\ teleuth/seie/ tis). ei)siw\n, i.e. in his visits.—di) w(=n a)pofeu/contai: final (M.T. 565).

4. e)peidh\...fe/roito, but when one of them had died and his relatives were carrying offerings to his tomb (all part of the supposition), depending on ei)...dieci/oi (M.T. 177, 558, 560). ta\ nomizo/mena are the customary offerings to the dead (e)nagi/smata), brought on the third and ninth days after death. Aeschines says, teleuth/santos de\ e)lqw\n ei)s ta\ e)/nata dieci/oi, and Demosthenes probably refers to these ninth-day offerings. For views of such offerings see Smith's Dict. Antiq. I. p. 888, and Gardner and Jevons's Greek Antiq. p. 367. Aeschines (225) predicts that Demosthenes will use this illustration, and (189) that he will allude to Philammon the boxer (which he does in § 319); both predictions were of course inserted after the trial.

6. to\ mnh=ma, the tomb, built above ground, which may at the same time be a monument; cf. mnh/masi, § 208.7. In the same double sense we must take ta/fos in the famous passage, Thuc. II. 43.18, a)ndrw=n ga\r e)pifanw=n pa=sa gh= ta/fos.—to\ kai\ to\, this and that, one of the few colloquial relics of the pronominal article: see IX. 68, e)/dei ga\r to\ kai\ to\ poih=sai kai\ to\ mh\ poih=sai.—a)/nqrwpos ou(tosi\: so all the MSS. The article may be omitted with demonstratives when the pro
noun emphatically points out a present person or thing; as Plat. Gorg. 489 B, ou(tosi\ a)nh\r ou) pau/setai fluarw=n, and 505 C, ou(=tos a)nh\r ou)x u(pome/nei w)felou/menos: see Thuc. I. 51.6, nh=es e)kei=nai e)piple/ousi, yonder are ships sailing up.
7. e)mbro/nthte, thunderstruck, stu- pefied by bronth/: cf. e)mbebronth=sqai, XIX. 231. For the relation of these words to tetu/fwmai see note on § 11.5.
8. ei)=ta nu=n le/geis; see note on 1.

1. th\n h(=ttan: still having in mind the figure of the reckoning (§ 227), he now argues that the chief item which his enemies place on the debit side, the defeat of Chaeronea, cannot justly be charged to him (cf. logi/zesqe in 4).
2. tw=n par' e)moi\, of what I was responsible for.

4. o(/poi e)pe/mfqhn: for the differ- ence between this and o(/poi pemfqei/hn in § 45 (referring to the same thing), and for e)n oi(=s krathqei=en (9), see note on § 45.2. Little is known of any of these embassies of Demosthenes except those to Byzantium (§§ 87—89) and Thebes (§ 211 ff.).
10. o(/plois katestre/feto, i.e. he decided these cases by throwing his sword into the scale.
1. tau=t' a)paitei=s, you call me to account for these (§ 244.10).

2. ei)s malaki/an: West. cites Aesch. III. 148, 152, 155, and 175. In these Demosthenes is ridiculed for having run away at Chaeronea, when the whole allied army was put to flight. Aeschines is never charged with this; but he was probably not in the battle at all, being over fifty years old. Probably Demosthenes refers also to the nickname *ba/ttalos: see note on § 180.3.
5. th=s yuxh=s, the life.
6. tw=n paratacame/nwn, the com- batants: §§ 208.5, 216.5.
7. eu)qu/nas: used metaphorically. —skaio\s, awkward (mentally): cf. § 120.4.
3. lamba/nete: plural, as he turns suddenly from Aeschines to the whole assembly.

4. i)dei=n...a)rxo/mena k.t.l.: no one can read the earlier orations of Demosthenes in the light of later events without feeling the justice of this claim to sagacity which he puts forward. He, indeed, of all the statesmen of Athens, saw things in their beginnings, and steadily warned the people of the coming danger.

7. politika\ tai=s po/lesi, inherent in (free) governments: a striking case of a favourite Greek form of emphasis, which repeats the idea of a noun in an adjective. Here the whole idea could have been expressed either by politika/ or by oi)kei=a tai=s po/lesi; but it is made doubly strong by politika\ tai=s po/lesi. The Greek constantly emphasizes by what we should call tautology, as in the repetition of negatives. In Aeschyl. Ag. 56, oi)wno/qroon go/on o)cubo/an, the whole idea could have been expressed by oi)wnw=n go/on o)cu/n, shrill cry of birds, but the idea of cry is added in both adjectives. po/lesi here has the same reference to free governments which is usually implied in politei/a (see note on § 65.9): cf. Soph. Ant. 737, po/lis ga\r ou)k e)/sq' h(/tis a)ndro/s e)sq) e(no/s. With the whole passage cf. §§ 235, 236.
8. w(s belongs to ei)s e)la/xista, into the smallest possible compass: see § 288.5.
9. sustei=lai, to contract: suste/l- lw sometimes means to shorten sail, as in Ar. Ran. 999; cf. Eq. 432, sustei/las tou\s a)lla=ntas.
11. pepoi/htai: in the same sense as pe/praktai (5): see note on § 4.6.
12. kat' e)me\: most MSS. (not *s and L.1) have to\ kat' e)me\, as in § 247.11.
3, 4. tw=| dido/nai, by making gifts.
5. duna/mewn, referring to strato- pe/dw| (3): see note on §234.1.
6. tau=ta (i.e. duna/meis): cf. kata\ th\n strathgi/an (§ 212.8).

7. tw=| diafqarh=nai h)\ mh\, in the matter of being corrupted or not, far more expressive than tw=| mh\ diafqarh=nai. This corresponds to tw=n me\n duna/mewn, in place of a clause with de/. Cf. XIX. 4, and 7, u(pe/r ge tou= proi=ka h)\ mh/.
8. o( w)nou/menos: conative, he who would buy. Cf. § 239.5.

9. o( mh\ labw\n kai\ diafqarei\s (*s, L.1) = o(\s mh\ e)/labe kai\ diefqa/rh, better than mhde\ diafqarei\s (vulg.), as it more closely unites the corruption with the bribe, he who refused to take the bribe and be corrupted.
1. ei)s to\...tou=ton, i.e. to justify Ctesiphon's language in his decree: see § 57.1.
3. oi( pa/ntes u(mei=s: sc. pare/- sxesqe.
6. e)mbebhkw\s, standing amid, surrounded by: be/bhka, stand, is related to i(/stamai as ge/gona to ei)mi/ and ke/kthmai to e)/xw.

7. h(ni/k) ou)d)...pro\s e)me\, i.e. when most men might have shown some want of feeling towards me without surprising anyone: this rather awkward translation shows the force of the construction of qaumasto
 h)=n (without a)/n) and the infinitive, where the chief potential force falls on the infinitive. (See M.T. 415, 416, and Appendix v. p. 406.) We naturally (but incorrectly) translate when it would have been no wonder, throwing the chief force on qaumasto
 h)=n, so that a)/n seems necessary: Blass reads ou)d' a)/n. For a similar case see Eur. Med. 490, ei) ga h)=sq' a)/pais, suggnwsto
 h)=n soi tou=d) e)rasqh=nai le/xous, i.e. in that case you might pardonably have been enamoured: see M.T. 422.1.

9. ta\s e)ma\s gnw/mas, my proposals of public measures: this and the following pa/nq' o(/sa...e)pra/tteto do not include such general measures for the public safety as the famous decree of Hyperides for the enfranchisement of slaves, the recall of exiles, and similar extreme provisions (see Hist. § 67).
10. h( dia/tacis tw=n fula/kwn: see Thuc. 11. 24, fulaka\s katesth/santo kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan, w(/sper dh\ e)/mellon dia\ panto\s tou= pole/mou fula/cein.
11. ta/froi...tei/xh: this has noth- ing to do with the more elaborate work on the walls undertaken in the following year, when Demosthenes was teixopoio/s (§ 113.6).

12. sitw/nhn, an extraordinary official appointed in special times of distress to regulate the trade in grain and to guard against scarcity. The grain trade was ordinarily in the charge of 35 sitofu/lakes (20 in the city, 15 in the Piraeus): see Arist. Pol. Ath. 51.8.
1. meta\ tau=ta, i.e. after the first excitement, when Philip's party gained courage at Athens.
2. susta/ntwn: gen. absol. with the implied antecedent of oi(=s.

3. grafa\s: here in the most re- stricted sense of ordinary public suits, excluding ei)saggeli/a, eu)/qunai, etc. The chief form of grafh/ here would be the grafh\ parano/mwn (§ 250.5).— pa/nta tau=t): emphatic apposition, all these, I say.
4. ou) di) e(autw=n, not in their own names: at first the leading philippizers kept in the background, and put forward such obscure men as those mentioned below.

7—9. a)po/noia, mani/a: “the first is the deliberate desperation of a man with nothing to lose, the last the desperation of blind passion” (Simcox).—*swsikle/ous...*mela/ntou: Sosicles and Melantus are otherwise unknown; for Diondas see § 222.6; Philocrates is not the one who gave his name to the peace of 346 B.C. (he disappears after he was condemned on the ei)saggeli/a brought by Hyperides, XIX. 116), but an Eleusinian (XXV. 44). The imitation of this passage by Cicero (Cat. III. 7) is familiar: hoc providebam animo, ...nec mihi P. Lentuli somnum, nec
L. Cassii adipes, nec Cethegi furiosam temeritatem pertimescendam.
11. di) u(ma=s, i.e. through the courts.
13. a)lhqe\s, in accordance with truth.—u(pe\r...dikastw=n, to the credit of judges, etc.
14. gno/ntwn ta\ eu)/orka, who (not only had sworn, but) gave judgment in accordance with their oaths.

1. e)n oi(=s ei)shggello/mhn (cf. e)n oi(=s h(ma/rtanon, § 19.3). The ei)saggeli/a was partly a state prosecution, which was first brought before the Senate (rarely before the Assembly). If the Senate accepted the ei)saggeli/a, it referred the case to the Heliastic court for trial, unless it settled it by inflicting a fine not exceeding 500 drachmas.

2. to\ me/ros tw=n yh/fwn: cf. §§ 103.2, 266.6. A comparison of Hyperides (Lycoph. 8), dia\ to\ a)ki/ndunon au)toi=s ei)=nai to\n a)gw=na, with Lycurgus (Leocr. 3), to\n i)di/a| kinduneu/onta, and Pollux (VIII. 52, 53), shows that in earlier times no penalty was inflicted on the ei)sagge/llwn who failed to get one-fifth of the votes, but that afterwards he was subject to the fine without the a)timi/a.
4. ta)/rista/ me pra/ttein: i.e. the judgment of the court justified this expression in Ctesiphon's decree (§ 57.1).
5. e)/nnoma gra/fein: opposed to para/noma gra/fein: see note on grafa\s, §249.3.

6. ta\s eu)qu/nas e)peshmai/nesqe, put your seal on my accounts: this probably refers to the official seal of the dikasth/rion before which Demosth. appeared to render his accounts (eu)/qunai) at the end of each term of office. See Aristotle, Pol. Ath. 48.18, 54.6.
10. to\n dh=mon tiqe/menon: this re- peated approval of the people refers to the votes mentioned in § 248.

11. dikasta\s: sc. tiqeme/nous. The present judges are addressed
above (6) as if they had themselves judged the previous cases.—th\n a)lh/qeian: with special emphasis, after to\n dh=mon and tou\s dikasta\s.

This passage is a dignified and fitting conclusion to the line of argument beginning with § 227 concerning the orator's account (logismo/s) with the state. Now, after a brief allusion (§ 251) to the case of Cephalus, he passes to another matter.

1. to\ tou= *kefa/lou kalo\n may be exclamatory, there is the glory of Cephalus; cf. l. 6. But kalo\n is generally taken here as predicate to to\ tou= *kefa/lou (sc. e)sti/). (See Aesch. III. 194.) This Cephalus (already mentioned in § 219.3) is not the father of Lysias, who opens the dialogue of Plato's Republic with Socrates and was e)pi\ gh/raos ou)dw=| in the lifetime of Socrates; but a later statesman, who with Thrasybulus of Collytus was a leader of the Theban party in Athens, and highly respected. —to\...feu/gein, the (glory of) never being under indictment. Aeschines (194), after mentioning the boast of Aristophon that he had been acquitted (a)pe/fugen) seventy-five times on the grafh\ parano/mwn, compares this with the higher boast of Cephalus, that he had proposed more decrees than any other man, and yet had never once been indicted by this process.
5. pro/s ge tou=ton, so far as this man is concerned; i.e. Aeschines has done nothing to prevent me from making the boast of Cephalus.
7. e)di/wce grafh\n, prosecuted an indictment, cognate accusative, as in e)gra/yato grafh/n. The English translation obscures the construction.
8. mhde\n ei)=nai: see M.T. 685.

§§ 252—275. Here Demosthenes replies at great length to scattered remarks of Aeschines about his “bad fortune,” which involved in calamity every person, state, or thing which he touched. Though Aeschines refers only to his general fortune, Demosthenes chooses to speak chiefly of his fortunes in life, which he compares with those of his opponent. He concludes (§§ 270—275) with some forcible remarks on his fortune in the other sense.
1. a)gnwmosu/nhn (cf. §§ 94.2, 207.7), want of feeling.

3. peri\ th=s tu/xhs: see Aesch. III. 114, 157, 158, with 135, 136; cf. § 212
(above).—o(/lws me\n is opposed to the special exception, e)peidh\ d' ou(=tos (8).
4. profe/rei, taunts with.

5. h(
, after suggesting the object of e)/xein, is the object of oi)=den.— be/ltista pra/ttein: superlative of eu)= pra/ttein. See Soph. O.C. 567: e)/coid' a)nh w)
 xw/ti th=s e)s au)/rion ou)de
 ple/on moi sou= me/testin h(me/ras (Weil).

9. u(perhfa/nws, arrogantly: op- posed to a)nqrwpinw/teron, more humanly, i.e. more as one man should speak of another: cf. o(/stis...profe/rei (4).—xrh=tai tw| lo/gw|: cf. ei) dikai/ws xrh/somai tw=| lo/gw|, § 233.8.

1. th\n...tu/xhn: the general good fortune of Athens, as it is here understood, is not mere chance or luck (as in §§ 207.7 and 306.6), but the result of divine protection and the care of the Gods. See the poem on Solon, quoted in XIX. 255, which begins

p.foreign: *(hmete/ra de\ po/lis kata\ me\n *dio\s ou)/pot' o)lei=tai
ai)=san kai\ maka/rwn qew=n fre/nas a)qa- na/twn:
toi/h ga\r mega/qumos e)pi/skopos o)brimo- pa/trh

div2.p:
*palla\s *)aqhnai/h xei=ras u(/perqen e)/xei: with the orator's comment (256), e)gw\ d' a)ei\ me
 a)lhqh= to
 lo/gon tou=ton h(gou=mai kai\ bou/lomai, w(s a)/r) oi( qeoi\ sw/|zousin h(mw=n th
 po/lin. So IV. 12: (th=s tu/xhs) h(/per a)ei\ be/ltion h)\ h(mei=s h(mw=n au)tw=n e)pimelou/meqa.

3. to
...*dwdwnai=on: cf. Il. XVI. 233, *zeu= a)/na *dwdwnai=e, *pelasgike\, thlo/qi nai/wn, in the prayer of Achilles. Oracles sent from Dodona to Athens are quoted by Demosthenes, XXI. 53; cf. XIX. 299, o( *zeu\s, h( *diw/nh (the Queen of Zeus at Dodona), pa/ntes oi( qeoi/. At this time Dodona was probably more revered at Athens because of the Macedonian influence at Delphi: cf. Aesch. III. 130, *dhmosqe/nhs de\ a)nte/lege, filippi/zein th
 *puqi/an fa/skwn, a)pai/deutos w)
 k.t.l.
4. tw=n pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn, man- kind in general, as opposed to Athens alone.

5. pollw=n kakw=n: witness the destruction of Thebes by Alexander; and the overthrow of the Persian Empire, which was then going on. See Aesch. III. 132, 133; in 134 he includes Athens in the general bad fortune which she owes to the baneful influence of Demosthenes.

1. to\ proele/sqai ta\ ka/l- lista, our choice of the most glorious course: the whole sentence through a)/meinon pra/ttein is the subject of ei)=nai (5), i.e. he includes all this in the special good fortune of Athens.
2. tw=n oi)hqe/ntwn introduces ei) pro/oinq' ...dia/cein in or. obl.: the gen. depends on a)/meinon pra/ttein (4).

4. au)tw=n: intensive with tw=n *(el- lh/nwn, than those very Greeks; almost reiterative.—a)/meinon pra/ttein: cf. be/ltistapra/ttein, § 252.5.—th=s tu/xhs with ei)=nai ti/qhmi: see I. 10, to\ me\n ga\r polla\ a)polwleke/nai...th=s h(mete/ras a)melei/as a)/n tis qei/h dikai/ws. ti/qhmi in this sense takes the infinitive regularly in or. obl.: see Aesch. III. 163, bou/lei se qw= fobhqh=nai kai\ xrh/sasqai tw=| sautou= tro/pw|;

5. to\ de\ proskrou=sai kai\ mh\... sumbh=nai, i.e. our disaster (euphemistically called collision) and our not having everything done as we wished: this is the object of meteilhfe/nai, with to\...me/ros as appositive, this I believe that our city has received as the share of the general (bad) fortune of the rest of mankind which falls to our lot.
7. to\ e)piba/llon me/ros: cf. to\ gigno/menon, the quota, § 104.5. Cf. e)piba/llei, § 272.3.

2. e)n toi=s i)di/ois: Aesch. had sought for the fortune of Demosth. e)n toi=s dhmosi/ois, as in III. 114, sumbe/bhken au)tw=| o(/tou a)\n prosa/yhtai... tou/twn e(ka/stous a)nia/tois sumforai=s periba/llein.
4. a)ciw=, judge: ou(twsi\ a)ciw==tou=to a)/cion ei)=nai nomi/zw.
5. nomi/zw u(mi=n: sc. dokei=n.
5. yuxro/thta, coldness, want of feeling.
7. e)n a)fqo/nois, in affluence.
8. xalepou=, harsh, stronger than yuxrou=.

10. e)k tw=n...metriw/tata, as mod- erately as the state of the case (ta\ e)no/nta) will permit. We have again an apology, perhaps an honest one, for the personal vituperation which follows, §§ 257—262.
1. u(ph=rcen: the subjects are didaskalei=a and the infinitives e)/xein and pra/ttein, with e(le/sqai (9). Most MSS. (not *s and L.1) insert me\n o)/nti foita=n ei)s after paidi/.

2, 3. prosh/konta, i.e. such as chil- dren of the better classes attended: one of the charges against his guardian Aphobus (XXVII. 46) is tou\s didaska/lous tou\s misqou\s a)peste/rhke.—to\n ...poih/sonta=o(\s poih/sei, he who is to do etc. (M.T. 527, 530).—ai)sxro\n, i.e. a)neleu/qeron: this idea of the ignobility of toil is a commonplace with the Greeks, as a slave-holding people. Cf. Ar. Av. 1432, ti/ ga\r pa/qw; ska/ptein ga\r ou)k e)pi/stamai.

4. a)ko/louqa pra/ttein is explained by the rest of the clause, xorhgei=n... xrh/simon ei)=nai.—xorhgei=n, trihrarxei=n: testimony about all his lh|tourgi/ai is given in § 267. He was xorhgo/s in 350 B.C., when he was assaulted by Midias (XXI. 13 ff.); for his numerous trierarchies see XXI. 78, 154, Aesch. III. 51, 52, and cf. § 99.11 (above).

5. ei)sfe/rein, to pay the ei)sfora/, or property-tax: this was assessed “progressively,” the richer being taxed on a larger proportion (ti/mhma) of their actual property than the poorer. (See Eisphora in Smith's Dict. Antiq.) The guardians of Demosthenes, to conceal their peculations, continued to enroll their ward in the highest class, so that he paid taxes on a ti/mhma of one-fifth of his property (ou)si/a), whereas he should have been placed in a much lower class after the inroads upon the estate. See XXVII. 7 and XXVIII. 4.
9. w(/ste, with perfect and present infinitive: M.T. 590, 109.
11. a(\ proeilo/mhn, i.e. th\n e)mh\n proai/resin: cf. § 190.5.
2. sumbebi/wka...ei)pei=n: an accidental dactylic hexameter.— po/ll' a)\n e)/xwn=po/ll' a)\n e)/xoimi, though I might etc.: cf. § 138.1, 2.
3. fulatto/menos to\ luph=sai (M.T. 374): the object infinitive takes the place of mh\ luph/sw, which in use had become an object clause (M.T. 303 C).
7. pro\s tw=| didaskalei/w|: see notes on § 129.2-4.
8. prosedreu/wn, attending (as a servant).—to\ me/lan tri/bwn: the ink was probably rubbed from a cake (like India ink) and mixed with water.

9. paidagwgei=on, probably a room in which the paidagwgoi/, slaves who brought the boys to and from school, waited for these to be ready to go home: later it was used like didaskalei=on for a schoolroom.—oi)ke/tou... e)/xwn: the mention of these menial duties implies the same condition of father and son as appears in § 129.

In this section and § 260 we have a lively comic description, highly caricatured, of some Asiatic ceremonies of initiation, in which the mother of Aeschines is said to have taken part. This was some form of Bacchic worship, with perhaps a mixture of Orphic mysteries. It seems there was a written service (ta\s bi/blous), which Aeschines read like a clerk while his mother officiated as priestess. The initiation of Strepsiades into the Socratic mysteries (Ar. Nub. 255—262) probably caricatures some similar worship.

1. th=| mhtri\ telou/sh|: see XIX. 281, *glaukoqe/as th=s tou\s qia/sous sunagou/shs, e)f' oi(=s e(te/ra te/qnhken i(e/reia, and cf. 249. In XIX. 199 we have ta\s bi/blous a)nagignw/skonta/ se th=| mhtri\ telou/sh|, kai\ pai=d' o)/nt) e)n qia/sois kai\ mequ/ousin a)nqrw/pois kalindou/menon.

2. ta)/lla suneskeuwrou=, you helped to conduct the rest of the ceremony:
skeuwrou=mai is properly look after skeu/h (of any kind), and generally manage, direct, devise, concoct (often in a bad sense): cf. IX. 17 ta\ e)n *peloponnh/sw| skeuwrou/menon (of Philip).

3. nebri/zwn and krathri/zwn are probably transitive and govern tou\s teloume/nous, like kaqai/rwn, a)poma/ttwn, and a)nista/s, i.e. dressing them in fawnskins and drenching them with wine. See Eur. Bacch. 24, nebri/d' e)ca/yas xroo/s, and Sandys' note. They are sometimes taken as neuter, meaning dressing yourself in a fawnskin and pouring out wine.
4. a)poma/ttwn...pitu/rois, i.e. plastering them over with clay and then rubbing them clean with bran.
5. a)nista\s: the victim is sup- posed to be sitting during the operation, like Strepsiades (Nub. 256).— kaqarmou=: the process was a purification and also a charm.

6. keleu/wn, subordinate to a)nista\s: i.e. making him get up as he bids him say, etc.—e)/fugon kako\n, eu(=ron a)/meinon: this formula was borrowed from initiations and other ceremonies of a higher character, meaning that a new life was opened as the result of the ceremony just ended. Suidas gives (under e)/fugon...a)/meinon): ta/ttetai e)pi\ tw=n a)po\ kakou= ei)s krei=tton e)lqo/ntwn. The saying originally referred to the change from the acorns and thistles of primitive life to the more civilized bread, and was used at weddings and other ceremonies. The words form a paroemiac, and probably belonged to some metrical formula.

7. o)lolu/cai, used especially of cries or shouts in religious worship or prayers: see Od. IV. 767, w(s ei)pou=s' o)lo/luce (after a prayer): Aeschyl. Eum. 1043, o)lolu/cate nu=n e)pi\ molpai=s: Eur. Bacch. 689, w)lo/lucen e)n me/sais staqei=sa *ba/kxais.

8. fqe/ggesqai me/ga: the strong voice of Aeschines is often mentioned by Demosthenes; see below, §§ 280, 285.6, 291.6, 313.7, and especially XIX. 206—208, 216, 337—340; in XIX. 216 he says, mhde/ ge ei) kalo\n kai\ me/ga ou(=tos fqe/gcetai, mhd' ei) fau=lon e)gw/, alluding to his own weakness of voice.

1. e)n de\ tai=s h(me/rais implies that the ceremonies just described were performed by night.— qia/sous, used especially of Bacchanals; see Eur. Bacch. 680, o(rw= de\ qia/sous trei=s gunaikei/wn xorw=n.

2. tw=| mara/qw| kai\ th=| leu/kh|: from ma/raqon, fennel, Marathon is said to have been named (cf. Strab. p. 160): for the fondness of serpents for it, see Ael. Hist. Animal. IX. 16. For serpents in the Bacchic worship, see Eur. Bacch. 102, 697. The white poplar, leu/kh, populus alba, is men
tioned in Ar. Nub. 1007. See Bekk. Anecd. p. 279: h( de\ leu/kh to\ me\n tw=n fu/llwn e)/xei leuko\n to\ d' e(/teron me/lan, su/mbolo/n ti tou= bi/ou kai\ tou= qana/tou.

3. tou\s parei/as: see Harpocr., parei=ai o)noma/zontai/ tines o)/feis para\ to\ parei/as mei/zous e)/xein, and Ael. Hist. An. VIII. 12, o( parei/as h)\ parou/as purro\s th\n xro/an, eu)wpo\s to\ o)/mma, platu\s to\ sto/ma, dakei=n ou) sfalero\s a)lla\ pra=|os. These harmless snakes were thus sacred to Aesculapius, and were named parei=ai from their fat cheeks. See Ar. Plut. 690.

4. eu)oi= saboi=: as eu)oi=, evoe, was the cry used in the regular Bacchic worship, so saboi= was used in invoking *saba/zios, the Phrygian Bacchus. All points to some Asiatic worship, more or less caricatured.

5. u(h=s a)/tths a)/tths u(h=s: these mystic words stand as a cognate accusative with e)porxou/menos; this is what he danced.—e)/carxos kai\ prohgemw\n designates Aeschines as leader of the song or dance or both.

6. kittofo/ros, ivy-bearer, the ivy being sacred to Bacchus.—liknofo/ros, bearer of the winnowing-fan, li/knon, the mystica vannus Iacchi. See Verg. Georg. I. 166.—kai\ toiau=q), i.e. these (e)/carxos k.t.l.) and similar names.

8. e)/nqrupta, streptou\s, sops, twists: for e)/nqrupta see the Schol., ywmoi\ oi)/nw| bebregme/noi. streptou/s: plakou=ntos ei)=dos (Harpocr.), evidently from stre/fw.—neh/lata: acc. to Harpocration, barley buns, made of newly-ground (roasted) barley, soaked in honey and covered with plums and chick-peas.

1. ei)s tou\s dhmo/tas e)ne- gra/fhs: each deme was responsible for the correctness of its lhciarxiko\n grammatei=on, or list of citizens. Aristotle's Constitution of Athens (42.2) gives us clear information on the whole subject of the enrolment of new citizens.

2. o(pwsdh/pote, somehow, with e)peidh/ g' e)negra/fhs, refers to the story that his father was a slave, in which case it would have been impossible for the son to be legally enrolled as a citizen without an affirmative vote of 6000 in the Assembly; while the safeguards against illegal enrolment would have made this almost impossible.

4. grammateu/ein: see §§ 162.5, 209.2. The occupation of a paid private clerk (not that of a clerk of the Senate or Assembly) was despised at Athens: see § 127.3, o)/leqros grammateu/s.—
a)rxidi/ois, petty officers: a)rxi/dion is here diminutive of a)rxh/ in the sense of a)/rxwn. See Aesch. III. 21, a)rxh\n u(peu/qunon mh\ a)podhmei=n.
7. tw=n prou+phrgme/nwn, of your antecedents.
2. toi=s barusto/nois, the heavy groaners.

3. *simu/kka| (so *s): Theophrastus (Athen. VIII. 348 A) mentions *simmu/kan to\n u(pokrith/n.—e)tritagwni/steis: a company of strolling actors, such as performed at the country festivals, was probably composed of two men, who played the first and second parts and hired another to play the third parts.

4. su=ka...xwri/wn: the meaning of these much disputed words seems to be, that the band of players subsisted chiefly on the fruit which Aeschines, as their hired servant, collected from the neighbouring farms by begging, stealing, or buying, as he found most convenient. He is compared to a small fruiterer (o)pwrw/nhs), who each morning collects his load of fruit from farms which he has hired, or wherever else he can get it cheapest. Pollux (VI. 128) includes o)pwrw/nhs (with pornobosko/s and a)llantopw/lhs) in his long list of bi/oi e)f' oi(=s a)/n tis o)neidisqei/h.
5. plei/w...a)gw/nwn, getting more (profit) from these than from your plays (contests).

6. ou(\s (cogn. acc.)...h)gwni/zesqe, which you played at the risk of your lives (or in which you fought for your lives), with a pun on the two meanings of a)gw/n and a)gwni/zomai, fight and play: see IV. 47 tw=n strathgw=n e(/kastos di\s kai\ tri\s kri/netai par' u(mi=n peri\ qana/tou, pro\s de\ tou\s e)xqrou\s ou)dei\s ou)de\ a(/pac au)tw=n a)gwni/sasqai peri\ qana/tou tolma=|, where there is a similar pun on beingtried (a)gwni/zesqai) for their lives in court and in battle.
7. a)/spondos kai\ a)kh/ruktos, with- out truce or herald, i.e. implacable, without even the common decencies of civilized warfare.

9. trau/mat' ei)lhfw\s: see XIX. 337, o(/te me\n ta\ *que/stou kai\ tw=n e)pi\ *troi/a| kaka\ h)gwni/zeto, e)ceba/llete au)to\n kai\ e)cesuri/ttete e)k tw=n qea/trwn, kai\ mo/non ou) kateleu/ete ou(/tws w(/ste teleutw=nta tou= tritagwnistei=n a)posth=nai. This account of the po/lemos makes trau/mat) here perfectly intelligible; but the reading tou/twn trau/mata in 6 (which all MSS. except *s have) makes endless difficulty and confusion. If trau/mata in 6 is referred to wounds received in stealing fruit, compared with those received on the
stage or after the play, there is a strange repetition of the latter; if there is a reference (as Westermann suggests) to fruit used in pelting the actors, it is hard to see how figs, grapes, and olives could endanger the lives of the “heavy groaners.”
10. w(s deilou\s skw/pteis: see § 245.2.

Demosthenes (XIX. 246, 247) says that Aeschines was a tritagwnisth/s also to actors of high repute, as Theodorus and Aristodemus; and he reminds him of the time when he used to play the part of Creon in the Antigone with these actors. He adds the following: e)n a(/pasi toi=s dra/masi toi=s tragikoi=s e)cai/reto/n e)stin w(/sper ge/ras toi=s tritagwnistai=s to\ tou\s tura/nnous kai\ tou\s ta\ skh=ptr' e)/xontas ei)sie/nai.
4. politei/an, position in public life.—kai\ emphasizes the rest of the clause, tou=t' ...poih=sai, i.e. when at last you took it into your head to try this.

6. lagw\ bi/on e)/zhs: Weil quotes Trag. frag. incert. 373 (N.), lagw\ bi/on zh=|s, o( pri\n a)/tromos le/wn. “Dicuntur leporis vitam vivere qui semper anxii trepidique vivunt; nam ut est apud Herod. III. 108, o( lago\s u(po\ panto\s qhreu/etai qhri/ou kai\ o)/rniqos kai\ a)nqrw/pou, ac ne somnum quidem capit nisi oculis apertis” (Dissen).
8. qrasu\s w)\n...w)=yai (M.T. 884): personal passive construction.

1. xili/wn a)poqano/ntwn, at Chaeronea: see Diod. XVI. 86, tw=n d' *)aqhnai/wn e)/peson me\n e)n th=| ma/xh| plei/ous tw=n xili/wn, h(/lwsan de\ ou)k e)la/ttous tw=n disxili/wn. See Lycurg. Leocr. 142, xi/lioi tw=n u(mete/rwn politw=n e)n *xairwnei/a| e)teleu/thsan, kai\ dhmosi/a| au)tou\s h( po/lis e)/qayan. Diod. XVI. 88 quotes an eloquent passage of the speech of Lycurgus at the trial of Lysicles, one of the Athenian commanders at Chaeronea, who was condemned to death.
5. proso/nt' ai)sxra\ tou/tw|: cf. § 276.5.
6. eu)xerw=s le/gein, to be ready to tell: cf. § 70.7.

In §§ 265, 266, the orator sums up vigorously the substance of §§ 257—264. Westermann points out that each of the five stages of the life of Aeschines is mentioned in order, when he was (1) a schoolmaster's assistant (§ 258), (2) initiator (§§ 259, 260), (3) scribe (§ 261), (4) actor (§ 262), (5) politician (§§ 263, 264). Many ancientrhetoricians quote these famous antitheses with approval and admiration. We are again shocked by the open avowal of the disgrace of earning an honest living; the ancients were certainly more honest than many of our generation in expressing this.
1. ta\...bebiwme/na: passive of a(\... bebiw/kamen (cf. § 130.1).
4. e)foi/twn, went to school: cf. Ar. Nub. 916, dia\ se\ de\ foita=n ou)dei\s e)qe/lei tw=n meiraki/wn.
5. e)telou/mhn, probably into the Eleusinian mysteries.
6. e)ce/piptes: e)kpi/ptein, exigi, is used as a passive to e)kba/llein; cf. XIX. 337, and Arist. Poet. 17.2, 18.15.

2. u(pe\r...dokima/zomai: dokimasi/a is any investigation to test the fitness or competency of a person for anything, as for office (its ordinary meaning) or for citizenship; and dokima/zomai here implies that this trial is to test his fitness for the crown.
3. to\...a)dikei=n a)nwmolo/ghmai: cf. § 86.2, a)nwmolo/ghmai ta\ a)/rista pra/ttein. The articular infinitive in or. obl. is rare (M.T. 794, 743).
4. soi\ u(pa/rxei, it is in store for you.—kinduneu/eis corresponds to dokima/zomai (2): the meaning is, the question with you is.
5. tou=to poiei=n, i.e. to go on being a sukofa/nths.—pepau=sqai, to be stopped (once for all), i.e. by a)timi/a (cf. § 82.9).

6. to\ pe/mpton me/ros: Dindorf omits pe/mpton because it is omitted in §§ 103, 222, 250, whereas it appears in other speeches frequently (e.g. XXII. 3). What modern orator or writer would submit to such rules of consistency as critics impose on the ancients?

1. fe/re...a)nagnw= (M.T. 257): the orator does not read the testimony himself; cf. le/ge (9).— lh|tourgiw=n: this includes the public services mentioned in xorhgei=n and trihrarxei=n in § 257.4,5, but not ei)sfe/rein, as the property tax was not a lh|tourgi/a. For the form lh|tourgi/a see note on § 108.3.
3. e)lumai/nou, used to outrage: cf. e)pe/triyas, § 180.6.
4. h(/kw...pu/las: the Hecuba of Euripides begins
h(/kw nekrw=n keuqmw=na kai\ sko/tou pu/las lipw\n, i(/n' *(/aidhs xwri\s w)/|kistai qew=n, *polu/dwros, *(eka/bhs pai=s.
All MSS. except *s have lipw/n for nekrw=n, making the sense of the quotation complete. But such a change is unlikely in quoting so familiar a verse.

6. kakaggelei=n...me: this verse is otherwise unknown. kakaggelei=n must be pres. infin. of kakaggele/w (otherwise unknown), depending on qe/lonta. The readings of the best MSS., kakagge/llein or ka/k' a)gge/llein (*s), are metrically impossible. The common reading is ka/k' a)ggelei=n, an irregular fut. infin. with qe/lonta (see M.T. 113).

7. The words kako\n kakw=s se... a)pole/seian are probably an adaptation of a verse quoted from Lynceus by Athenaeus, IV. 150 C, kako\s kakw=s se/<g)> a)pole/seian oi( qeoi/, or both may go back to the source of Ar. Eq. 2, 3, kakw=s *pafla/gona...a)pole/seian oi( qeoi/. See Blass.
8. ponhro\n: with both poli/thn and tritagwnisth/n.
2. koino\s, in public rela- tions, public spirited, in private matters (as here), devoted, at the service of all: cf. Isoc. I. 10, toi=s fi/lois koino/s.
3. e)parkw=n, i.e. ready to help.— ou)de\n a)\n ei)/poimi, I had rather not mention anything.

5. ei)/ tinas e)lusa/mhn: these were Athenians captured by Philip at Olynthus in 348 B.C., whom Demosthenes
ransomed at Pella in 346 (Hist. § 30). See XIX. 166—170. Dem. lent various sums to these prisoners, which they paid for their ransoms; when afterwards Philip set the other prisoners free without ransom, Dem. forgave the first their debts to him (e)/dwka dwrea\n ta\ lu/tra), which otherwise they would have been strictly required by law to pay (XIX. 170).

6. sunece/dwka, i.e. helped poor citizens to endow their daughters: giving a dowry was an important part of giving a daughter in marriage. —ou)/te...ou)de/n, nor anything else of the kind. These words are rather loosely connected with the preceding clauses with ou)/te: in all three ou)/te repeats the negative of ou)de
 a)
 ei)/poimi k.t.l., so that the construction here is ou)/te a)
 ei)/poimi tw=n toiou/twn ou)de/n.
1. u(pei/lhfa: cf. pass. u(pei/lhmmai (8).—e)gw\...dei=n: an iambic trimeter.
3. poih/sant): sc. eu)=.—e)pilelh=- sqai: cf. pepau=sqai, § 266.5.
4. mikroyu/xou: see note on § 279.6.
5. u(pomimnh/|skein, i.e. to be always calling to mind.

6. mikrou= dei=n, the full form of mikrou=, almost (M.T. 779): cf. § 151.3. West. quotes Cic. Lael. XX. 71, odiosum sane genus hominum officia exprobrantium; quae meminisse debet is in quem collata sunt, non commemorare qui contulit; and Sen. Benef. II. 10, haec enim beneficii inter duos lex est: alter statim oblivisci debet dati, alter accepti nunquam; lacerat animum et premit frequens meritorum commemoratio. Pericles (Thuc. II. 40) looks at the matter from a different point of view: ou) ga\r pa/sxontes eu)= a)lla\ drw=ntes ktw/meqa tou\s fi/lous: k.t.l. There is a New England saying, “If a man does you a favour, he follows you with a tomahawk all your lifetime.”
8. proaxqh/somai: cf. proh/xqhn (sc. ta/cai), VIII. 71.—o(/pws u(pei/lhmmai, as I have been understood, i.e. the general opinion which has been formed of me.
9. a)rkei= moi: sc. ou(/tws u(peilh=fqai.

§§ 270—275. We have here a sort of peroration to the discourse on Fortune (§§252—275), in which the orator comes at last to the precise point of his opponent's remark, that Demosthenes has brought ill-luck upon every person or state with which he had to do (Aesch. III. 114). Hitherto Demosthenes has spoken
far more of his “fortunes” than of his “fortune.” See remarks before notes on § 252.
3. u(po\ tou=ton to\n h(/lion, as we say, under the Sun (poetic). See Il. v. 267, o(/ssoi e)/asin u(p' h)w= t) h)e/lio/n te: Od. XV. 349, zw/ousin u(p' au)ga\s h)eli/oio.
4. a)qw=|os, unharmed: cf. § 125.1, where we have the original meaning, free from qwh/, penalty, as in XXIII. 78, tau/ths me\n (di/khs) a)qw=|os a)fi/etai, he is acquitted.
5. dunastei/as: see §§ 67.2, 3, 322.7, with notes.

8. pa/ntwn gegenh=sqai, has fallen to the lot of us all: pa/ntwn refers to all the Athenians, opposed to tw=n mhdepw/pot' i)do/ntwn e)me/ in § 271.1. He might admit (he implies) that his own fortune had extended to Athens, were it not that foreign states had suffered the same ill fortune.
3. kat' a)/ndra, i.e. indi- viduals, as opposed to po/leis and e)/qnh.

6. fora/n tina pragma/twn, a rush of events: fora/ in this sense (impetus) belongs to fe/romai, used as in bi/a| fe/retai, Plat. Phaedr. 254 A, and fero/menos, with a rush (M.T. 837): fora/n, crop, in § 61.2, belongs to fe/rw, bear, produce.—ou)x oi(/an e)/dei, not what it should be (present in time, M.T. 417); e)/dei here is ought to be (but is not).
3. e)piba/llei: see note on to\ e)piba/llon me/ros, § 254.7.
4. a(/pasi: sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois (cf. pa/ntwn, § 270.8).
5. ei) me\n...e)bouleuo/mhn is past, while h)=n a)/n, its apodosis, is present. —kat' e)mauto\n au)tokra/twr, an absolute autocrat: cf. au)to\s au)tokra/twr, § 235.5.

2. e)n koinw=|...prou)ti/qei skopei=n, put forward for public consideration: cf. IV. 1, ei) peri\ kainou= tinos pra/gmatos prou)ti/qeto le/gein. See § 192.2, proti/qhsi boulh/n, and § 236.4, e)c i)/sou prou)ti/qete. gnw/mas protiqe/nai often means to open a debate: cf. Thuc. I. 139.18, and III. 38.2, tw=n proqe/ntwn au)=qis le/gein, where le/gein is like skopei=n here.
4. e)p' eu)noi/a|, out of devotion, cor- responds to a)lla\ h(ttw/menos (7).—e)moi\ is dative of advantage with parexw/reis, but is also felt with e)p' eu)noi/a|.
5. zh/lou, pride: see § 120.6.
9. w(=n: with belti/w.

Westermann thinks the argument of this section not quite fair, as it is not to be assumed that Aeschines assented to all which he did not oppose. But, apart from the obvious irony of parts of the argument (as in ou) ga\r e)p' eu)noi/a| k.t.l.), it was surely not too much to expect of the acknowledged “leader of the opposition” in such a desperate crisis, that he should at least protest strongly against measures of such vital importance as those which he censures afterwards, even if he could not propose any positive measures himself. Now it is an important part of the argument of Demosthenes, that Aeschines said nothing whatever on such occasions as the sudden seizure of Elatea by Philip. See § 191.5, sou= d' a)fw/nou...kaqhme/nou: see the whole passage, §§ 188—191. The only ground on which such neglect can be excused is the one here assumed, that the opposition had no better plan to propose. The plain truth is, of course, that Aeschines really wished to let Philip have his own way at this time.
1. para\...a)nqrw/pois: see two similar cases of para/ in § 297.4, 6. —toi=s a)/llois pa=sin, i.e. all except Aesch.
2. ta\ toiau=ta, i.e. such (prin- ciples) as the following, explained by the statements in 3—8.

3. a)dikei= tis e(kw/n, a man (let us suppose) is guilty of voluntary injustice. We have three such suppositions in independent sentences, with paratactic replies or apodoses. For a similar arrangement see § 117, e)pe/dwka, h)=rxon, a)di/kws h)=rca, with the replies. See also § 198.7—9.
o)rgh\n kai\ timwri/an: sc. diwrisme/- nhn o(rw=.
5. ou)/t' a)dikw=n tis ou)/t) e)camarta/- nwn, i.e. one who neither is guilty of injustice nor errs (sc. a)kw/n).
7. meq' a(pa/ntwn, i.e. in common with everybody.
8. suna/xqesqai, sympathize with him.
2. toi=s no/mois (without e)n *s, AI), by the laws: cf. XX. 57, tau=ta kai\ no/mois tisi\ kai\ do/cais diw/ristai.

3. toi=s a)gra/fois nomi/mois, by the principles of unwritten law, further explained by toi=s a)nqrwpi/nois h)/qesi: cf. § 114.2. The unwritten law is known as the law of Nature, the moral law, the divine law, or the higher law, the law which is not alia lex Romae, alia Athenis. Aristotle distinguishes two kinds of unwritten law, one the koino\s no/mos, o( kata\ fu/sin, the universal law of Nature, the other a branch of the special law of particular States, by which the defects of the written law may be remedied, that is, to\ e)pieike/s, equity. See Rhet. I. 13. As an example of the universal law he quotes Antig. 456, 457, ou) ga/r ti...e)c o(/tou f)a/nh, and the verses of Empedocles:

p.foreign: a)lla\ to\ me\n pa/ntwn no/mimon dia/ t' eu)rume/dontos

div2.p: ai)qe/ros h)neke/ws te/tatai dia/ t' a)ple/- tou au)= gh=s.
5. w)mo/thti: cf. w)mo/teros, § 212.9.
6. w(s a)tuxhma/twn: see Aesch. III. 57, tw=n de\ a)tuxhma/twn a(pa/ntwn *dhmosqe/nhn ai)/tion gegenhme/non.

§§ 276—296. Here Demosthenes begins by alluding to the attempt of Aeschines to represent him as a skilful sophist and rhetorician, who will impose on the judges by his wily arts. He retorts by showing that his own oratorical power has always been exerted in behalf of Athens, while that of Aeschines has been used to help her enemies or to gratify personal malice. He refers to the testimony of the citizens in choosing him to deliver the eulogy on those who fell at Chaeronea, as a proof of his patriotism. Finally, he declares that the present calamities of Greece have been caused by men of the stamp of Aeschines in various Greek states; and he gives a black list of these traitors who have betrayed their countries to the common enemy.

1. w(/sper...ei)rhkw\s, i.e. posing as one who had always spoken his own thoughts honestly and loyally: we generally translate (for con
venience) as if he had spoken (quasi vero dixisset, West.), though there is nothing conditional in the participle with w(/sper, which merely expresses comparison (M.T. 867): having, as it were, spoken, would be more correct, though less clear. See w(/sper ou)x, § 323.7, and note on w(s (5).

3. e)ke/leuen: sc. u(ma=s.—o(/pws mh\ parakrou/somai: the subject of the object clause appears by attraction (e)me\) in the leading clause (M.T. 304.2). This is a reply to Aesch. 16, 174, 206, 207, and other passages.

5—7. w(s...ou(/tws e)/xonta (accus. abs., M.T. 853), i.e. assuming that this must needs be so. w(s has no more conditional force than w(/sper (1), though we often find it convenient to use as if in translation (M.T. 864): notice ou)ke/ti with skeyome/nous, will not further consider, showing that there is nothing conditional in the expression. ta\ proso/nq' e(autw=|, i.e. things which are true of himself (cf. prosei=nai, l. 10).

2. e)/stw ga/r, well! grant that I have it. Having broken his sentence, he proceeds to say that the hearers have it in their power to neutralize the highest gifts of eloquence by refusing to listen. See XIX. 340, ai( me\n toi/nun a)/llai duna/meis e)pieikw=s ei)sin au)ta/rkeis, h( de\ tou=le/gein, a)\n ta\ par' u(mw=n tw=n a)kouo/ntwn a)ntisth=|, diako/ptetai.
4. w(s a)\n...pro\s e(/kaston e)/xht) eu)noi/as, i.e. according to your goodwill towards each, eu)noi/as being partitive with w(s, as in ei)s tou=to eu)noi/as. (G. 1092.) Cf. Thuc. I. 22.
5. ou(/tws fronei=n, i.e. eu)= or kakw=s fronei=n.
6. e)mpeiri/a, substituted modestly for the stronger deino/thta of l. 2, the original construction being resumed by tau/thn (7).
7. e)cetazome/nhn u(pe\r u(mw=n, mar- shalled on your side, the familiar military figure: see notes on § 173.5 and § 173.6.
9. tou)nanti/on (adv.): sc. e)cetazome/- nhn eu(rh/sete.

11. kata\ tou/twn (sc. tw=| le/gein), opposed to u(pe\r tw=n e)xqrw=n. tou/twn refers loosely to tis: see § 99.3 and II. 18, ei)/ tis...tou/tous. We are all familiar with anybody becoming them in conversation. The whole expression ei)/ tis e)lu/phse/ ti...kata\ tou/twn (gratifying private grudges) is opposed to ou)d' i)di/a| (8), as u(pe\r tw=n e)xqrw=n is opposed to u(pe\r u(mw=n (8).
3. u(pe\r tw=n koinw=n, with ei)selhluqo/tas, i.e. who have come into court to give judgment for the public good, opposed to o)rgh\n...bebaiou=n.
4. a)ciou=n au(tw=| bebaiou=n, to ask (them) to confirm for him, i.e. by condemning his opponent.
5. u(pe\r tou/twn, for these ends, i.e. to gratify his o)rgh/ or e)/xqra.
6. ma/lista me\n, best of all.—ei) d' a)/r) a)na/gkh, i.e. but if after all he must have these feelings. Cf. § 178.12.
7. e)n ti/sin...dei=; when should an orator use all his vehemence?
9. tw=n o(/lwn ti, any of the supreme (entire) interests of the state: cf. §§ 28.9, 303.9.
10. e)sti\ tw=| dh/mw|, the people are concerned, etc.
11. e)n tou/tois: with strongest emphasis, in reply to e)n ti/sin;
Still answering the ques- tion e)n ti/sin...dei=; (§ 278.7), he describes the present suit as one which does not justify vehemence in an orator.
2. mhd' i)di/ou (sc. a)dikh/matos) con- tinues the construction of dhmosi/ou: cf. VIII. 39, 40, e)xqro\s o(/lh| th=| po/lei... prosqh/sw de\ kai\ toi=s e)n th=| po/lei pa=sin a)nqrw/pois.

3. stefa/nou...kathgori/an, an ac- cusation against a crown and a vote of thanks (e)pai/nou) (i.e. against a proposition to confer these): nearly all decrees conferring a crown had the words e)paine/sai kai\ stefanw=sai.
4. suneskeuasm., having trumped up.
6. mikroyuxi/as, littleness of soul, opposed to megaloyuxi/a, § 68.4: cf. § 269.4.—ou)deno\s xrhstou=: neuter, cf. pa/nta ta\ xrhsta/, XX. 165.
7. tou\s...a)gw=nas e)a/santa with e)pi\ to/nd' h(/kein recurs to the idea of § 16.
8. kai\ strengthens pa=san, the very depth of baseness.
2. fwnaski/as, declama- tion (practice of voice): cf. § 308.10, and fwnaskh/sas and pefwnaskhkw/s in XIX. 255, 336.—tou=ton to\n a)gw=na, i.e. this form of suit (against Ctesiphon).
6. tau)ta\ proairei=sqai toi=s pol- loi=s: cf. §§ 281.6, 292.3.

4. tou/tous renews em- phatically the antecedent implied in a)f) w(=n.—ou)k...o(rmei= (sc. a)gku/ras), does not ride at the same anchor, an oft-quoted saying. See Harpocr. under ou)k e)pi\ th=s k.t.l., and Apostolius XIII. 55 (Paroem. Gr. 11. p. 591): both note the ellipsis of a)gku/ras. Another expression was e)pi\ duoi=n o(rmei= (sc. a)gku/rain), e)pi\ tw=n a)stemfw=s e)xo/ntwn (Apostol. VII. 61), to which Solon refers in his comparison of Athens with her two senates to a ship with two anchors: Plut. Sol. 19, oi)o/menos e)pi\ dusi\ boulai=s w(/sper a)gku/rais o(rmou=san h(=tton e)n sa/lw| th\n po/lin e)/sesqai. Cf. Soph. Ant. 188—190, quoted in XIX. 247.
5. ou)/koun ou)de\: the two negatives unite their force, and that of ou)=n, therefore, remains: ou)kou=n ou)de\ would give essentially the same sense.
6. o(ra=|s; see ou)x o(ra|s; §§ 232.5, 266.7, and ou) ga\r; § 136.2.—e)gw/: the ellipsis may be supplied from ou(/tws e)/xwn th\n yuxh\n (1), with the preceding to\...misei=n kai\ filei=n.
7. ei(lo/mhn, in the sense of proairei=sqai (§ 280.6).—e)cai/reton, exclusive.
1. a)=r' ou)=n ou)de\ su/; can the same be said also of you? i.e. ou)de\n ...pepoi/hsai.

2. presbeuth\s pro\s *fi/lippon: Aeschines (III. 227) says of this, th=s ma/xhs e)pigenome/nhs...u(pe\r th=s swthri/as th=s po/lews e)presbeu/omen. Aeschines, Demades (from whom the peace was named, § 285.6), and probably Phocion, went to Philip to negotiate a peace after Chaeronea. See Hist. § 68.

5. tau/thn th
 xrei/an: this, taken with to
 e)/mprosqe xro/non, refers to earlier personal intercourse with Philip. Aeschines is now less anxious to repudiate this charge, in the day of Alexander's great success in Asia: see III. 66, o( ga misale/candros nuni\ fa/skwn ei)=nai kai\ to/te misofi/lippos *dhmosqe/nhs, o( th
 ceni/an e)moi\ profe/rwn th
 *)aleca/ndrou, and cf. §§ 51, 52 (above).
6. o( mh\ le/gwn=o(\s mh\ le/gei.

7. katara=tai: a most compre- hensive curse (a)ra/) was a part of the religious ceremony at the opening of each meeting of the Senate and Assembly. See XXIII. 97: dio/per katara=tai kaq' e(ka/sthn e)kklhsi/an o( kh=ruc...ei)/ tis e)capata=| le/gwn h)\ boulh
 h)\ dh=mon h)\ th
 h(liai/an. Aeschines, as u(pogrammateu/wn u(mi=n kai\ u(phretw=n th=| boulh=|, had the duty of dictating this curse to the herald. See Dinarch. I. 47 (of Demosth.), kata/ratos de\ kaq' e(ka/sthn e)kklhsi/an gino/menos, e)celhlegme/nos dw=ra kata\ th=s po/lews ei)lhfw\s, e)chpathkw\s de\ kai\ to
 dh=mon kai\ th
 boulh
 para\ th
 a)ra
, kai\ e(/tera me
 le/gwn e(/tera de\ fronw=n, which shows that o( mh\ le/gwn a(\ fronei= (6) was included in the same curse. See note on § 130.2.
10. ou(=tos: cf. e)fa/nhn ou(=tos e)gw/, § 173.1.

4. w(/st' ou) memnh=sqai, (so) that they do not remember, not (so) as not to remember: this is a regular case of w(/ste ou) with the infinitive in indirect discourse, where the direct form would have been tosou=ton u(/pnon...e)/xousin w(/st' ou) me/mnhntai (M.T. 594).
5. e)n tw=| pole/mw|: opposed to meta\ th\n ma/xhn (§ 282.2) when Aeschines went on his embassy to Philip.

6. katarw/menos kai\ diomnu/menos, cursing (i.e. protesting, with curses on himself if he was false) and swearing; like Matth. Evang. xxvi. 74, to/te h)/rcato (*pe/tros) kataqemati/zein kai\ o)mnu/ein, then began he to curse and to swear.
7. th\n ai)ti/an tau/thn: i.e. the charge of intimate relations with Philip.
2. w(molo/geis: i.e. your friendship with Philip.
3. fili/an kai\ ceni/an: see §§ 51, 52.
4. metatiqe/menos, substituting (ap- plying by exchange).
6. tumpanistri/as, timbrel-beater: the tu/mpanon, kettle-drum, was a favourite instrument in the Asiatic ceremonies described in §§ 259, 260. —h)\ gnw/rimos, or even an acquaintance.
9. kata\ sautou=...sumba=si, an informer against yourself after the facts, whereas para\ ta\ sumba/nta (cf. § 285.4) he had denied everything which told against him (§ 283.6). See § 197.9 and note.
11. pa/ntas ma=llon, i.e. any rather than myself: most MSS. (not *s and L.1) add the implied h)\ e)me/.

1. polla\ kai\ kala\ k.t.l.: these accusatives are direct objects of proei/leto, but cognate with katw/rqwse. Demosth. invariably uses katorqw= in its neuter sense of succeed, as in § 274.6, ou) katw/rqwse. If an object is added, as in XXI. 106, ei) ga\r e(\n w(=n e)pebou/leuse katw/rqwsen, it is cognate: see XXIV. 7, XXXVII. 2. So in Cor. § 290.3 tou= katorqou=n tou\s a)gwnizome/nous is not causing the combatants to succeed, but the success of the combatants, as in pa/nta katorqou=n,
to succeed in all things, just preceding. In other authors katorqw= is often active, as in Soph. El. 416, katw/rqwsan brotou/s.

3. to\n e)rou=nt), i.e. the orator for the public funeral. The funeral eulogy on those who fell in battle was first introduced (acc. to Diod. XI. 33) in the Persian wars. We have one genuine e)pita/fios lo/gos, that of Hyperides in honour of those who fell in the Lamian war (322 B.C.); the famous eulogy of Pericles in 430 B.C., given in the words of Thucydides (II. 35—46); with one in Plat. Menex. (236—249), sportively ascribed to Aspasia by Socrates. The one ascribed to Lysias (II.) is of doubtful authenticity, and that found among the speeches of Demosthenes (LX.) is certainly spurious.
4. par' au)ta\ ta\ sumba/nta: i.e. when there might have been a strong public prejudice against him, as a leader who had failed (cf. § 248.7).
5. problhqe/nta, nominated: cf. § 149.3.
7. *(hgh/mona, mentioned by Ae- schines (III. 25): he belonged to the Macedonian party at Athens with Demades and Pythocles.
8. parelqo/ntos before sou= kai\ *puqokle/ous, but kathgorou/ntwn after these words.
10. a(\ kai\ su\ nuni\, i.e. which you again (kai\) now charge me with.— e)/t' a)/meinon, all the more eagerly.
3. au)toi\, of themselves (without being told).
4—6. a(\ ga\r...w(mologh/sate re- peats for the whole Macedonian party what was said of Aeschines in §§ 282, 283. For diomnu/menoi see § 283.6.
7. tou\s...labo/ntas a)/deian, i.e. those who gained license to speak their minds with impunity, etc. See §§ 198, 263.7.

287. 1. ei)=ta kai\ prosh/kein: sc. h(gh/santo (from § 286.9). I bracket u(polamba/nontes with Blass: a mere carelessness in style, aiming at no rhetorical effect, seems inadmissible in this oration: see note on § 317.6.

4. o(mwro/fion: to be under the same roof with anyone had a peculiar significance to the Greeks. Trials for homicide were held in the open air that neither the judges nor the prosecutor (usually a relative) might be under the same roof with the accused.—gegenhme/non ei)=nai, not a mere pleonasm for gegenh=sqai, but expressing more forcibly the combination of past and future which is often seen in gegenh=sqai (M.T. 102, 109), i.e. they thought he should not be one who had been under the same roof, etc.

5. paratacame/nois: see § 208.5, and note on sumparataca/menoi, § 216.5. —e)kei= kwma/zein: the revelling in Philip's camp after the victory at Chaeronea was notorious. See Plut.
