Dem. 20, where the story is told of the drunken Philip rushing out among the slain and chanting the introductory words of the decrees of Demosthenes, which make an iambic tetrameter: *dhmosqe/nhs *dhmosqe/nous *paianieu\s ta/d' ei)=pen. See XIX. 128, where Aeschines is charged with joining familiarly in the festivities held by Philip after the destruction of the Phocians (see Hist. § 38).

7. tw=n au)toxei/rwn: au)to/xeir is properly one who commits any deed by his own hands or by his own act, as in Soph. Ant. 306, to\n au)to/xeira tou=de tou= ta/fou. It also, when fo/nou is easily understood, means a murderer, as in Eur. H. F. 1359, pai/dwn au)qe/nthn e)mw=n.

8. th=| fwnh=| dakru/ein: a strong metaphor, opposed to th=| yuxh=| sunalgei=n (9).—u(pokrino/menon, like a play-actor.—th\n tu/xhn: object of dakru/ein. Blass takes it with u(pokrino/menon, as in XIX. 246, *)antigo/nhn u(poke/kritai.
11. u(ma=s, i.e. any one of you. Cf. u(mw=n, § 285.7.
1. ou)x, negativing the two clauses with me\n and de\: cf. § 13.11, and the grand climax in § 179, with notes.
2. pate/res kai\ a)delfoi\: the pub- lic funeral was in charge of a committee of relatives of those who had fallen.
4. to\ peri/deipnon, the funeral banquet: see Hermann (Blümner), Gr. Priv. Ant. § 39 (p. 371); Smith, Dict. Ant. under Funus.

5. w(s par' oi)keiota/tw|, at the house of him who stood in the closest possible relation to the deceased, as at private funerals the nearest relative. w(s belongs to oi)keiota/tw|, in the usual intensive sense: cf. § 246.8, w(s ei)s e)la/xista.
6. w(/sper...gi/gnesqai, i.e. as is the custom at private funerals.— e)poi/hsan: like poiei=n in 4.
9. w(=|...die/feren, i.e. who had most at stake, i.e. in their success.

10. kai/, likewise.—a(\ mh/pot' w)/fe- lon (sc. paqei=n), lit. which would they had never suffered: this rather poetic form of an unattained wish is used here for animation, and again in § 320.6. See M.T. 734, 736.
1. dhmosi/a|, with e)pi- gra/yai.

2. proei/leq' h( po/lis, more formal than e)/doce th=| po/lei, perhaps implying (as H. Jackson suggests) a choice from epigrams sent in by competing poets—i(/n) ei)dh=|s...miaro/n: explained in § 290.

EPIGRAM. This cannot be the real epitaph inscribed on the public monument of the heroes of Chaeronea. It has too little poetic merit and too slovenly a style to be accepted as genuine. It is not in the older MSS., and it appears in the Anthol. Graeca, IV. p. 249 (Jacobs). We can be sure of one genuine verse (9), which is quoted by Demosthenes in § 290.1 (see note on this verse). A small fragment of an inscription has been found at Athens, cut (acc. to Köhler) between 350 and 300 B.C.,
which contains parts of six words of an epigram in the Anthol. Pal. VII. 245: this epigram was evidently inscribed to the heroes of Chaeronea. The full epigram is as follows, the letters found in the inscription being printed in heavy type:—
*)=w *xro/ne, pantoi/wn qnhtoi=s panepi/- skope dai=mon,
*boiwtw=n kleinoi=s qnh/|skomen e)n dape/- dois.
This, though genuine, cannot be the inscription quoted by Demosthenes, as it does not have the verse mhde\n... katorqou=n; but there were undoubtedly many epigrams commemorating the men of Chaeronea.

v. 1. e)/qento o(/pla, arrayed them- selves (lit. placed their arms): see Arist. Pol. Ath. 8.29, o(\s a)\n stasiazou/shs th=s po/lews mh\ qh=tai ta\ o(/pla mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn, i.e. who takes sides with neither party. So Plat. Rep. 440 E. This is enough to show that the old interpretation of ti/qesqai o(/pla (as in Thuc. II. 2, twice), to pile and stack arms, is untenable, though it still lingers.

v. 2. a)peske/dasan, scattered, brought to nought: a patriotic exaggeration as applied to Chaeronea, perhaps referring to some special exploits of the Athenians. Diod. (XVI. 86) says, me/xri me/n tinos o( a)gw\n a)mfidocoume/nas ei)=xe ta\s e)lpi/das th=s ni/khs. Cf. Lycurgus (Leoc. 49), ei) de\ dei= kai\ paradoco/taton me\n ei)pei=n a)lhqe\s de\, e)kei=noi nikw=ntes a)pe/qanon.

v. 3. a)reth=s kai\ dei/matos must depend on brabh=, arbiter, by an hyperbaton which would be incredible in the genuine epitaph; ou)k e)sa/wsan yuxa\s a)ll) being introduced in place of a participial clause like ou) sw/santes yuxa/s. The meaning evidently is, in the battle, while they sacrificed their lives, they left to the God of Death to judge whether they showed courage or fear. There is a similar hyperbaton in Xen. Hell. VII. 3, 7: u(mei=s tou\s peri\ *)arxi/an kai\ *(upa/thn,...ou) yh=fon a)nemei/nate, a)ll' o(po/te prw=ton e)duna/sqhte e)timwrh/sasqe (West.).
v. 5. ou(/neken *(ellh/nwn belongs to vv. 3, 4.—zugo\n au)xe/ni qe/ntes, a strange expression for classical times, but common in later poetry, as in the Anthology (Blass).
v. 6. a)mfi\s e)/xwsin (with mh\), have about them, wear, like a yoke: cf. Od. III. 486, sei=on zugo\n a)mfi\s e)/xontes.
v. 7. tw=n plei=sta kamo/ntwn, of men who most grievously laboured, referring to the defeat; to these words e)pei/ (v. 8) refers back.

vv. 9, 10. mhde\n...e)n bioth=|, it is the gift of the Gods (for men) never to fail and always to succeed in life, i.e. this is a miraculous exception in mortal life; opposed to which is the
fixed rule that death is appointed for all, moi=ran...e)/poren (sc. *zeu\s brotoi=s). The two verses contain the e)k *dio\s kri/sis; but the change of construction in moi=ran...e)/poren is awkward, and e)n bioth=| is an unnatural addition to v. 9. It is now known that mhde\n a(martei=n e)sti qeou= (or qew=n) kai\ pa/nta katorqou=n is a verse of the epigram of Simonides on the heroes of Marathon, of which two other lines are preserved:
xrusofo/rwn *mh/dwn e)sto/resan du/na- min.

Kirchhoff (Hermes VI. pp. 487— 489) quotes from a MS. scholium: le/gei de\ *simwni/dhs e)n e)pigra/mmati r(hqe/nti au)tw=| e)pi\ toi=s *maraqw=ni pesou=sin *)aqhnai/wn to
 sti/xon tou=ton, *mhde
 a(martei=n e)sti qeou= kai\ pa/nta katorqou=n. See Bergk, Poet. Lyr., Simon. fr. 82, with the note. See Themist. Or. XXII. p. 276 B, e)pei\ de\ to\ mhde
 a(marta/nein e)/cw th=s fu/sews kei=tai th=s a)nqrwpi/nhs,...to\ e)pi/gramma a)lhqe/steron o(\ *)aqh/nhsin e)pige/graptai e)n tw=| ta/fw| tw=| dhmosi/w|: kai\ ga toi=s qeoi=s mo/nois to\ pa/nta katorqou=n a)pone/mei. These two quotations refer to a verse in which “never to fail and always to succeed” is called a divine prerogative; while in the same words in the inscription quoted by Demosthenes these are called a privilege sometimes granted by the Gods to favoured mortals (see § 290). The original verse of Simonides, mhde
... katorqou=n (without e)n bioth=|), was probably used, as a well-known verse, in the genuine epigram on those who fell at Chaeronea (still without e)n bioth=|), but with a different meaning; and in this new sense it was quoted by Demosthenes in § 290. The writer of our epigram probably borrowed the genuine line (perhaps from the text of Demosthenes), and added the whole of v. 10. See notes of West. and Bl.
4. a)ne/qhke: the epigram or its composer, or perhaps h( po/lis, is the subject.
5. a(\...ei)s kefalh/n; cf. XIX. 130, a(\ nu=n ei)s kefalh\n u(ma=s au)tw=| dei= tre/yai, and § 294.8 (below).
4. w(s a)\n: sc. e)/sxe or sxoi/h: cf. § 197.8.
5. e)/sxe th\n gnw/mhn, was disposed.

7. laruggi/zwn: see Harpocr., to\ platu/nein th\n fwnh\n kai\ mh\ kata\ fu/sin fqe/ggesqai, a)ll' e)pithdeu/ein periergo/teron tw=| la/ruggi xrh=sqai ou(/tws e)le/geto. Cf. Ar. Eq. 358, laruggiw= tou\s r(h/toras, I will screech down the orators.

8. dei=gma e)ce/fere, he was making an exhibition, giving a specimen: cf. XIX. 12.—o(/ti...toi=s a)/llois: depending on the verbal force of dei=gma.— toi=s gegen. a)niaroi=s: causal dative with e)/sxe, was affected; cf. e)/sxe th\n gnw/mhn (5).
9. toi=s a)/llois: with o(moi/ws.
1. tw=n no/mwn: Aeschines began his speech (1—8) with a grand glorification of the laws, and of the grafh\ parano/mwn as the great bulwark of the constitution.
3. tau)ta\...toi=s polloi=s: cf. § 280.6.
4. th=| proaire/sei tw=n koinw=n: cf. § 192.5 and l. 8 (below); see §§ 93.4, 317.2.
5. teta/xqai, to be found (posted).
6. pepoihkw\s: in or. obl. with ei)= fanero\s (M.T. 907).
7. pra/gmata, troubles: cf. Ar. Ach. 310, a(pa/ntwn ai)ti/ous tw=n pragma/twn. See Aesch. III. 57.

8. ou)k...bohqei=n: i.e. the policy of helping friendly states against Philip has followed the true traditions of Athens: see §§ 95—100. Demosth. here only denies that he began this policy (ou)k a)rcame/nwn).
3. th=|...prattome/nh|, the dominion which was growing up: cf. § 62.2.
6. eu)= oi)= d' o(/ti, as usual, paren- thetic: oi)=d' o(/ti can be thus used even with a participle, as in IX. 1, XIX. 9.
8. e)/blapte kai\ die/ballen (with a(/n): conative.

In §§ 294—296, Demosthenes gives a “black list” of the traitors who have helped Philip or Alexander in subjugating Greek states, and declares that Aeschines is the representative of this pestilent class in Athens. Saving his own country from the disgrace of joining or abetting this foul plot against liberty is the great service for which he claims the name of patriot.
3. e)mou= filippismo\n: the pronoun is emphatic, me, of all men. The word Philippic in all languages is a standing answer to the charge of Aeschines.
6. a)nelo/ntas e)k me/sou (sc. u(ma=s), discarding.
9. a)naqei=en: cf. § 290.6.
10. eu(/roit) (eu(/roite) a)/n, you would find, appealing suddenly to the court or the audience.
1. o(/t' h)=n a)sqenh=, i.e. in the state described in II. 14—21.
2. ta\ *fil. pra/gmata, i.e. his condition.
3. prolego/ntwn...ta\ be/ltista, as Demosthenes in the Olynthiacs and the First Philippic.

5. tou\s u(pa/rxontas poli/tas, their own fellow-citizens, those with whom each had to deal. Daochus and Thrasydaus were the Thessalian ambassadors sent by Philip to Thebes in 339 B.C. (see note on § 211.6). Perillus, Timolaus, and Aristratus are mentioned in § 48. Hipparchus and Clitarchus were set up as tyrants in Eretria by Philip about 343 B.C.: see §§ 71, 80, and 81. Most of the men in the list remain in deserved obscurity.

With this whole passage compare §§ 45—49, and Polyb. XVII. 14. Polybius censures Demosthenes for calling some of these men traitors,
maintaining that they did what they believed to be for the best interest of their own states. Demosthenes, looking back on his long struggle with Philip, felt that their selfish regard for the temporary interests of special cities, which always proved fatal to Hellenic unity, and their utter disregard of the good of Greece as a whole, really amounted to treachery.
1. e)pilei/yei...o)no/mata: emphatic asyndeton. Cf. the Epistle to the Hebrews, xi. 32, e)pilei/yei me o( xro/nos, and Cic. Nat. Deor. III. 32 (81), dies deficiat si velim numerare.

3. tw=n au)tw=n bouleuma/twn, (men) of the same purposes: this genitive of quality is as rare in Greek as it is common in Latin. See Aesch. III. 168, qewrh/sat' au)to\n, mh\ o(pote/rou tou= lo/gou a)ll) o(pote/rou tou= bi/ou e)sti/n, and Thuc. III. 45.29, a(plw=s te a)du/naton kai\ pollh=s eu)hqei/as.

5. a)la/stores, accursed wretches (applied to Philip in XIX. 305); properly victims of divine vengeance, as in Soph. Aj. 374, meqh=ka tou\s a)la/storas. a)la/stwr also means a divine avenger, as in Aeschyl. Pers. 354, fanei\s a)la/stwr h)\ kako\s dai/mwn. See note on a)lith/rios, § 159.3.

6. h)krwthriasme/noi, who have out- raged (lit. mutilated): see Harpocr., a)nti\ tou= lelumas me/noi ˙ oi( ga\r lumaino/menoi/ tisin ei)w/qasi periko/ptein au)tw=n ta\ a)/kra. In Aeschyl. Cho. 439 and Soph. El. 445 there is the same idea in e)masxali/sqh, masxali/zw being to mutilate a dead body by cutting off the extremities (ta\ a)/kra) and putting them under the armpits (masxa/lai). Perhaps such strong metaphors as this suggested to Aeschines the absurd expressions which he pretends to quote from Demosthenes in III. 166, a)mpelourgou=si/ tines th\n po/lin, a)natet mh/kasi/ tines ta\ klh/mata ta\ tou= dh/mou, and others.—th\n e)leuqeri/an propepwko/tes: for the successive
steps by which propi/nw comes to mean recklessly sacrifice, see Liddell and Scott. An intermediate meaning, present a cup (or other gift) after drinking one's health, is seen in XIX. 139, pi/nwn kai\ filanqrwpeuo/menos pro\s au)tou\s o( *fi/lippos a)/lla te dh\ polla\, ...kai\ teleutw=n e)kpw/mat' a)rgura= kai\ xrusa= prou)/pinen au)toi=s, i.e. in drinking their health, he gave them these various gifts. See also Pind. Ol. VII. 1—6, fia/lan w(s ei)/ tis... dwrh/setai neani/a| gambrw=| propi/nwn, oi)/koqen oi)/kade, and the Schol. on V. 5, propi/nein e)sti\ kuri/ws to\ a(/ma tw=| kra/mati to\ a)ggei=on xari/zesqai... kai\ *dhmosqe/nhs tou\s prodido/ntas ta\s patri/das toi=s e)xqroi=s propi/nein e)/fh.
8. th=| gastri\ metrou=ntes: see note on § 48.6 (on *timo/las). See Cic. Nat. Deor. I. 40 (113), quod dubitet omnia quae ad beatam vitam pertineant ventre metiri.
11. o(/roi kai\ kano/nes, bounds and rules, i.e. they applied these as tests to whatever was presented to them as a public good.—a)natetrofo/tes, having overturned (i.e. reversed) these tests.

THE EPILOGUE, §§ 297—323. In these sections we have the four characteristics of the e)pi/logos, as Aristotle gives them (Rhet. III. 19, 1): arguments which will dispose the hearers favourably to the speaker and unfavourably to his opponent, amplification and depreciation, excitement of emotions, and recapitulation. He begins by claiming the credit of keeping Athens free from the notorious conspiracy against Grecian liberty just mentioned; and he charges Aeschines with failing in all the characteristics of a patriotic citizen which his own course exemplifies (§§ 297—300). He recapitulates some of his chief services in providing Athens with means of defence, and asks what similar claims Aeschines has to the public gratitude (§§ 301—313). He objects to being compared with the great men of former times, though he declares that he can bear such a comparison far better than his opponent (§§ 314—323).
1, 2. periboh/tou, notorious.
3. ei) dei= mh\ lhrei=n, i.e. to call it by its right name, prodosi/as.
4. para\ pa=sin a)nqrw/pois, i.e. in the minds of all men; but para\ toi=s *(/ellhsi (8), among the Greeks: in § 274.1 both ideas are combined.
6. e)rwta=|s; see Aesch. 236.
8. a(pa/ntwn: exaggeration; but see § 304.
9. a)rcame/nwn a)po\ sou=, i.e. your- self first and foremost.
3. e)ph=ren, induced (roused): cf. §§ 168.2, 175.8.

5—7. ou)d)...o(moi/ws u(mi=n...sum- bebou/leuka (7), nor have I given my advice, like you, inclining towards gain like a balance, i.e. as a balance would incline if a weight were put into one of the scales: w(/sper a)
 (sc. r(e/poi). The MSS. are corrupt: w(/sper a)
 truta/nh is nearest to w(/spera
trutanhi of *s. We have e)n trut. in A, and a)
 ei) e)n trut. vulg. This is illustrated by a striking passage in V. 12: proi=ka ta\ pra/gmata kri/nw kai\ logi/zomai, kai\ ou)de
 lh=mm' a)
 ou)dei\s e)/xoi pro\s oi(=s e)gw\ pepoli/teumai kai\ le/gw dei=cai proshrthme/non. o)rqo
 ou)=n, o(/ ti a)/n pot) a)p) au)tw=n u(pa/rxh| tw=n pragma/twn, to\ sumfe/ron fai/netai/ moi. o(/tan d) e)pi\ qa/tera w(/sper ei)s truta/nhn a)rgu/rion prosene/gkh|s, oi)/xetai fe/ron kai\ kaqei/lkuke to
 logismo
 e)f) au(to\, kai\ ou)k a)
 e)/t) o)rqw=s ou)d) u(giw=s o( tou=to poih/sas peri\ ou)deno\s logi/saito.
7. o)rqh=s...a)diafqo/rou: predicative (cf. § 322.6).
8. megi/stwn...a)nqrw/pwn, lit. the weightiest concerns of (any of) the men of my time (partitive).

1. teixismo\n, the repair- ing of the walls of Athens in 337— 336 B.C., for which Demosthenes was teixopoio/s. See Aesch. III. 27. Demosthenes was then appointed by his tribe, the *pandioni/s, and received from the treasury (according to Aesch. 31) nearly ten talents for the expenses (cf. § 113.6,7).—o(\n su/ mou die/sures: cf. tou=to/ mou diaba/llei § 28.3.
3. po/rrw, i.e. far below.

4. ou) li/qois e)tei/xisa th\n po/lin: a famous passage, often quoted by the rhetoricians. See the beginning of the u(po/qesis of Libanius. Plutarch (Lycurg. 19) quotes a saying of Lycurgus the lawgiver, ou)k a)\n ei)/h a)tei/xistos po/lis a(/tis a)ndra/si kai\ ou) pli/nqois e)stefa/nwtai. Whiston refers to Sir Wm Jones's ode, “What constitutes a State?” The passage is a most effective answer to the taunts of Aeschines (236) about the walls and ditches.

5. pli/nqois: sun-dried bricks, of which no small part of the walls of Athens and of the Long Walls to the Piraeus were built. The brick wall was built on a solid foundation of stone. See Thuc. I. 93, oi( qeme/lioi pantoi/wn li/qwn u(po/keintai (of the walls of Athens). The stone walls of Mantinea, which are still standing almost complete, have at most only four courses of stone, which were once surmounted by a wall of brick: Pausanias (VIII. 8, 7) describes this wallas w)mh=s w)|kodomhme/non th=s pli/nqou, built of raw (i.e. unbaked) bricks.
8. to/pous, countries, Euboea, Boeotia, the Chersonese, as opposed to cities.
9. tou\s u(pe\r tou/twn a)munome/nous, the defenders of these (our fellowcitizens).
2. prou)balo/mhn: cf. §§ 97.10 and 301.4.—a)nqrwpi/nw| logismw=|: cf. § 193.5.
4. to\n ku/klon tou= *peiraiw=s: the circuit of the Piraeus was assigned to the tribe Pandionis, to which Demosthenes belonged. See Essay III. § 1.
5. logismoi=s may refer to the encounter with Python (§ 136) and also to the embassies mentioned in § 244.—*fili/ppou: with h(tth/qhn.

7. oi( tw=n summa/xwn strathgoi\: of these we hear only of two Thebans, Proxenus and Theagenes: of these Dinarchus (I. 74) says, e)pi\ de\ toi=s ce/nois toi=s ei)s *)/amfissan sullegei=si *pro/cenos o( prodo/ths e)ge/neto: h(gemw\n de\ th=s fa/laggos (at Chaeronea) kate/sth *qeage/nhs, a)/nqrwpos a)tuxh\s kai\ dwrodo/kos w(/sper ou(=tos (Demosthenes).
In §§ 301—313, the orator re- capitulates his own chief services, with which he compares the public career of Aeschines.

1. ti/ xrh=n k.t.l., i.e. what was his duty?—poiei=n, of a course of action, explained by several aorists, each of a special act. In the following series of questions, all introduced by xrh=n, the orator states the various problems which faced the Athenian statesman of that day and the obvious solutions of them.
3. e)k qala/tths: cf. § 230.5.

4. probale/sqai: cf. prou)balo/mhn, § 300.2. With this figure of throwing forward Euboea as a wall of defence to Attica, compare that in § 71.2 (see note). See Aesch. III. 84, nai\, a)lla\ xalkoi=s kai\ a)damanti/nois tei/xesin, w(s au)to/s fhsi, th\n xw/ran h(mw=n e)tei/xise, th=| tw=n *eu)boe/wn kai\ *qhbai/wn summaxi/a|.
6. tou\s o(mo/rous tau/th|, our neigh- bours on this side, as Megara and Corinth (cf. § 237).

7. para\ pa=san fili/an (sc. gh=n): i.e. that the corn-trade should pass along an entirely friendly coast. For the subject of §§ 301, 302, see §§ 71, 79—82, 87—89, 240, 241, and Hist. §§ 46, 51, 52, 54.
1. The measures men- tioned in ta\ me\n sw=sai and ta\ d)... pra=cai (4) were designed to secure a friendly coast for the corn-trade.
2. bohqei/as: cf. § 305.8.
3. gra/fonta toiau=ta, by propos- ing measures accordingly.
4. o(/pws u(pa/rcei pra=cai, i.e. to get possession of them (cf. u(parxo/ntwn in 2).
6. *eu)/boian: Euboea, with its long coasts, was always essential to the safety of the corn trade.

7. ta\s megi/stas: especially Thebes in 339 B.C.—w(=n e)ne/leipe th=| po/lei, what the city lacked: e)llei/pei is here
impersonal, like e)ndei=; so Plat. Leg. 844 B, ei)/ tisi to/pois...e)llei/pei tw=n a)nagkai/wn pwma/twn, and 740 C.
1. bebouleume/na o)rqw=s eu(rh/sei (or obl.) refers chiefly to politeu/mata.

4. ou) pareqe/nta...proeqe/nta, op- portunitatem cuiusque rei non per negligentiam praetermissam nec ignoratam nec proditam (Dissen). pareqe/nta implies carelessness (cf. VIII. 34), proeqe/nta wilfulness (cf. VIII. 56).
5. o(/s) implies tosou/twn, depend- ing on ou)de/n.

6. dai/monos h)\ tu/xhs: cf. to\n dai/mona kai\ th\n tu/xhn, Aesch. III. 115, 157. The strength (i)sxu/s) of the superhuman powers is opposed to the weakness and incapacity (faulo/ths) or the treachery of men. See notes on §§ 264.1 and 300.7.
9. toi=s o(/lois: see note on § 278.9. —a)ne/treyen, overset, the familiar figure of the ship of state.
10. a)dikei=, not is doing wrong, but is to blame for a past wrong (M.T. 27).
3. *qettali/a...*)arkadi/a: see §§ 63, 64. “Philip's party in the one opened Northern Greece to him, and in the other neutralized the Peloponnesus” (Simcox).
6. e)ke/xrht' a)\n, would have expe- rienced.
1. a)/n is repeated with w)/|koun (3), contrary to general usage, because of the change of time from e)ke/xrht' a)\n to w)/|koun (present time).
7. le/ge kai\ a)na/gnwqi: cf. § 28.1.

8. bohqeiw=n: forces sent out for special purposes, like those mentioned in § 302.2: see IV. 32, mh\ bohqei/ais polemei=n (u(steriou=men ga\r a(pa/ntwn) a)lla\ paraskeuh=| sunexei= kai\ duna/mei, and cf. IV. 41. The famous expedition which checked Philip at Thermopylae in 352 B.C. (IV. 17) is called a boh/qeia in XIX. 84. Often boh/qeia means a mere raid.

1. tau=ta...pra/ttein...dei= sums up the reply to the question ti/ xrh=n...poiei=n; in § 301.1, but with a change in tense. He asked what was the duty, with special reference to the case in hand; and he replies in general terms this is the duty. poiei=n (§ 301.1) and pra/ttein here have the same sense, as have xrh/ (in xrh=n) and dei=.

2—4. katorqoume/nwn=ei) katwr- qou=to, if they had been successful (as they were not), to which the apodosis is u(ph=rxen ei)=nai, it belonged to us to be, i.e. we should properly have been (M.T. 416).—megi/stois (sc. h(mi=n)... kai\ to\ dikai/ws prosh=n, i.e. indisputably, and (I might add.) justly, greatest: dikai/ws stands as a mere word with the article; and prosh=n is belonged there, i.e. might properly be added.
4. w(s e(te/rws, otherwise: see note on § 85.6.—sumba/ntwn, simply temporal, now, when they (have) resulted otherwise.
5. peri/esti, there is left to us: the subject is to\ eu)dokimei=n kai\ to\ mhde/na... kri/nasan (7).

7. kaki/zein: the subject is pa/ntas, to be supplied from the preceding subject mhde/na. The same carelessness of expression is always common; a famous case is the clause of the United States Constitution concerning fugitive slaves: “No person held to service or labor in one state, escaping into another, shall...be discharged from said service or labor, but shall be delivered up,” etc.

1. ou) ma\ *di/) ou)k: em- phatic repetition, not a double negative: dei= is understood here
from § 306.2, and on it depend the infinitives qerapeu/ein etc. through a)/gein (8).
2. a)posta/nta: strongly opposed to qerapeu/ein (4) and u(posta/nta (5).
4. tw=n th=s patri/dos (sc. kairw=n), instead of the fuller form with u(pe/r (as in 3).—to\n u(posta/nta, the man who has undertaken, object of baskai/nein.
8. u(/poulon, lit. festering within, of the quiet of Aesch., false, treacherous; see Thuc. VIII. 64 (end), th\n a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn u(/poulon au)tonomi/an (Bl.).
2. oi( polloi\ here simply the majority.
3. a(plw=s, in honest simplicity, without pretence, opposed to u(/poulos, h(suxi/a (307.8).—ou)tau/thn: cf. Aesch. III. 216.
5. fula/ttei phni/k) (*s, L) e)/sesqe mestoi/, he watches (to see) when you will be sated, an indirect question where we might expect a temporal clause: o(phni/ka is the common reading.
6. tou= sunexw=s le/gontos, with your regular speaker, i.e. the one who is continually advising you: see Plut. Cim. 5, o( dh=mos...mesto\s w)\n tou= *qemistokle/ous.
8. ta)nqrw/pina: sc. e)nantiw/mata.
9. r(h/twr, as an orator, predicate to e)fa/nh (gnomic).—w(/sper pneu=m), with e)cai/fnhs.
10. pefwnaskhkw\s: cf. § 280.2.— suneiloxw\s, the only proper perf. act. of sulle/gw, though here *s has suneilexw/s (but sunei/loxa in XXI. 23). Cf. sumforh/sas, § 15.4.
11. r(h/mata: cf. § 232.4.—sunei/rei, reels off (strings together).
12. a)pneustei\, all in one breath (without taking breath).
13. tw=| tuxo/nti, cuivis, to any one who happens to hear them.
14. koinh\n, public, opposed to tw=| tuxo/nti.—ai)sxu/nhn: Blass refers this to the speech described in § 35.
1, 2. mele/ths, e)pimelei/as, practice, study, referring to § 308.10-12.
3. ta\...proh|rhme/nhs, one which had made the interests of the fatherland its choice (proai/resin), connected by kai\ to dikai/as. Cf. § 315.8.

4. e)/dei ei)=nai, ought to have been, implying that in the case of Aeschines they were not so.—gennai/ous: often used literally of fruits, as in Plat. Leg. 844 E, th\n gennai/an nu=n legome/nhn stafulh\n h)\ ta\ gennai=a su=ka e)ponomazo/mena (Bl.).
6. e)mpori/ou kataskeuh\n: (pro- bably) securing new commercial rights for Athens in some foreign seaport: see XX. 33, kataskeua/sas e)mpo/rion *qeudosi/an, with Sandys's note.
7. a)podeixqei=sin, declared, open. Cf. a)podei/ceis, 310.2.

1. tou/twn h)=n e)ce/tasis: e)ce/tasis is again a military term, as in § 320.10, where it means a mustering or review of hirelings etc., in which they were called forth to show themselves. Here, with a genitive denoting public services, it means likewise calling out and arraying such services to a man's credit. (See note on § 173.5.)
2. e)/dwken...a)podei/ceis, i.e. the past gave many opportunities for showing such services, as it were arraying them for a review.
3. e)n oi(=s, in which class (the kaloi/ te ka)gaqoi/), as if a)ndra/si had preceded.—ou)damou=: cf. § 320.5.

5. ou)x o(postosou=n (cf. o(stisou=n), not in any rank whatsoever. Dissen thinks this alludes to a Delphic oracle given to the Megarians, quoted in the Scholia to Theoc. XIV. 48, 49, of which the last two verses are:

p.foreign: u(mei=s d' w)= *megarei=s ou)/te tri/toi ou)/te te/tartoi

div2.p: ou)/te duwde/katoi, ou)/t' e)n lo/gw| ou)/t) e)n a)riqmw=|.
6. ou)/koun e)pi/ g' oi(=s, at all events, not in matters in which, etc.

These questions are argu- ments for the judgment just pronounced upon Aeschines. After the third question, the conjunctions are omitted in the speaker's vehemence. With the whole passage compare XIX. 282.

5. tw=n *(ellhnikw=n, opposed to tw=n oi)kei/wn, is the so-called foreign policy of Athens, i.e. her policy with other Greek states: see note on § 59.2. Here tw=n cenikw=n is added to include her relations to other than Greek states, both being opposed to tw=n oi)kei/wn, her domestic policy.
6. poi=ai trih/reis; sc. gego/nasi th=| po/lei.
7. ti/...xrh/simos ei)=; what in the world (tw=n a(pa/ntwn) ARE you good for?
8. ti/s h)\ xrhma/twn; what public financial help has ever come from you to either rich or poor (i.e. to anybody)?
9. politikh\ kai\ koinh\ is a rhetori- cal amplification, like the cases in the note to § 4.6: in XXV. 22, e)/ranos politiko\s kai\ koino\s is a public contribution for the general good.
1. w)= ta=n, a familiar form of address, found in three other passages of Demosthenes, I. 26, III. 29, XXV. 78; in all introducing an imaginary retort of an opponent.
3. e)fqe/gcant): cf. § 199.7.

4. ei)s swthri/an e)pedi/dosan, i.e. made contributions (e)pido/seis, § 171.8) for the safety of the state. Such were made after Chaeronea, and again before the destruction of Thebes by Alexander: for the latter see XXXIV. 38, o(/te me\n *)ale/candros ei)s *qh/bas parh/|ei, e)pedw/kamen u(mi=n ta/lanton a)rguri/ou.

5. to\ suneilegme/non (sc. a)rgu/rion), i.e. money contributed to pay some debt to the state which made him a)/timos, and thus to make him again e)pi/timos. Every defaulting public debtor was ipso facto a)/timos.
7. keklhrono/mhkas...pentetala/n- twn, have inherited the estate of your brother-in-law Philo, which was (sc. o)/ntwn) more than five talents.
9. dita/lanton e)/ranon, a contribu- tion of two talents. There is probably a sarcastic reference to the common meaning of e)/ranos.

10. h(gemo/nwn: see note on § 103.4. —e)f' oi(=s e)lumh/nw, for the damage you did: oi(=s for a cognate a(/, as in § 18.6. The attack of Aeschines on the trierarchic law was not made when it was enacted in 340 B.C., but probably after Chaeronea. Demosthenes says (§ 107.6) that through the whole war (i.e. 340—338 B.C.) the naval armaments were fitted out under his law; and the statement of Aeschines (III. 222), e)chle/gxqhs u(p' e)mou= e(ch/konta kai\ pe/nte new=n taxunautousw=n trihra/rxous u(fh|rhme/nos, shows that evidence as to the working of the new law in details was derived from actual experience.
1. lo/gon e)k lo/gou le/gwn, by saying one thing after another.
2. tou= paro/ntos (sc. lo/gou) e)mau- to\n e)kkrou/sw, cut myself off from (discussing properly) the subject immediately before us.
3. o(/ti g' ou)xi\ di) e)/ndeian ou)k e)pe/- dwkas, that it was not through poverty that you did not contribute; each negative having its own force, as the second is not a compound (G. 1618).
4. a)lla\ connects fula/ttwn to di) e)/ndeian, both being casal.—fula/ttwn to\...gene/sqai: see M.T. 374; and note on § 258.3.
5. tou/tois, oi(=s: not simply to those for whom (which would hardly be tou/tois), but to these persons (§ 312.10), for whom (in whose interest), etc.

6. neani/as, often used in the sense of vigorous, lively, like the adjective neaniko/s: it occurs twice in Demosthenes, here and § 136.2.—h(ni/k) a)\n... ti de/h|: supply ei)pei=n, which all MSS. except *s.1 insert.

8. tragiko\s *qeokri/nhs: see Har- pocr., to
 gou=n pa/lai me
 u(pokrith
 tragiko
 u(/steron de\ sukofa/nthn ei)ko/tws w)no/mase tragiko
 *qeokri/nhn, Theocrines is the one accused in Or. LVIII. Cf. § 242.5.

In §§ 314—323, the orator com- plains of the unfairness of judging him, as Aeschines has done (178— 190), by comparison with the great men of ancient times. But he shrinks from no comparison with his contemporaries. In §§ 321—323 he states two points, which he claims for himself, in the character of the me/trios poli/ths.

1. tw=n pro/teron gegenhme/- nwn: in III. 181 Aeschines calls on the court directly to compare Demosthenes with Themistocles, Miltiades, the heroes of Phyle, and Aristides; and he does this very effectively.
3. th\n...u(pa/rxousan, the devotion which it is to be assumed you feel towards the dead.

4. prolabo/nta, securing for him- self in advance, taking advantage of. See Hor. Od. III. 24, 31, Virtutem incolumem odimus, Sublatam ex oculis quaerimus invidi.—pro\s e)kei/nous: cf. pro\s se\ 315.7.

2. toi=s me\n zw=si...fqo/nos k.t.l.: cf. Thuc. II. 45, fqo/nos ga\r toi=s zw=si pro\s to\ a)nti/palon, to\ de\ mh\ e)mpodw\n a)nantagwni/stw| eu)noi/a| teti/mhtai.—u(/pesti, implying more or less concealment: cf. § 36.2.
5. kri/nwmai; am I to be judged? With the answer mhdamw=s, we must understand kri/nwmai, in the sense let me not be judged: cf. Plat. Rep. 527 C, tiqw=men; with answer tiqw=men.
7, 8. Here pro\s se\ and zw/ntwn were pronounced with special emphasis. Supply e)me\ kri/nesqai. With proh|rhme/nwn cf. § 309.3.
3. ou)...h(li/kas, no man can tell how great: ou) me\n ou)=n, as usual, is emphatic and corrective.
4. e)pi\ to\n paro/nta bi/on gigno- me/nas (sc. eu)ergesi/as), shown to the present generation.
5. ei)s a)xaristi/an a)/gein: cf. § 112.8.
7. timh=s kai\ filanqrwpi/as: cf. § 209.3.
1. ei)...ei)pei=n: he makes this slight apology for asserting even the following claim to be compared with the great men of old.
3. e)painoume/nwn: imperfect, like sukofantou/ntwn (5), as shown by to/te.

6. diasu/rontes...e)ph/|noun: I keep diasu/rontes, with *s and L, but omit de\ before pro/teron (7). diasu/rw, ridicule, is a favourite word with Demosthenes: it occurs elsewhere in this speech in §§ 27.6, 126.7, 180.3, 218.10, 299.2, 323.7, 8, always in the same sense.
7. to/te: with o)/ntas.
2. o( d' a)delfo\s o( so/s: Aeschines had two brothers, Philochares, older, and Aphobetus, younger than himself.

4. w)= xrhste\, my good man, iron- ical: cf. §§ 30.3, 89.7.—i(/na...ei)/pw: this is generally understood to refer to the gentle style of address in xrhste\, to call you nothing more: see West. and Bl. But it may refer to pro\s tou\s zw=ntas (4), and imply that he will not press the slight claim to a comparison with the men of old made in § 317: it will then mean, to claim no more than this.
5. tou\s kaq' au(to\n: with pro\s (4). —w(/sper ta)/lla pa/nta, i.e. as in other cases, less exact than tou\s a)/llous pa/ntas.
6. tou\s poihta\s...a)gwnista/s, i.e. as in dramatic and other contests of that nature, and in the public games.

1. *fila/mmwn is chosen as an Athenian who had recently returned as an Olympic victor. Glaucus, on the contrary, was one of the most famous boxers of the time of the
Persian wars, who, besides gaining a victory at Olympia, gained two Pythian, eight Nemean, and eight Isthmian prizes. Pausanias (VI. 10, 1—3) saw his statue at Olympia. See the fragment of the ode of Simonides in his honour (fr. 8, Bergk): ou)de\ *poludeu/keos bi/a xei=ras a)ntei/nait' a)\n e)nanti/on au)tw=|, ou)de\ sida/reon) *alkma/nas te/kos. Aeschines (III. 189) refers to this comparison as one which he “heard that Demosthenes would make.” This is evidently a bold addition made to his speech after it was spoken.
4. ei)selqo/ntwn: cf. Soph. El. 700; Xen. An. VI. 1, 9.
6. o(/ra me: cf. qewrw=mai; (§ 315.5) and e)ce/taze (§ 318.5).

7. ou)de/n' e)ci/stamai, I shrink from no one: this reading of the best MSS. agrees with Lobeck's rule (note on Soph. Aj. 82), that e)ci/stamai, declinare, takes the accusative, but in the sense of cedere, the dative. For the dative see Soph. Phil. 1053, nu=n de\ soi/ g' e(kw\n e)ksth/somai.
1. w(=n, partitive with kra/tista le/gwn (3).

2. e)fami/llou...keime/nhs: the figure of a public contest is kept up, the privilege of showing devotion to the state being a prize open to general competition (e)fami/llou). Cf. e)na/millon, Plat. Rep. 433 D.
5. h)=n ou)damou=: cf. § 310.3.—ei)/... ti de/oi: the optative implies frequent occasions for insulting the people.
6. a(\ mh/pot' w)/felen (sc. sumbh=nai), i.e. the defeat: see 288.10, and note ou)ke/ti (7), opposed to o(/te...parh=n (1).
9. e(/teron: this is the vague term by which Demosthenes often alludes to Alexander: see § 323.1, 10.
10. e)ce/tasis: the familiar military figure recurs, i.e. a call for these, as for a review; and this is carried out in e)n ta/cei (11). Cf. note on § 173.5.

11. i(ppotro/fos: the keeping of horses was a sign of wealth, and the word implies that Aeschines had become a richer and more powerful man at Athens since the complete establishment of Alexander's supremacy. Cf. Ar. Nub. 15.

12. a)sqenh\s: Aeschines (159) speaks of Dem. at this time as u(po/tromos, pariw\n h(miqnh\s e)pi\ to\ bh=ma. Westermann refers this to the time when Philip was made a citizen of Athens and his statue was erected in the city (Plut. Dem. 22; Paus. I. 9, 4). It more probably refers to the recent honours paid to Alexander: see C. I. Att. II. no. 741, dated by Köhler in 331 B.C., stefa/nwn duoi=n, oi(=s o( dh=mos o( *)aqhnai/wn e)stefa/nwse *)ale/ca[ ndron].
1. me/trion: see § 10.7, 8.
2. ou(/tw (with ei)pei=n): he uses me/trios here modestly, as he is speaking of himself; but he means the man called kalo\s ka)gaqo\s poli/ths in § 278.3 and 306.1 (see Blass).

3, 4. e)n tai=s e)cousi/ais, i.e. o(/te... e(le/sqai parh=n, 320.1, in time of power. —th\n...proai/resin, the policy which aims at nobility and pre-eminence; and th=| po/lei diafula/ttein, to guard this always for the state. For tou= prwtei/ou see § 66.7.

5. pra/cei (sc. e)n pa/sh|) may mean in every act (of the statesman). But Blass is probably right in taking it in the sense of fortune, like eu)= and kakw=s pra/ttein: see Aeschyl. Prom. 695, pra=cin *)iou=s; Hdt. III. 65 (end), a)pe/klaie pa=san th\n e(wutou= pra=cin: and Soph. Tr. 294, eu)tuxh= klu/ousa pra=cin th/nde.
6. eu)/noian, loyal devotion to the state: so in § 322.5.—tou/tou, i.e. th\n eu)/noian diafula/ttein.
7. e(/tera, other things, as chance or Fortune, which he cannot control. —tau/thn: i.e. th\n eu)/noian.
8. a(plw=s, absolutely, without ex- ception.
1. e)caitou/menos, i.e. by Alexander; see the next note and note on § 41.10.

2. ei)s *)amfiktu/onas, before the Amphictyonic Council: cf. e)n *)amfiktu/osin, XIX. 181 (also without the article). When Alexander demanded the orators of Athens in 335 B.C., he doubtless intended to have them tried by the Amphictyonic Council: see Aesch. III. 161, kai\ to\ pa/ntwn deino/taton, u(mei=s me\n tou=ton ou) prou)/dote, ou)d' ei)a/sate kriqh=nai e)n tw=| tw=n *(ellh/nwn sunedri/w|. Notice the spirit of this sentence. What a trial this would have been for Demosthenes,
Hyperides, and Lycurgus! Schaefer (III. 198) refers the passages of both Demosthenes and Aeschines to an attempt to bring Demosth. before the Amphictyonic Council in 330 B.C. on account of his complicity with the rebellion of Agis (see note on § 323.4). —di/kas e)pago/ntwn, bringing suits (against me): see § 249.3.
3. e)paggellome/nwn: cf. e)paggeliw=n me/geqos, § 298.2.—tou\s katara/tous tou/tous, the whole pack of sycophants mentioned in § 249.7-9.
4. prosballo/ntwn, setting them on (as qhri/a); cf. prosba/llesqai, to attack.
6. o)rqh\n...ei(lo/mhn: cf. 321.3, th\n...proai/resin. For the predicate adjectives cf. § 298.7.

7. dunastei/as: cf. §§ 67.2, 3, 270.5. dunastei/a means lordly power; and when it refers to a ruler, it often means absolute power or despotism. But it can also mean (as here), in a good sense, the lordly power which Athens once exercised over her dependent states, and which she always aspired to exercise.
8. qerapeu/ein, au)/cein, ei)=nai explain o)rqh\n...o(do/n (6).
9. meta\ tou/twn ei)=nai, to be faithful to these (ta\s tima\s...ta\s th=s patri/dos), lit. to be on their side: see Ar. Ach. 661, to\ ga\r eu)= met' e)mou= kai\ to\ di/kaion cu/mmaxon e)/stai.

1. ou)k belongs to both perie/rxomai (3) and a)kou/w (5).— e(te/rwn, i.e. the Macedonians; as e(/teros (10) and e(/teron (§ 320.9) refer to Alexander.—eu)tuxh/masi: the victories of Alexander at the Granicus (334 B.C.), at Issus (333 B.C.), and at Arbela (331 B.C.), were still fresh in recollection, the last not yet a year old.

3, 4. eu)aggelizo/menos, properly an- nouncing good tidings (cf. eu)agge/lion, Gospel), but here congratulating on good news, e.g. saying “This is a great victory.”—tou/tois ou(\s a)\n... oi)/wmai: the apparently definite antecedent is peculiar before the conditional relative clause. He means any of those (a well-known class) who I ever think are likely to report thither (to Macedonia) such an event as my congratulating them on a victory of Alexander. It has, I believe, never been asked who these men may have been. There were, of course, many Macedonians in Athens at this time, and there were many Athenians who would welcome news of Macedonian victories. But the greatest Macedonian who ever lived, the philosopher Aristotle, was then a resident in Athens at the head of the Lyceum. His relations with the Court of Pella and with Alexander were most intimate. Who would be more likely
to report to Pella, or even to Alexander himself, that Demosthenes had congratulated him on the victory at Arbela, if he had any such pleasant fact to report? It would be interesting, though not quite pleasant, to find an allusion to the great philosopher in this striking passage.

4. tw=n...a)gaqw=n: these advantages may be the early successes of the Spartan king Agis in his revolt against Macedonia in the spring of 330 B.C. (Diod. XVII. 63). Aeschines (167) quotes Demosthenes as saying of this, w(s a)ntipra/ttwn' *aleca/ndrw|, “o(mologw= ta\ *lakwnika\ susth=sai: o(mologw= *qettalou\s kai\ *perraibou\s a)fista/nai.” See Grote XII., ch. 95. The words tw=n ...a)gaqw=n more probably refer to the interest of Athens in the reverses of Alexander, which were occasionally reported from Asia. Aeschines (164) describes Demosthenes as once reporting that Alexander was shut up in Cilicia, and au)ti/ka ma/la e)/melle sumpathqh/sesqai u(po\ th=s *persikh=s i(/ppou. This shows that the mere report of a disaster to Alexander roused the spirit of liberty at Athens, even in her deep humiliation.
6. ku/ptwn ei)s th\n gh=n: cf. Caes. B. G. I. 32, 2, tristes capite demisso terram intueri.
7. diasu/rousin: see note on § 317.6.—w(/sper ou)x with the participle shows that there is nothing conditional in the expression: see note on § 276.1.
8. e)/cw ble/pousi: cf. Plut. Arat. 15, tai=s e)lpi/sin e)/cw ble/pwn.
9. e)n oi(=s (cf. § 19.3) belongs equally to a)tuxhsa/ntwn and eu)tu/xhsen.
10. tau=t), this state of things (e)n oi(=s...e(/teros), understood also as subject of menei=.

The Peroration is confined to this single impressive sentence. As he began his oration by beseeching the Gods to put it into the hearts of the judges to hear him impartially, so now he implores them to change the hearts of the traitors within the state, or, if it is too late for this, to annihilate them utterly as the only hope of safety to honest men.
2. ma/lista me\n, if possible, best of all.

3. e)nqei/hte, may you inspire even in them: this combines the wish with an exhortation (M.T. 725). In the corresponding clause with de\ we have the imperatives poih/sate and do/te.— ei) d) a)/r), but if after all.

4. au)tou\s kaq' e(autou\s: the strongest expression for by themselves. —e)cw/leis kai\ prow/leis poih/sate, cause them to be destroyed utterly and before their time: see Shilleto's note on XIX. 172, e)cw/lhs a)poloi/mhn kai\ prow/lhs. Westermann quotes an inscription of Halicarnassus from Keil, Sched. Epigr. p. 36: e)cw/lhs kai\ panw/lhs e)/stw kai\ ge/nos e)k ge/nous, kai\ mh/te gh= bath\ au)tw=| mh/te qa/lassa plwth/.
5. e)n gh=| kai\ qala/tth|, i.e. in all their ways.

6. e)phrthme/nwn, impending: for the passive of e)partw= see XXIII. 140, tosou=tos e)ph/rthtai fo/bos. Cf. Aesch. I. 175, fo/bous e)ph/rthsa toi=s a)krowme/nois, i.e. I caused terrors to hang over them (impendere).
7. swthri/an a)sfalh=, safety which cannot be shaken.

With these solemn but hopeful words of good cheer, Demosthenes leaves his case and his reputation with perfect confidence in the hands of the judges. Since the success of his burst of eloquence in §§ 51, 52, he has felt no anxiety about the judgment, and his courage has increased steadily in every stage of his argument.
